{@Aṃśu.@}¦ — I. Name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup>
2. {@Dhānaṃjayya,@} pupil of {@Amāvāsya Śāṇḍilyāyana,@} according
to the Vaṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) viii. 5, 26. {%Cf.%} Ludwig, Transla-
tion of the Rigveda, 3, 160; Hopkins,
{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
17, 89; Sieg, {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%}
129, suggests that he may be identical
with {@Khela.@}</F>

<L>2<pc>1-001<k1>aMhasaspati<k2>aMhasaspati
{@Aṃhasas-pati.@}¦ — This is the name of the intercalary month in
the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (vii. 30; xxii. 31). See {@Māsa.@}

according to Geldner,<sup>2</sup> ‘horse.’ Roth<sup>3</sup> suggests that ‘riding
horse’ is the precise sense. {%Cf.%} {@Aśva.@}

<L>4<pc>1-001<k1>akza<k2>akza<h>1
1. {@Akṣa,@}¦ ‘axle,’ is a part of a chariot often referred to in
the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later. It was apparently<sup>2</sup> fastened to the
body of the chariot ({@Kośa@}) by straps ({%akṣā-nah,%} lit. ‘tied to the
axle,’ though this word is also<sup>3</sup> rendered ‘horse’). The
heating of the axle and the danger of its breaking were known.<sup>4</sup>
The part of the axle round which the nave of the wheel
revolved was called Āṇi, ‘pin.’
<F>1) i. 30, 14; 166, 9; iii. 53, 17; vi.
24, 3; x. 89; 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 246.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 53, 7. {%Cf.%} Roth, St. Peters-
burg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 164, 13.</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-002+ 49]

<L>5<pc>1-002<k1>akza<k2>akza<h>2
2. {@Akṣa.@}¦ — This word occurs frequently, from the Rigveda
onwards, both in the singular and plural, meaning ‘die’ and
‘dice.’ Dicing, along with horse-racing, was one of the main
amusements of the Vedic Indian; but, despite the frequent
mention of the game in the literature, there is considerable
difficulty in obtaining any clear picture of the mode in which it
was played.
<div n="P"/>(1) {%The Material.%} — The dice appear normally to have been
made of Vibhīdaka nuts. Such dice are alluded to in both the
Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> hence being called ‘brown’
({%babhru%}), and ‘born on a windy spot.’<sup>3</sup> In the ritual game of
dice at the Agnyādheya and the Rājasūya ceremonies the
material of the dice is not specified, but it is possible that
occasionally gold imitations of Vibhīdaka nuts were used.<sup>4</sup>
There is no clear trace in the Vedic literature of the later use
of cowries as dice.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="P"/>(2) {%The Number.%} — In the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> the dicer is described as
‘leader of a great horde’ ({%senānīr mahato gaṇasya%}), and in
another passage<sup>7</sup> the number is given as {%tri-pañcāśaḥ,%} an expres-
sion which has been variously interpreted. Ludwig,<sup>8</sup> Weber,<sup>9</sup>
and Zimmer<sup>10</sup> render it as fifteen, which is grammatically
hardly possible. Roth<sup>11</sup> and Grassmann<sup>12</sup> render it as ‘con-
sisting of fifty-three.’ Lüders<sup>13</sup> takes it as ‘consisting of one
hundred and fifty,’ but he points out that this may be merely a
vague expression for a large number. For a small number
Zimmer<sup>14</sup> cites a reference in the Rigveda<sup>15</sup> to one who fears
‘him who holds four’ ({%caturaś cid dadamānāt%}), but the sense of
that passage is dependent on the view taken of the method of
playing the game.
<div n="P"/>(3) {%The Method of Play.%} — In several passages of the later
[Page1-003+ 49]
Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas lists are given of expressions con-
nected with dicing. The names are Kṛta, Tretā, Dvāpara,
Āskanda, and Abhibhū in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā.<sup>16</sup> In the
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>17</sup> among the victims at the Puruṣamedha,
the {%kitava%} is offered to the Akṣarāja, the {%ādinava-darśa%} to the
Kṛta, the {%kalpin%} to the Tretā, the {%adhi-kalpin%} to the Dvāpara,
the {%sabhā-sthāṇu%} to the Āskanda. The lists in the parallel
version of the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa are {%kitava, sabhāvin, ādinava-%}
{%darśa, bahiḥ-sad,%} and {%sabhā-sthāṇu,%}<sup>18</sup> and Aksarāja, Kṛta, Tretā,
Dvāpara, and Kali. From the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>19</sup> it appears
that another name of Kali was Abhibhū, and the parallel lists
in the Taittirīya and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitās suggest that Abhibhū
and Akṣarāja are identical, though both appear in the late
Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa list. The names of some of these throws
go back even to the Rigveda and the Atharvaveda. Kali occurs
in the latter,<sup>20</sup> and Lüders<sup>21</sup> shows that in a considerable number
of passages in the former Kṛta means a ‘throw’ (not ‘a stake’<sup>22</sup>
or ‘what is won’<sup>23</sup> and this sense is clearly found in the
Atharvaveda.<sup>24</sup> Moreover, that there were more throws ({%ayāḥ%})
than one is proved by a passage in the Rigveda,<sup>25</sup> when
the gods are compared to throws as giving or destroying
wealth.
<div n="P"/>The nature of the throws is obscure. The St. Petersburg
Dictionary conjectures that the names given above were applied
either to dice marked 4, 3, 2, or 1, or to the sides of the dice so
marked, and the latter interpretation is supported by some late
commentators.<sup>26</sup> But there is no evidence for the former
interpretation, and, as regards the latter, the shape of the
Vibhīdaka nuts,<sup>27</sup> used as dice, forbids any side being properly
on the top. Light is thrown on the expressions by the descrip-
[Page1-004+ 52]
tion of a ritual game<sup>28</sup> at the Agnyādheya and at the Rājasūya
ceremonies. The details are not certain,<sup>29</sup> but it is clear that
the game consisted in securing even numbers of dice, usually a
number divisible by four, the Kṛta, the other three throws then
being the Tretā, when three remained over after division by
four; the Dvāpara, when two was the remainder; and the Kali,
when one remained. If five were the dividing number, then the
throw which showed no remainder was Kali, the Kṛta was that
when four was left, and so on. The dice had no numerals
marked on them, the only question being what was the total
number of the dice themselves.
<div n="P"/>There is no reason to doubt that the game as played in the
Rigveda was based on the same principle, though the details
must remain doubtful. The number of dice used was certainly
large,<sup>30</sup> and the reference to throwing fours,<sup>31</sup> and losing by one,
points to the use of the Kṛta as the winning throw. The
Atharvaveda,<sup>32</sup> on the other hand, possibly knew of the Kali as
the winning throw. In one respect the ordinary game must
have differed from the ritual game. In the latter the players
merely pick out the number of dice required — no doubt to avoid
ominous errors, such as must have happened if a real game had
been played. In the secular game the dice were thrown,<sup>33</sup>
perhaps on the principle suggested by Lüders:<sup>34</sup> the one
throwing a certain number on the place of playing, and the other
then throwing a number to make up with those already thrown
a multiple of four or five. This theory, at any rate, accounts for
the later stress laid on the power of computation in a player,
as in the Nala.
<div n="P"/>No board appears to have been used, but a depression on which
[Page1-005+ 60]
the dice were thrown ({%adhi-devana, devana,%}<sup>35</sup> {%iriṇa%}<sup>36</sup> ), was made
in the ground. No dice box was used, but reference is made to
a case for keeping dice in ({%akṣa-vapana%}<sup>37</sup> The throw was called
{%graha%}<sup>38</sup> or earlier {%grābha.%}<sup>39</sup> The stake is called {%vij.%}<sup>40</sup> Serious
losses could be made at dicing: in the Rigveda a dicer laments
the loss of all his property, including his wife.<sup>41</sup> Lüders<sup>42</sup> finds
a different form of the game referred to in the Chāndogya
Upaniṣad.<sup>43</sup>
<F>1) vii. 86, 6; x. 34, 1.</F>

<L>6<pc>1-005<k1>akza<k2>akza<h>3
3. {@Akṣa.@}¦ — In the Chāndogya Upaniṣad (vii. 3, 1) this word
seems to denote the nut of the Vibhīdaka ({%Terminalia bellerica%}).
<LEND>

<L>7<pc>1-005<k1>akzata<k2>akzata
{@Akṣata@}¦ or {@Akṣita.@} — In one passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup>
dealing with the {@Jāyānya,@} mention is made of a remedy for
sores designated both Akṣita and Sukṣata, or, according to
the reading of the Kauṣika Sūtra, Akṣata and Sukṣata, while
Sāyaṇa has Akṣita and Sukṣita. Bloomfield<sup>2</sup> renders ‘not
caused by cutting’ and ‘caused by cutting.’ Formerly<sup>3</sup> he
suggested ‘tumour’ or ‘boil.’ Whitney<sup>4</sup> thinks that two
varieties of Jāyānya are meant. Ludwig<sup>5</sup> reads with Sāyana
{%akṣita,%} which he renders by ‘not firmly established’ in the
invalid. Zimmer<sup>6</sup> finds in it a disease Kṣata.
<F>1) vii. 76, 4.</F>
<F>2) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 17, 562.</F>
<F>3) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
{%Society,%} 13, cxvii. {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Atharvaveda
442.</F>
<F>5) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 500.</F>
<F>6) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 377.</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-006+ 47]

<L>9<pc>1-006<k1>akzu<k2>akzu
{@Akṣu.@}¦ — The word occurs in two passages of the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup>
and one of the Rigveda.<sup>2</sup> Roth<sup>3</sup> renders it by ‘net,’ while
Böhtlingk<sup>4</sup> suggests ‘axle of a car.’ Geldner<sup>5</sup> sees in it a stake
or pole used with a fishermen's net ({@Jāla@}),<sup>6</sup> the pole of a wagon,<sup>7</sup>
and the pole of a house, whether vertical or horizontal, he leaves
uncertain (see {@Vaṃśa@}).<sup>8</sup> Bloomfield<sup>9</sup> takes it as a covering
of wickerwork stretched across a beam and sloping down to
both sides — like a thatched roof, and this best explains the
epithet ‘thousand-eyed’ ({%i.e.,%} with countless holes) ascribed to
it. In the other Atharvaveda passage<sup>10</sup> he accepts the sense
‘net,’ and doubts if the word in the Rigveda is not an adjective
({%a-kṣu%}) as it is taken by Sāyaṇa. See also {@Gṛha.@}
<F>1) viii. 8, 18 ({%akṣujālābhyām%}); ix. 3, 18.</F>
<F>2) i. 180, 5.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 136.</F>
<F>6) Av. viii. 8, 18.</F>
<F>7) Av. i. 180, 5.</F>
<F>8) ix. 3, 18.</F>
<F>9) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 598.</F>
<F>10) Av. viii. 8, 18.

265; Whitney, Translation of the
Atharvaveda, 506, 526; Oldenberg,
{%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 179.</F>

<F>1) iv. 9, 3. {%Cf.%} {@Sieg,@} {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 127, n. 5.</F>

<L>11<pc>1-006<k1>agastya<k2>agastya
{@Agastya.@}¦ — This is the name of a sage, of mythical character,
who plays a great part in the later literature. He was a {@Māna,@}<sup>1</sup>
and therefore is called {@Mānya@}<sup>2</sup> and son of Māna, and only once
is there a reference<sup>3</sup> to the legend prevalent in latter times that
he was a son of Mitra and Varuṇa.
<div n="P"/>His greatest feat was the reconciliation of Indra and the
Maruts after Indra had been annoyed at his proposing to give
the Maruts an offering to the exclusion of Indra. This feat is
the subject of three hymns of the Rigveda,<sup>4</sup> and is often referred
[Page1-007+ 62]
to in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>5</sup> though the exact details and significance
of the legend are variously treated by Oldenberg,<sup>6</sup> Sieg,<sup>7</sup> Hertel,<sup>8</sup>
and von Schroeder.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>He also appears in a strange dialogue with Lopāmudrā in
the Rigveda,<sup>10</sup> which appears to show him as an ascetic who
finally yields to temptation. Von {@Schroeder@}<sup>11</sup> regards it as
a ritual drama of vegetation magic.
<div n="P"/>In another passage of the Rigveda<sup>12</sup> he appears as helping
in the Aśvins’ gift of a leg to Viśpalā. Sāyaṇa holds that be
was the Purohita of {@Khela,@} and Sieg<sup>13</sup> accepts this view, while
Pischel<sup>14</sup> thinks that Khela is a deity, Vivasvant.
<div n="P"/>Geldner<sup>15</sup> shows from the Rigveda<sup>16</sup> that Agastya, as brother
of Vasiṣṭha — both being miraculous sons of Mitra and Varuṇa
-introduces {@Vasiṣṭha@} to the {@Tṛtsus.@} There are two other
references to Agastya in the Rigveda, the one<sup>17</sup> including him
in a long list of persons, the other alluding to his sister's sons
({%nadbhyaḥ%}),<sup>18</sup> apparently {@Bandhu,@} etc. In the Atharvaveda<sup>19</sup>
he appears as connected with witchcraft, and in a long list of
sages.<sup>20</sup> In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>21</sup> cows, with a peculiar
mark on their ears ({%viṣṭya-karṇyaḥ%}), are associated with him.
<F>1) Rv. vii. 33, 10 (Agastya), 13 (Māna).</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 165, 15 = 166, 15 = 167, 11 =
168, 10; 165, 14; 177, 5; 184, 4 (Mānya);
i. 189, 8; 117, 11 ({%Mānasya sūnu%}).</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 33, 13. {%Cf.%} Geldner,
{%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 138 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 165; 170; 171.</F>

[Page1-008+ 47]

<L>13<pc>1-008<k1>agnidagDa<k2>agnidagDa
{@Agni-dagdha.@}¦ — This epithet (‘burnt with fire’)<sup>1</sup> applies to
the dead who were burned on the funeral pyre. This is one
of the two normal methods of disposing of the dead, the other
being burial ({%an-agnidagdhāḥ,%} ‘not burnt with fire’).<sup>2</sup> The
Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> adds two further modes of disposal to those — 
viz., casting out ({%paroptāḥ%}), and the exposure of the dead
({%uddhitāḥ%}). The exact sense of these expressions is doubtful.
Zimmer<sup>4</sup> considers that the former is a parallel to the Iranian
practice of casting out the dead to be devoured by beasts, and
that the latter refers to the old who are exposed when helpless.<sup>5</sup>
Whitney<sup>6</sup> refers the latter expression to the exposure of the
dead body on a raised platform of some sort.
<div n="P"/>Burial was clearly not rare in the Rigvedic period: a whole
hymn<sup>7</sup> describes the ritual attending it. The dead man was
buried apparently in full attire, with his bow in his hand, and
probably at one time his wife was immolated to accompany
him, in accordance with a practice common among savage
tribes. But in the Vedic period both customs appear in a
modified form: the son takes the bow from the hand of the
dead man, and the widow is led away from her dead husband
by his brother or other nearest kinsman. A stone is set
between the dead and the living to separate them. In the
Atharvaveda,<sup>8</sup> but not in the Rigveda, a coffin ({%vṛkṣa%}) is alluded
to. In both Saṃhitās<sup>9</sup> occur other allusions to the ‘house
of earth’ ({%bhūmi-gṛha%}). To remove the apparent discrepancy
between burning and burial, by assuming that the references to
burial are to the burial of the burned bones, as does Oldenberg,<sup>10</sup>
is unnecessary and improbable, as burning and burial subsisted
side by side in Greece for many years.
<div n="P"/>Burning was, however, equally usual, and it grew steadily
in frequency, for in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad<sup>11</sup> the adornment
[Page1-009+ 56]
of the body of the dead with curd ({@Āmikṣā@}), clothes, and
ornaments, in order to win the next world, is referred to as
something erroneous and wrong, and in the funeral Mantras of
the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>12</sup> only burning seems to be contemplated;
the verses which refer to burial here really alluding to the burial
of the ashes in the burying-ground ({%śmaśāna%}).<sup>13</sup> The body was
wrapped in fat,<sup>14</sup> as we learn from the funeral hymn in the
Rigveda, a goat being apparently burned with it,<sup>15</sup> to act as
a guide on the way to the next world. According to the
Atharvaveda<sup>16</sup> a draft-ox was burned presumably for the dead
to ride with in the next world. It was expected that the dead
would revive with his whole body and all his limbs ({%sarva-tanūḥ%}
{%sāṅgaḥ%}),<sup>17</sup> although it is also said<sup>18</sup> that the eye goes to the sun,
the breath to the wind, and so forth.
<div n="P"/>Before burial or burning, the corpse was washed,<sup>19</sup> a clog
({%kūdī%}) being tied to the foot to prevent the deceased returning
to earth.<sup>20</sup>
<F>1) Rv. x. 15, 14; Taittirīya Brāh-
maṇa, iii. 1, 1, 7; {%dagdhāḥ,%} Av. xviii.
2, 34.</F>
<F>2) Rv., {%loc. cit.;%} = {%nikhātāḥ,%} Av. xviii.
2, 34.</F>
<F>3) {%Loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 402.</F>
<F>5) Rv. viii. 51, 2.</F>
<F>6) Translation of the Atharvaveda, 841.</F>
<F>7) x. 18. The interpretation of v. 8 is
a famous crux, see Patnī.</F>
<F>8) xviii. 2, 25; 3, 70.</F>
<F>9) Rv. vii. 89, 1; Av. v. 30, 14; xviii.
2, 52.</F>
<F>10) {%Religion des Veda,%} 571.</F>
<F>11) viii. 8. 5.</F>
<F>12) xxxv. {%Cf.%} also Kauśika Sūtra,
80 {%et seq.,%} which treats the Atharvaveda
hymns, xviii. 1-3, as intended for

<F>13) Av. v. 31, 8; x. 1, 18; Taittirīya
Saṃhitā, v. 2, 8, 5; 4, 11, 3.</F>
<F>14) Rv. x. 16, 7.</F>
<F>15) Rv. x. 16, 4. But {%aja%} may mean

to take it, Proceedings of the Berlin

<L>16<pc>1-010<k1>aGA<k2>aGA
{@Aghā.@}¦ — In the wedding hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> it is said that
cows are slain in the Aghās, and the wedding takes place at the
{@Arjunīs@} (dual). The Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> has the ordinary {@Maghās@}
instead. It is impossible to resist the conclusion that the read-
ing of the Rigveda was deliberately altered because of the con-
nection of the slaughter of kine with sin ({%agha%}) — possibly, too,
with a further desire to emphasize the contrast with {%aghnyā,%}
a name for ‘cow.’ Moreover, in the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup>
occurs the formula ‘Svāhā to the Maghās, Svāhā to the
Anaghās.’ See also {@Nakṣatra.@}
<F>1) x. 85, 13.</F>
<F>2) xiv. 1, 13.</F>
<F>3) iii. 1, 4, 8.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Naxatra,%} 2, 364; Pro-
ceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1894,
804; Jacobi, {%Festgruss an Roth,%} 69;
Winternitz, {%Das altindische Hochzeits-%}
{%rituell,%} 32; Whitney, Translation of the
Atharvaveda, 742; Thibaut, {%Indian%}
{%Antiquary,%} 24, 95.</F>

<L>19<pc>1-010<k1>aNka<k2>aNka
{@Aṅka.@}¦ — The Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>1</sup> and Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> refer to two
Aṅkas and two Nyaṅkas as parts of a chariot. The meaning
of these terms is quite obscure. The commentators refer them
to the sides or wheels. Zimmer<sup>3</sup> compares the Greek <lang n="greek">ἄντυγες</lang><sup>4</sup>
and thinks that the Aṅkau were the upper border of the body
of the chariot ({%kośa, vandhura%}), and the Nyaṅkau the lower rims
for greater security. Oldenberg<sup>5</sup> confesses that the exact sense
is impossible to make out, but considers that the terms at once
refer to parts of the chariot and to divinities, while Böhtlingk<sup>6</sup>
takes the term as referring to divinities alone.
<F>1) i. 7, 7, 2.</F>
<F>2) ii. 7, 8, 1. {%Cf.%} Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
maṇa, i. 7, 5.</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 251, 252.</F>
<F>4) {%Iliad,%} v. 728. {%Cf.%} Smith's {%Dic-%}
{%tionary of Antiquities,%} 1, 578.</F>
<F>5) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 29, 364, on
Pāraskara Gṛhya Sūtra, iii. 14, 6.</F>
<F>6) Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>

<L>20<pc>1-011<k1>aNga<k2>aNga
{@Aṅga.@}¦ — The name occurs only once in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> in
connection with the {@Gandhāris, Mūjavants,@} and {@Magadhas,@} as
distinct peoples. They appear also in the Gopatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup>
in the compound name {%Aṅga-magadhāḥ.%} As in later times they
were settled on the Sone and Ganges,<sup>3</sup> their earlier seat was
presumably there also. See also {@Vaṅga.@}
<F>1) v. 22, 14.</F>
<F>2) ii. 9.</F>

446, 449; Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal%}
{%Asiatic Society,%} 1908, 852, inclines to
regard them as a non-Aryan people
that came over-sea to Eastern India.
There is nothing in the Vedic litera-
ture to throw light on this hypothesis.</F>

<L>22<pc>1-011<k1>aNgArAvakzayaRa<k2>aNgArAvakzayaRa
{@Aṅgārāvakṣayaṇa.@}¦ — A word of doubtful meaning found

Max Müller and Böhtlingk in their translations. The St.
Petersburg Dictionary explains it as ‘a vessel in which coals

renders the word ‘coal-shovel or tongs.’ {%Cf.%} {@Ulmukāva-@}

<L>23<pc>1-011<k1>aNgiras<k2>aNgiras
{@Aṅgiras.@}¦ — The Aṅgirases appear in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as semi-
mythical beings, and no really historical character can be
assigned even to those passages<sup>2</sup> which recognize a father of
the race, Aṅgiras. Later, however, there were definite families
of Aṅgirases, to whose ritual practices ({%ayana, dvirātra%}) references
are made.<sup>3</sup>

ii. 156-169.</F>

etc.; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, i. 2, 10.</F>
<F>3) Av. xviii. 4, 8, but this may be
mythical; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xx.
11, 1; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 4, 1.
{%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%} 142, 143.</F>

<L>26<pc>1-012<k1>aja<k2>aja
{@Aja, Ajā.@}¦ — This is the ordinary name for goat in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
and the later literature. The goat is also called {@Basta, Chāga,@}
{@Chagala.@} Goats and sheep ({%ajāvayaḥ%}) are very frequently
mentioned together.<sup>2</sup> The female goat is spoken of as pro-
ducing two or three kids,<sup>3</sup> and goat's milk is well known.<sup>4</sup>
The goat as representative of Pūṣan plays an important part
in the ritual of burial.<sup>5</sup> The occupation of a goatherd ({%ajapāla%})
was a recognized one, being distinguished from that of a cow-
herd and of a shepherd.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) {%Aja%} in Rv. x. 16, 4; i. 162, 2. 4;
Av. ix. 5, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi.
9, etc.; {%ajā%} in Rv. viii. 70, 15; Av. vi.
71, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii., 56,
etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 90, 10; Av. viii. 7, 25;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 43, etc.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 1.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 6, 1; v.
1, 7, 4. {%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische%}
{%Mythologie,%} 3, 364, n. 4.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 16, 4, etc. {%Cf.%} p. 9.</F>

<L>27<pc>1-012<k1>aja<k2>aja
{@Aja.@}¦ — The Ajas are named in one verse of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as
having been defeated by the {@Tṛtsus@} under {@Sudās.@} They are
there mentioned with the {@Yakṣus@} and {@Śigrus,@} and Zimmer<sup>2</sup>
conjectures that they formed part of a confederacy under
Bheda against Sudās. The name has been regarded as a sign
of totemism,<sup>3</sup> but this is very uncertain, and it is impossible to
say if they were or were not Āryans.
<F>1) vii. 18. 19.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 127, {%Cf.%} Ludwig,
Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173.</F>

153; Keith, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
{%Society,%} 1907, 929; Aitareya Āraṇyaka,

{%et seq.%}</F>

<L>33<pc>1-013<k1>ajYAtayakzma<k2>ajYAtayakzma
{@Ajñāta-yakṣma,@}¦ the ‘unknown sickness,’ is mentioned in
the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> and Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā.<sup>3</sup> It is
referred to in connection with Rājayakṣma. Grohmann<sup>4</sup> thinks
that the two are different forms of disease, hypertrophy and
atrophy, the purpose of the spell in the Rigveda being thus the
removal of all disease. From the Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> he deduces its
identity with {@Balāsa.@} Zimmer,<sup>6</sup> however, points out that this
[Page1-014+ 42]
conclusion is unjustified, leaving the disease unidentified, which
seems to accord with its name.

<L>34<pc>1-014<k1>ajina<k2>ajina
{@Ajina.@}¦ — This word denotes generally the skin of an animal
-{%e.g.,%} a gazelle,<sup>1</sup> as well as that of a goat ({@Aja@}).<sup>2</sup> The use
of skins as clothing is shown by the adjective ‘clothed in skins’
({%ajina-vāsin%}) in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> and the furrier's trade
is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>4</sup> The Maruts also
wear deer-skins,<sup>5</sup> and the wild ascetics ({%muni%}) of a late Rigveda
hymn<sup>6</sup> seem to be clad in skins ({@Mala@}).

<L>39<pc>1-014<k1>aRu<k2>aRu
{@Aṇu.@}¦ — This is the designation in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>1</sup> and
the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>2</sup> of a cultivated grain, {@apparently@}
the {%Panicum miliaceum.%}

<L>40<pc>1-014<k1>atiTi<k2>atiTi
{@Atithi@}¦ (‘guest’). — A hymn of the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> celebrates in
detail the merits of hospitality. The guest should be fed before
[Page1-015+ 50]
the host eats, water should be offered to him, and so forth.
The Taittirīya Upaniṣad<sup>2</sup> also lays stress on hospitality, using
the expression ‘one whose deity is his guest’ ({%atithi-deva%}). In
the Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>3</sup> it is said that only the good are deemed
worthy of receiving hospitality. The guest-offering forms a
regular part of the ritual,<sup>4</sup> and cows were regularly slain in
honour of guests.<sup>5</sup>
<F>1) ix. 6.</F>
<F>2) i. 11, 2.</F>
<F>3) i. 1, 1.</F>
<F>4) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vii. 3, 2, 1.</F>
<F>5) {%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%American Journal of%}
{%Philology,%} 17, 426; Hillebrandt, {%Ritual-%}
{%litteratur,%} 79.</F>
<LEND>

<L>41<pc>1-015<k1>atiTigva<k2>atiTigva
{@Atithi-gva.@}¦ — This name occurs frequently in the Rigveda,
apparently applying, in nearly all cases, to the same king,
otherwise called {@Divodāsa.@} The identity of the two persons
has been denied by Bergaigne,<sup>1</sup> but is certainly proved by a
number of passages, when the two names occur together,<sup>2</sup> in
connection with the defeat of {@Śambara.@} In other passages<sup>3</sup>
Atithigva is said to have assisted Indra in slaying Parṇaya and
Karañja. Sometimes he is only vaguely referred to, while once<sup>5</sup> he
is mentioned as an enemy of Turvaśa and Yadu. Again<sup>6</sup> Atithigva
is coupled with {@Āyu@} and {@Kutsa@} as defeated by {@Tūrvayāṇa.@}
<div n="P"/>A different Atithigva appears to be referred to in a Dānastuti<sup>7</sup>
(‘Praise of Gifts’), where his son, {@Indrota,@} is mentioned.
<div n="P"/>Roth<sup>8</sup> distinguishes three Atithigvas — the Atithigva Divodāsa,
the enemy of Parṇaya and Karañja, and the enemy of Tūrvayāṇa.
But the various passages can be reconciled, especially if it is
admitted that Atithigva Divodāsa was already an ancient hero
in the earliest hymns, and was becoming almost mythical.
<div n="P"/><sup>4</sup>
<F>1) {%Religion Védique,%} 2, 342 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 51, 6; 112, 14; 130, 7;
iv. 26, 3; vi. 47, 22.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 53, 8; x. 48, 8.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 19, 8. There is no ground
for assuming the reference here to be
to a later Atithigva.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 53, 10; ii. 14, 7; vi. 18, 13;
viii. 53, 2.</F>
<F>7) Rv. viii. 68, 16. 17.</F>
<F>8) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the
Rigveda, 3, 123; Bloomfield, {%American%}
{%Journal of Philology,%} 17, 426, who renders
the name ‘presenting cows to guests.’</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 26, 3.</F>

<L>44<pc>1-016<k1>atka<k2>atka<h>1
1. {@Atka.@}¦ — This word occurs frequently in the Rigveda, but its
sense is doubtful. Roth, Grassmann, Ludwig, Zimmer,<sup>1</sup> and
others render it as ‘garment’ in several passages,<sup>2</sup> when the
expressions ‘put on’ ({%vyā%} or {%prati muñc%}) or ‘put off’ ({%muñc%}) are
used of it, and when it is said to be ‘woven’ ({%vyuta%})<sup>3</sup> or ‘well-
fitting’ ({%surabhi%}).<sup>4</sup> On the other hand, Pischel<sup>5</sup> denies that this
sense occurs, and otherwise explains the passages. He takes
the term to mean ‘axe’ in four places.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 262.</F>
<F>2) i. 95, 7; ii. 35, 14; iv. 18, 5;
v. 55, 6; 74, 5; vi. 29, 3; viii. 41, 7;
ix. 101, 14; 107, 13; Sāmaveda,
ii. 1193.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 122, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 29, 3; x. 123, 7.</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 193-204.</F>
<F>6) Rv. v. 55, 6; vi. 33, 3; x. 49, 3; 99, 9.
{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 94, n. 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>45<pc>1-016<k1>atka<k2>atka<h>2
2. {@Atka.@}¦ — In two passages of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> this word is
regarded as a proper name by Roth, Grassmann, and Ludwig.
But Zimmer<sup>2</sup> explains it in these passages as the ‘armour of a
warrior as a whole,’ and Pischel<sup>3</sup> thinks that in both cases an
‘axe’ is meant.
<F>1) x. 49, 3; 99, 9.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 262, 297.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 195.</F>
<LEND>

<L>46<pc>1-016<k1>atyaMhasAruRi<k2>atyaMhasAruRi
{@Aty-aṃhas Āruṇi.@}¦ — According to the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa
(iii. 10, 9, 3-5), this teacher sent a pupil to question {@Plakṣa@}
{@Dayyāṃpati@} as to the Sāvitra (a form of Agni). For this
impertinence his pupil was severely rebuked.

<L>47<pc>1-016<k1>atyarAtijAnaMtapi<k2>atyarAtijAnaMtapi
{@Aty-arāti Jānaṃ-tapi,@}¦ though not a prince, was taught the
Rājasūya by {@Vāsiṣṭha Satyahavya,@} and thereupon conquered
the earth. When Vāsiṣṭha reminded him of his indebtedness,
and claimed a great reward, the warrior replied irascibly that
he intended to conquer the {@Uttara Kurus,@} and that Vāsiṣṭha
would then become King of the Earth, Atyarāti himself being
his general ({%senā-pati%}). Vāsiṣṭha replied that as no mortal man
could conquer the Uttara Kurus he was cheated of his reward.
[Page1-017+ 53]
He consequently procured Atyarāti's defeat and death at the
hands of {@Amitratapana Śuṣmiṇa Śaibya.@}<sup>1</sup>
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 23. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 214.</F>

<L>48<pc>1-017<k1>atri<k2>atri
{@Atri.@}¦ — Neither Atri himself nor the Atris can claim any
historical reality,<sup>1</sup> beyond the fact that Maṇḍala V. of the Rigveda
is attributed, no doubt correctly, to the family of the Atris.<sup>2</sup>
The Atris as a family probably stood in close relations with the
{@Priyamedhas@}<sup>3</sup> and {@Kaṇvas,@}<sup>4</sup> perhaps also with the {@Gotamas@}<sup>5</sup>
and {@Kākṣīvatas.@}<sup>6</sup> The mention of both the {@Paruṣṇī@} and the
{@Yamunā@} in one hymn<sup>7</sup> of the fifth Maṇḍala seems to justify the
presumption that the family was spread over a wide extent of
territory.

donell, {%Vedic Mythology,%} 145. {%Cf.%} also
Av. ii. 32, 3; iv. 29, 3; Mantra Brāh-
maṇa, ii. 7, 1; Taittirīya Āraṇyaka,
iv. 36, etc.; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,
ii. 2, 4.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Rv. v. 39, 5; 67, 5; Kauṣītaki
Brāhmaṇa, xxiv. 3; Aitareya Āraṇyaka,
ii, 2, 1.</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 45, 3; 139, 9; viii. 5,
25; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 22.</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 118, 7; v. 41, 4;
x. 150, 5.</F>

<L>50<pc>1-017<k1>aTarvan<k2>aTarvan
{@Atharvan.@}¦ — The name in the singular denotes the head of a
semi-divine family of mythical priests,<sup>1</sup> of whom nothing his-
torical can be said. In the plural the family as a whole is
meant. In a few places an actual family seems to be referred
to. Thus, for instance, they are mentioned as recipients of
gifts in the Dānastuti<sup>2</sup> (‘Praise of Gifts’), of {@Aśvattha's@}
[Page1-018+ 56]
generosity; their use of milk mingled with honey in the ritual
is referred to;<sup>3</sup> and a cow that miscarries ({%ava-tokā%}) from accident
is dedicated to the Atharvans, according to the Taittirīya
Brāhmaṇa.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) See Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
141. In the Vaṃśa of the Bṛhad-
āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 6, 3, Atharvan
Daiva is characteristically the pupil of
Mṛtyu.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 47, 24.</F>
<F>3) Rv. ix. 11, 2.</F>
<F>4) iii. 4, 11, 1. {%Cf.%} Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
hitā, xxx. 15.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
{%vaveda,%} xxxv. {%et seq.,%} who (p. xxxviii)
takes {%avatokā%} as a woman, and the
Atharvans as the hymns; Hillebrandt,
{%Vedische Mythologie,%} 2, 174 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>52<pc>1-018<k1>aTarvANgirasaH<k2>aTarvANgirasaH
{@Atharvāṅgirasaḥ.@}¦ — This is the collective name of the Athar-
vaveda in several passages<sup>1</sup> of the later Brāhmaṇas. It occurs
once in the Atharvaveda itself,<sup>2</sup> while the term Atharvaveda
is not found before the Sūtra period.<sup>3</sup> The compound seems,
according to Bloomfield,<sup>4</sup> to denote the two elements which
make up the Atharvaveda. The former part refers to the aus-
picious practices of the Veda ({%bheṣajāni%});<sup>5</sup> the latter to its hostile
witchcraft, the {%yātu%}<sup>6</sup> or {%abhi-cāra.%}<sup>7</sup> This theory is supported by
the names of the two mythic personages {@Ghora Āṅgirasa@} and
{@Bhiṣaj Ātharvaṇa,@} as well as by the connection of Atharvāṇaḥ
and {@Ātharvaṇāni@} with healing ({%bheṣaja%}) in the Pañcaviṃśa
Brāhmaṇa.<sup>8</sup> Moreover, the term {%bhesajā%} (‘remedies’) designates
in the Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> that Veda itself, while in the Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa<sup>10</sup> {%yātu%} (‘sorcery’) conveys the same meaning. The
evidence, however, being by no means convincing, it remains
probable that there existed no clear differentiation between the
two sages as responsible for the Atharvaveda as a whole.
<F>1) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 12, 8, 2;
Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, ii. 9; 10; Śata-
patha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5, 6, 7; Bṛhad-
āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 4, 10; iv. 1, 2;
5, 11; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iii. 4, 1. 2;
Taittirīya Upaniṣad, ii. 3, 1.</F>
<F>2) x. 7, 20.</F>
<F>3) Śāṅkhāyana Srauta Sūtra, xvi. 2, 9,
etc.</F>
<F>4) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
{%Society,%} 11, 387 {%et seq.; Hymns of the%}
{%Atharvaveda,%} xviii. {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) Av. xi. 6, 14.</F>
<F>6) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, x. 5, 2, 20.</F>
<F>7) Kauśika Sūtra, 3, 19.</F>
<F>8) xii. 9, 10; xvi. 10, 10.</F>
<F>9) x. 6, 14.</F>
<F>10) x. 5, 2, 20.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}
2, 177.</F>
<LEND>

<L>53<pc>1-019<k1>adfzwa<k2>adfzwa
{@A-dṛṣṭa.@}¦ — ‘The unseen’ is a term used in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
and the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> to designate a species of vermin. The
sun is also described as ‘the slayer of the unseen’ ({%adṛṣṭa-han%}),<sup>3</sup>
and as a counterpart a ‘seen’ ({%dṛṣṭa%}) is mentioned.<sup>4</sup> In one
passage<sup>5</sup> the epithets ‘seen’ and ‘unseen’ are applied to the
worm ({@Kṛmi@}), their use being no doubt due to the widespread
theory of diseases being due to worms, whether discernable by
examination or not.<sup>6</sup>

<L>55<pc>1-019<k1>adri<k2>adri
{@Adri.@}¦ — Zimmer<sup>1</sup> deduces from the use of this word (‘rock,’

<L>57<pc>1-019<k1>aDirAja<k2>aDirAja
{@Adhi-rāja.@}¦ — The word occurs fairly often throughout the
early literature,<sup>1</sup> denoting ‘overlord’ among kings or princes.
[Page1-020+ 47]
In no passage is it clear that a real over-king is meant, as
the word {%rājan%} may mean king or merely prince, a person of
royal blood. On the whole it seems most probable that the
word connotes no more than ‘king’ as opposed to ‘prince.’

<L>58<pc>1-020<k1>aDizavaRa<k2>aDizavaRa
{@Adhi-ṣavaṇa.@}¦ — The two Adhiṣavaṇas<sup>1</sup> are usually understood,
as by Roth<sup>2</sup> and Zimmer,<sup>3</sup> to designate the two boards between
which the Soma was pressed. Hillebrandt,<sup>4</sup> however, shows
from the ritual that the boards were not placed one over the
other, but were placed one behind the other, the two serving
as a foundation upon which the Soma was pressed by a stone.
This theory seems to account best for the etymological sense
of the name ‘over-press,’ as well as for the use of the word as
an adjective (‘used for pressing {%upon%}’). But according to the
procedure as witnessed by Haug<sup>5</sup> in the Deccan, the shoots of
the plant are first placed on the skin, one of the boards being
then laid over them and pounded with a stone. The shoots
are then taken out and placed upon the board, the second
board being then laid over them.
<F>1) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 21;
Av. v. 20, 10; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
iii. 9, 4, 1; 5, 3, 22 ({%adhiṣavaṇe%}
{%phalake%}); Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 32
({%adhiṣavaṇaṃ carma,%} ‘the skin upon
which the pressing takes place’;
{%adhiṣavaṇe phalake,%} ‘the boards on
which the pressing takes place,’
etc.).</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 277.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 148 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) See Haug, Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, 2,
p. 488, n. 10.</F>
<LEND>

<L>64<pc>1-021<k1>anaqvAh<k2>anaqvAh
{@Anaḍ-vāh@}¦ (lit. ‘cart-drawer’). — This is the common<sup>1</sup> name of
oxen as employed for drawing carts ({@Anas@}). Such oxen were
normally castrated,<sup>2</sup> though not always. Female draft cattle
were also used ({%anaḍuhī%}), but rarely.<sup>3</sup> See also {@Go.@}
<F>1) Rv. x. 59, 10; 85, 10; iii. 53, 18;

<L>65<pc>1-021<k1>anas<k2>anas
{@Anas.@}¦ — This is the term<sup>1</sup> used to designate the draft wagon,
as opposed to the chariot ({%ratha%}) for war or sport, with which
it is sometimes expressly contrasted,<sup>2</sup> though Indra is once said
to be ‘seated in a wagon’ ({%anar-viś%})<sup>3</sup> instead of on a chariot.
Though Uṣas, Goddess of Dawn, sometimes rides on a chariot
({%ratha%}), the wagon is her characteristic vehicle.<sup>4</sup> Of its con-
struction we know little. The bridal wagon on which Sūryā,
the daughter of the Sun, was borne in the marriage hymn in the
Rigveda had a covering ({@Chadis@}).<sup>5</sup> The axle-box ({@Kha@}) is also
[Page1-022+ 56]
mentioned.<sup>6</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> Vipatha appears to denote a
rough vehicle used for bad tracks. The wagon was usually
drawn by oxen ({@Anaḍvāh@}), as in wedding processions.<sup>8</sup> The
wagon of Dawn is described as drawn by ruddy cows or bulls.<sup>9</sup>
<F>1) Rv. iv. 30, 10; x. 85, 10; 86,
18, etc.; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 1,
2, 5, etc.; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, vii.
15, 1; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, iii. 8,
etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. iii. 33, 9.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 121, 7.</F>
<F>4) Rv. ii. 15, 6; iv. 30, 11; viii. 91,
7; x. 73, 6; 138, 5.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 85, 10.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii. 91, 7; Jaiminīya Upaniṣad
Brāhmaṇa, i. 3.</F>
<F>7) xv. 2, 1.</F>
<F>8) Rv. x. 85, 11</F>
<F>9) Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%} 47.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 246;
Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 4.</F>

<L>68<pc>1-022<k1>anu<k2>anu
{@Anu, Ānava.@}¦ — Grassmann and Roth<sup>1</sup> see in these words
designations of people foreign to the Aryans. But it is clear<sup>2</sup>
that they denote a special people, the Anus, who are mentioned
with the {@Yadus, Turvaśas, Druhyus,@} and {@Pūrus,@}<sup>3</sup> with the
Druhyus,<sup>4</sup> and with the Turvaśas, Yadus, and Druhyus.<sup>5</sup> It
is also a fair conclusion from their mention in a passage of the
Rigveda<sup>6</sup> that they dwelt on the Paruṣṇī. The inference that
the Bhṛgus were connected with this tribe is much more
doubtful,<sup>7</sup> for it rests solely on the fact that in one place<sup>8</sup> the
Bhṛgus and Druhyus are mentioned together, and not Anus and
Druhyus. Ānava is used as an epithet of Agni,<sup>9</sup> but also in the
sense of ‘Anu prince,’<sup>10</sup> in one case in conjunction with Turvaśa.<sup>11</sup>
<F>1) St. Petersburg Dictionary.</F>
<F>2) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 125.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 108, 8.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vii. 18, 14.</F>
<F>5) viii. 10, 5.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii. 74. 15, compared with
vii. 18, 14.</F>
<F>7) Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 221, n. 1.</F>
<F>8) Rv. vii. 18, 4.</F>
<F>9) Rv. viii. 74, 4. {%Cf.%} Rv. v. 31, 4,
where the Anus prepare the chariot of
the Aśvins.</F>
<F>10) Rv. vii. 18, 13.</F>
<F>11) viii. 4, 1. Apparently as prince
also in vi. 62, 9. {%Cf.%} {@Kuruṅga.@}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the
Rigveda, 3, 205; Hillebrandt, {%Vedische%}

{%Literature,%} 154.</F>

<L>81<pc>1-024<k1>anvAKyAna<k2>anvAKyAna
{@Anvā-khyāna.@}¦ — From the literal translation (‘after-story’) the
meaning of ‘supplementary narrative’ seems to follow. In two<sup>1</sup>
of its three occurrences in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa this sense
is hardly felt, the expression being used to indicate a subse-
quent portion of the book itself. But in the third<sup>2</sup> passage it
is distinguished from the {@Itihāsa@} (‘story’) proper, and there
must mean ‘supplementary narrative.’ {%Cf.%} {@Anuvyākhyāna.@}
<F>1) vi. 5, 2, 22; 6, 4, 7 (the reference
is to vi. 6, 4, 8).</F>
<F>2) xi. 1, 6, 9.

<L>82<pc>1-024<k1>apacit<k2>apacit
{@Apa-cit.@}¦ — This word occurs several times in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup>
It is held by Roth,<sup>2</sup> Zimmer,<sup>3</sup> and others to denote an insect
whose sting produced swellings, etc. ({%glau%}). But Bloomfield<sup>4</sup>
shows that the disease, scrofulous swellings, is what is really
meant, as is shown by the rendering ({%gaṇḍa-mālā,%} ‘inflammation
of the glands of the neck’) of Keśava and Sāyaṇa, and by the
parallelism of the later disease, {%apacī,%} the derivation being from
{%apa%} and {%ci,%} ‘to pick off.’
<F>1) vi. 25, 1; 83, 1; vii. 75, 1; 77, 1.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 97. So also
Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda,
3, 342, 500.</F>

320 {%et seq.; Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%}
503, 504. {%Cf.%} Jolly, {%Medicin,%} 89;

vaveda, 343.</F>

<L>84<pc>1-025<k1>apaskamBa<k2>apaskamBa
{@Apa-skambha.@}¦ — The word occurs only in one passage of the
Atharvaveda, where the tip of it is mentioned as poisoned.

corruption of text. Zimmer<sup>3</sup> follows Roth. Ludwig<sup>4</sup> renders
the word by ‘barb.’ Bloomfield<sup>5</sup> thinks it means ‘tearing
(arrow),’ a sense deduced from the etymology.

<L>86<pc>1-025<k1>apAna<k2>apAna
{@Apāna.@}¦ — The word appears repeatedly in the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup>
and later as one of the vital breaths ({@Prāṇa@}), usually with
Prāṇa, and often with one or more of the other three. Its
original sense<sup>2</sup> appears to have been ‘inspiration.’ Its con-
nection with the lower part of the body ({%nābhi,%} ‘navel’), which
is found already in the Aitareya Upaniṣad,<sup>3</sup> is not unnatural.
<F>1) Av. ii. 28, 3; v. 30, 12, etc.; Vāja-

<L>87<pc>1-025<k1>apAmArga<k2>apAmArga
{@Apā-mārga.@}¦ — A plant ({%Achyranthes aspera%}) used frequently<sup>1</sup> in
witchcraft practices, and for medical purposes, especially against
{@Kṣetriya.@} It is described in the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> as ‘revertive’
({%punaḥ-sara%}), either, as Roth<sup>3</sup> and Zimmer<sup>4</sup> think, because of
its having reverted leaves (a view also accepted by Whitney<sup>5</sup> ),
[Page1-026+ 46]
or because, as Bloomfield<sup>6</sup> holds, it wards off a spell by
causing it to recoil on its user.
<F>1) Atharvaveda, iv. 17, 6; 18, 7;
19, 4; vii. 65, 2; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
xxxv. 11; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 7,

xiii. 8, 4, 4.</F>
<F>2) iv. 17, 2.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>

sons divided the property amongst themselves while he was

<L>101<pc>1-028<k1>aBipraSnin<k2>aBipraSnin
{@Abhi-praśnin.@}¦ — This term occurs after {@Praśnin,@} and followed
by {@Praśnavivāka@} in the list of victims for the Puruṣamedha
given in the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> and the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>2</sup>
The commentators, Sāyaṇa and Mahīdhara, see in it merely a
reference to an inquisitive man. But there can be little doubt
that the term must have had a legal reference of some sort — 
perhaps indicating the defendant as opposed to plaintiff and
judge.
<F>1) iii. 4, 6, 1.</F>
<F>2) xxx. 10.</F>

<L>104<pc>1-028<k1>aBizeka<k2>aBizeka
{@Abhi-ṣeka@}¦ (‘besprinkling’). — The Vedic king was conse-
crated after his election with an elaborate ritual, which is fully
described in the Taittirīya,<sup>1</sup> Pañcaviṃśa,<sup>2</sup> Śatapatha,<sup>3</sup> and
Aitareya Brāhmaṇas,<sup>4</sup> and for which the Mantras are given in
the Saṃhitās.<sup>5</sup> The consecration took place by sprinkling with
water ({%abhiṣecanīyā āpaḥ%}).<sup>6</sup> Only kings could be consecrated,
the people not being worthy of it ({%anabhiṣecanīyāḥ%}).<sup>7</sup> The
sprinkler ({%abhiṣektṛ%}) is mentioned in the list of victims at the
Puruṣamedha.<sup>8</sup> The Abhiṣeka is an essential part of the
{@Rājasūya,@} or sacrifice of royal inauguration, being the second
of its component members.
<div n="P"/>9 {%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Rituallitteratur,%}
143-147; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the%}
{%East,%} 41, xxvi; Weber, {%Über den%}
{%Rājasūya.%}

<F>2) xviii. 8 {%et seq.%}</F>

<F>4) viii. 5 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 8, 11; Kāṭh-

hitā, ii. 6; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 1-4.</F>
<F>6) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 3, 5, 10-15,</F>

<L>105<pc>1-029<k1>aBISu<k2>aBISu
{@Abhīśu@}¦ is a common Vedic word<sup>1</sup> denoting the ‘reins’ or
‘bridle’ of the chariot horses. The use of the plural is due to
the fact that two or four horses, possibly five ({%daśābhīśu%} ‘ten-
bridled’),<sup>2</sup> were yoked to the car.
<F>1) Rv. i. 38, 12; v. 44, 4; vi. 75, 6;
viii. 33, 11; Av. vi. 137, 2; viii. 8, 22;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 6; Śata-
patha Brāhmaṇa, v. 4, 3, 14 (where it
= {%raśmayaḥ,%} ‘reins’), etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 94, 7.</F>

<L>106<pc>1-029<k1>aByagniEtaSAyana<k2>aByagniEtaSAyana
{@Abhy-agni Aitaśāyana.@}¦ — This man was, according to the
Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> unfortunate enough to quarrel with his
father, {@Aitaśa.@} The result was that he and his progeny were
called the worst of the {@Aurvas.@} In the version of the Kauṣītaki
Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> the {@Aitaśāyana Ājāneyas@} take the place of the
Abhyagnis and the {@Bhṛgus@} of the {@Aurvas,@} the latter being
probably a branch of the former family.
<F>1) vi. 33.</F>
<F>2) xxx. 5. {%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 2, 173.</F>

<L>107<pc>1-029<k1>aByAvartincAyamAna<k2>aByAvartincAyamAna
{@Abhyā-vartin Cāyamāna@}¦ appears in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of
Gifts’) in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and as conqueror of the Vṛcīvants
under the leader {@Varaśikha.@} It is probable though not abso-
lutely certain, that he is identical with the {@Sṛñjaya Daivavāta,@}
mentioned in the same hymn<sup>2</sup> as having the {@Turvaśas@} and
{@Vṛcīvants@} defeated for him by Indra. In this case he would
be prince ({%samrāj%}) of the Sṛñjayas. Daivavāta is mentioned
elsewhere<sup>3</sup> as a worshipper of Agni.
<div n="P"/>Abhyāvartin is also referred to as a Pārthava. Ludwig<sup>4</sup> and
Hillebrandt<sup>5</sup> maintained that he is thus a Parthian, the latter
using the evidence of the two places mentioned in the descrip-
tion<sup>6</sup> of Daivavāta's victories, {@Hariyūpīyā@} and {@Yavyāvatī,@} as
proofs for the western position of Abhyāvartin's people in
Arachosia, in Iran. But Zimmer<sup>7</sup> is probably right in holding
that the name Pārthava merely means ‘a descendant of Pṛthu,’
and that its similarity to the Iranian Parthians is only on a par
with the numerous other points of identity between the Indian
and Iranian cultures.
<F>1) vi. 27, 8. 5.</F>
<F>2) vi. 27, 7.</F>
<F>3) iv. 15, 4.</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 198
{%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 105; 3, 268,
n. 1. {%Cf.%} Grierson, {%Journal of the Royal%}
{%Asiatic Society,%} 1908, 604 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>6) Rv. vi. 27, 5. 6.</F>
<F>7) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 133 {%et seq.,%} 433;
Bergaigne, {%Religion Védique,%} 2, 362.</F>

<L>108<pc>1-030<k1>aBrAtaraH<k2>aBrAtaraH
{@A-bhrātaraḥ@}¦ (‘brotherless’). — The lot of girls without brothers
is referred to in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as unsatisfactory — apparently
they became prostitutes. The Nirukta<sup>2</sup> expressly forbids
marriage with a brotherless maiden, probably because of the
risk of her being made a {%putrikā%} (‘adoptive daughter’) by her
father — that is, any son of hers being counted as belonging to
her father's, instead of to her husband's, family. See {@Ayogū.@}
<F>1) i. 124, 7; iv. 5, 5. {%Cf.%} Av.
i. 17, 1.</F>
<F>2) iii. 5 ({%abhrātrī%}).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
{%vaveda,%} 259; Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
328.</F>
<LEND>

<L>109<pc>1-030<k1>aBri<k2>aBri
{@Abhri@}¦ (‘spade’) is a Vedic word<sup>1</sup> of frequent occurrence.
Various possible materials and forms are enumerated in the
Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> It may be made of bamboo or of the wood
of Vikaṅkata or Udumbara. It may be a span or a cubit in size.
It is hollow, and either one or both edges are sharp. From
this it would appear that the handle was made of some wood,
but the head of some metal.

out with a spade,’ not ‘prepared
ground’ with Roth, St. Petersburg
Dictionary, {%s.v.%}); x. 4, 14; {%hiraṇya-%}
{%yībhir abhribhiḥ,%} ‘with golden spades’);
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 22; xi. 10;
xxxvii. 1; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xvi.
6; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 3, 2, 15,
etc.</F>
<F>2) vi. 3, 1, 30 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>119<pc>1-031<k1>ayas<k2>ayas
{@Ayas.@}¦ — The exact metal denoted by this word when used by
itself, as always in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is uncertain. As favouring the
sense of ‘bronze’ rather than that of ‘iron’ may perhaps be
cited with Zimmer<sup>2</sup> the fact that Agni is called {%ayo-daṃṣṭra,%}
‘with teeth of Ayas,’<sup>3</sup> with reference to the colour of his flames,
and that the car-seat of Mitra and Varuṇa is called {%ayaḥ-sthūṇa,%}<sup>4</sup>
‘with pillars of Ayas’ at the setting of the sun.<sup>5</sup> Moreover,
in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>6</sup> Ayas is enumerated in a list of six
metals: gold ({%hiraṇya%}), Ayas, Śyāma, Loha, lead ({%sīsa%}), tin
({%trapu%}). Here {%śyāma%} (‘swarthy’) and {%loha%} (‘red’) must mean
‘iron’ and ‘copper’ respectively; {%ayas%} would therefore seem to
mean ‘bronze.’ In many passages in the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> and
[Page1-032+ 48]
other books, the Ayas is divided into two species — the {%śyāma%}
(‘iron’) and the {%lohita%} (‘copper’ or ‘bronze’). In the Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> a distinction is drawn between Ayas and {%lohāyasa,%}
which may either be a distinction between iron and copper as
understood by Eggeling,<sup>9</sup> or between copper and bronze as held
by Schrader.<sup>10</sup> In one passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>11</sup> the sense of
iron seems certain. Possibly, too, the arrow of the Rigveda,<sup>12</sup>
which had a tip of Ayas ({%yasyā ayo mukham%}), was pointed
with iron. Copper, however, is conceivable, and bronze quite
likely.
<div n="P"/>Iron is called {%śyāma ayas%} or {%śyāma%} alone.<sup>13</sup> See also
{@Kārṣṇāyasa.@} Copper is {@Lohāyasa@} or {@Lohitāyasa.@}
<div n="P"/>The smelting ({%dhmā%} ‘to blow’) of the metal is frequently
referred to. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>14</sup> states that if ‘well
smelted’ ({%bahu-dhmātam%}) it is like gold, referring evidently to
bronze. A heater of Ayas is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi
Saṃhitā,<sup>15</sup> and bowls of Ayas are also spoken of.<sup>16</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 57, 3; 163, 9; iv. 2, 17;
vi. 3, 5.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 52.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 88, 5; x. 87, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. v. 62, 8 ({%cf.%} 7).</F>
<F>5) But this is not convincing, as in
the same verse it is said to be ‘of
golden appearance at the flush of
dawn.’</F>
<F>6) xviii. 13.</F>
<F>7) xi. 3, 1. 7; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
iv. 2, 9.</F>
<F>8) v. 4, 1, 2.</F>
<F>9) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 41, 90</F>
<F>10) {%Prehistoric Antiquities,%} 189.</F>
<F>11) v. 28, 1.</F>
<F>12) vi. 75, 15.</F>
<F>13) Av. ix. 5, 4.</F>
<F>14) vi. 1, 3, 5. {%Cf.%} vi. 1, 1, 13; v. 1, 2,
14; xii. 7, 1, 7; 2, 10, etc.</F>
<F>15) xxx. 14; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4,
10, 1.</F>
<F>16) Av. viii. 10, 22; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃ-
hitā, iv. 2, 13.</F>
<LEND>

<L>122<pc>1-033<k1>ayogU<k2>ayogU
{@Ayogū@}¦ is a word of quite doubtful meaning, found in the list
of victims in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>1</sup> It may, like the late
{%āyogava,%} denote a member of a mixed caste (theoretically a
descendant of a Śūdra by a Vaiśya wife).<sup>2</sup> Weber<sup>3</sup> rendered it
as ‘unchaste woman.’<sup>4</sup> Zimmer thinks it denotes a brotherless
maiden who is exposed to the dangers of prostitution ({%cf.%}
{%āyogava%}).
<F>1) xxx. 5; Taithrīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4,
1, 1.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Streifen,%} 1, 76, n. b. In the
{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
{%Gesellschaft,%} 18, 277, he thought it re-
ferred to dicing ({%ayas%}). Risley, {%Peoples%}
{%of India,%} 250, regards the Āyogavas
as a functional caste of carpenters
({%cf.%} Manu, x. 48).</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 328.</F>

<L>125<pc>1-033<k1>araRya<k2>araRya
{@Araṇya.@}¦ — This term denotes the uncultivated land — not
necessarily forest land — beyond the village. It is contrasted
with home ({%amā%}),<sup>1</sup> and with the plough land ({%kṛṣi%}),<sup>2</sup> being spoken
of as apart ({%tiras%}) from men.<sup>3</sup> It is also contrasted with the
{@Grāma,@}<sup>4</sup> and it is the place where thieves live.<sup>5</sup> The character
of the forest is described in a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> to the
forest spirit (Araṇyānī). The dead are carried there for burial,<sup>7</sup>
and hermits live there.<sup>8</sup> Forest fires were common.<sup>9</sup>
<F>1) Rv. vi. 24, 10.</F>
<F>2) Av. ii. 4, 5.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 6, 2, 20.</F>
<F>4) Av. xii. 1, 56; Rv. i. 163, 11;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45; xx. 17.</F>
<F>5) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 2, 3, 5;
xiii. 2, 4, 4.</F>
<F>6) x. 146.</F>
<F>7) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, v. 11.</F>
<F>8) Chāndogya Upaniṣad, viii. 5, 3.</F>
<F>9) Rv. i. 65, 4; 94, 10. 11; ii. 14, 2;

<L>126<pc>1-034<k1>aratni<k2>aratni
{@Aratni.@}¦ — This word, which primarily means ‘elbow,’ occurs
frequently from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards as denoting a measure of
length (‘ell’ or ‘cubit’), the distance from the elbow to the tip
of the hand. The exact length nowhere appears from the early
texts.
<F>1) Rv. viii. 80, 8; Av. xix. 57, 6;
Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 5; Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa, vi. 3, 1, 33, etc. For

<L>127<pc>1-034<k1>arAjAnaH<k2>arAjAnaH
{@A-rājānaḥ,@}¦ ‘not princes,’ is a term used to describe persons
in two passages of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> and in the
Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> Weber<sup>3</sup> also finds them mentioned in the
Atharvaveda,<sup>4</sup> and thinks that they — {@Sūtas@} (‘charioteers’) and
{@Grāmaṇīs@} (‘troop-leaders’) there referred to — were called thus
because, while not themselves princes, they assisted in the con-
secration of princes.
<F>1) iii. 4, 1, 7. 8; xiii. 4, 2, 17.</F>
<F>2) viii. 23.</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 199.</F>
<F>4) iii. 5, 7, where he emends {%rājānaḥ%}
to {%a-rājānaḥ%} (see Whitney's note on the
passage). {%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the%}
{%Atharvaveḍa,%} 333; Weber, {%Über den%}
{%Rājasūya,%} 22 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>135<pc>1-035<k1>arunDatI<k2>arunDatI<h>1
1. {@Arundhatī@}¦ is the name of a plant celebrated in several
passages of the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> as possessing healing properties in
case of wounds, as a febrifuge, and as inducing cows to give
milk. The plant was a climber which attached itself to trees
like the {@Plakṣa, Aśvattha, Nyagrodha,@} and {@Parṇa.@}<sup>2</sup> It was
of golden colour ({%hiraṇya-varṇā%}), and had a hairy stem ({%lomaśa-%}
{%vakṣaṇā%}).<sup>3</sup> It was also called Silācī, and the {@Lākṣā@} appears to
have been a product of it.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) iv. 12, 1; v. 5, 5. 9; vi. 59, 1. 2;
viii. 7, 6; xix. 38, 1.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 5, 5.</F>
<F>3) Av. v. 5, 7; Pischel, {%Vedische%}
{%Studien,%} 1, 174; Bloomfield, {%Zeitschrift%}
{%der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell-%}
{%schaft,%} 48, 574.</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} Whitney's note on Av. iv. 12;
Bloomfield, {%Atharvaveda,%} 61.</F>

<L>145<pc>1-037<k1>arya<k2>arya
{@Arya.@}¦ — This word is not common in the older literature, in
places where the quantity of the first vowel is fixed as short, except
in a mere adjectival sense. Geldner,<sup>1</sup> indeed, contends that no
other sense is anywhere needed; but Roth<sup>2</sup> and Zimmer<sup>3</sup> agree
in thinking that in several passages of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup>
the word has the same sense as {@Ārya,@} and this appears probable.
Whether it is necessary to ascribe this sense to the word in the
compound {%arya-patnī%}<sup>5</sup> applied to the waters set free by Indra,
is more doubtful. The commentator, Mahīdhara,<sup>6</sup> suggests
that the word means a {@Vaiśya,@} not an {@Ārya@} generally. This
view is supported by the explanation in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup>
of one of the passages of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>8</sup> But though
the use of Arya to denote a Vaiśya became common later, it is
not clear that it was original.
<F>1) {%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 96.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 214, 215.</F>
<F>4) xiv. 30; xx. 17; xxiii. 21; xxvi. 2.
{%Cf.%} also Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 5;
Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 3. In
Atharvaveda, xix. 32, 8, an analogous
form occurs, as contrasted with {%brāh-%}
{%maṇa, rājanya,%} and {%śūdra;%} but even
there Whitney renders it as ‘Āryan.’
{%Cf.%} xix. 62, 1; Rv. viii. 94, 3; Pischel,
{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
{%Gesellschaft,%} 40, 125.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 6, 5; x. 43, 8.</F>
<F>6) On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii.
30.</F>
<F>7) xiii. 2, 9, 8. Contrast Śāṅkhāyana
Srauta Sūtra, xvi. 4, 4 {%et seq.,%} where
Arya appears to be taken in the wider
sense.</F>
<F>8) xxiii. 30. {%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation
of the Rigveda, 3, 212; Weber, {%Indische%}
{%Studien,%} x. 6; Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-%}
{%Noten,%} 1, 126, 363.</F>
<LEND>

<L>162<pc>1-039<k1>avata<k2>avata
{@Avata,@}¦ a word occurring several times in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> denotes
a well, artificially made ({%khan%} ‘to dig’) in contrast with a spring
[Page1-040+ 51]
({%utsa%}), though the latter expression is also applied to an artificial
well. Such wells were covered by the makers,<sup>2</sup> and are described
as unfailing ({%a-kṣita%}) and full of water.<sup>3</sup> The water was raised
by a wheel ({%cakra%}) of stone, to which was fastened a strap
({%varatrā%}), with a pail ({%kośa%})<sup>4</sup> attached to it. When raised it was
poured ({%siñc%}) into buckets ({%āhāva%}) of wood.<sup>5</sup> Sometimes those
wells appear to have been used for irrigation purposes, the water
being led off into broad channels ({%sārmī suṣirā%}).<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) i. 55, 8; 85, 10. 11; 116, 9, 22;
130, 2; iv. 17, 16; 50, 3; viii. 49, 6;
62, 6; 72, 10, 12; x. 25, 4; 101,
5. 7. {%Cf.%} Nirukta, v. 26.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 55, 8.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 101, 6, etc.</F>
<F>4) {%Aṃsatra-kośam,%} Rv. x. 101, 7, is best
thus rendered. For the stone wheel
({%aśma-cakra%}) which was above ({%uccā-%}
{%cakra%}), see Rv. x. 101, 7; viii. 72, 10. For
the {%varatrā,%} see Rv. x. 101, 6. Perhaps
{%kū-cakra%} in Rv. x. 102, 11, is another
name for the wheel, but {%cf.%} St. Peters-
burg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 101, 6. 7.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii. 69, 12. {%Cf.%} Zimmer,
{%Altindisches Leben,%} 156, 157; Geldner,
{%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 14.</F>
<LEND>

<L>163<pc>1-040<k1>avatsAra<k2>avatsAra
{@Avatsāra@}¦ is mentioned as a seer in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> as a priest
in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> and as Prāsravaṇa (or Prāśravaṇa),

<L>168<pc>1-040<k1>avi<k2>avi
{@Avi.@}¦ — ‘Sheep’ are repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda, and
later, often in conjunction with goats ({%aja%}). The wolf ({%vṛka%})
was their great enemy,<sup>1</sup> and they were tended by shepherds.<sup>2</sup>
[Page1-041+ 52]
Sheep as well as kine were captured from the enemy.<sup>3</sup> The
Soma sieve was made of sheep's wool, and is repeatedly
referred to ({%avi, meṣī, avya, avyaya%}).<sup>4</sup> Considerable herds
must have existed, as Ṛjrāśva is said<sup>5</sup> to have slain one
hundred rams, and in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’)<sup>6</sup> a hundred
sheep are mentioned as a gift. The ({%meṣa,%}<sup>7</sup> {%vṛṣṇi%}<sup>8</sup> ) ram was
sometimes castrated ({%petva%}).<sup>9</sup> The main use of sheep was their
wool; hence the expression ‘woolly’ ({%ūrṇāvatī%})<sup>10</sup> is employed to
designate a sheep. In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>11</sup> the ram is
described as ‘woolly,’ and as ‘the skin of beasts, quadruped and
biped,’ with reference to the use of its wool as clothing for men
and shelter for animals. Pūṣan is said<sup>12</sup> to weave raiment from
the wool of sheep. Normally the sheep stayed out at pasture;
in an obscure passage of the Rigveda<sup>13</sup> reference appears to be
made to rams in stall. Gandhāra<sup>14</sup> ewes were famous for their
wool. Pischel<sup>15</sup> considers that the {@Paruṣṇī@}<sup>16</sup> was named from
its richness in sheep, {%parus%}<sup>17</sup> denoting the ‘flocks’ of wool.
<F>1) Av. v. 8, 4; Rv. viii. 34, 3; 66, 8.</F>
<F>2) {%Avi-pāla,%} Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx.
11; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iv. 1, 5, 2;
{%avi-pa,%} Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 9, 1.</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 86, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. ix. 109, 16; 36, 4, etc. See
Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1,
203.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 116, 17.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii. 67, 3.</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 43, 6; 116, 16, etc.</F>
<F>8) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 7, 4, etc.</F>
<F>9) Rv. vii. 18, 17; Av. iv. 4, 8;
Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 22, 1; Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 58; 59.</F>
<F>10) Rv. viii. 67, 3. {%Cf.%} x. 75, 8; so
{%urā,%} x. 95, 3.</F>
<F>11) xiii. 50.</F>
<F>12) Rv. x. 26, 6.</F>
<F>13) x. 106, 5.</F>
<F>14) Rv. i. 126, 7.</F>
<F>15) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 210.</F>
<F>16) Rv. iv. 22, 2; v. 52, 9.</F>
<F>17) Rv. ix. 15, 6; {%parvan,%} iv. 22, 2.
{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 229,
230; Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 348.</F>

<L>169<pc>1-041<k1>aSani<k2>aSani
{@Aśani.@}¦ — Zimmer<sup>1</sup> cites this word from the Rigveda<sup>2</sup> as
denoting a sling stone, and compares a similar use of {@Adri.@}<sup>3</sup>
In either case, however, the weapons are mythical, being used
in descriptions of Indra's deeds. Schrader<sup>4</sup> also cites {%aśan%} in this
sense, but no Vedic passage requires this sense.

<L>171<pc>1-042<k1>aSva<k2>aSva
{@Aśva@}¦ is the commonest word for ‘horse’ in the Vedic
literature. The horse is also called ‘the runner’ ({%atya%}), ‘the
swift’ ({%arvant%}), ‘the strong,’ for pulling ({%vājin%}), ‘the runner’
({%sapti%}), and ‘the speeding’ ({%haya%}). The mare is termed {%aśvā,%}
{%atyā, arvatī, vaḍavā,%} etc. Horses of various colour were known,
dun ({%harita, hari%}), ruddy ({%aruṇa, aruṣa, piśaṅga, rohita%}), dark
brown ({%śyāva%}), white ({%śveta%}), etc. A white horse with black
ears is mentioned in the Atharvaveda as of special value.<sup>1</sup>
Horses were highly prized,<sup>2</sup> and were not rare, as Roth<sup>3</sup>
thought, for as many as four hundred mares are mentioned in
one Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’).<sup>4</sup> They were on occasion
ornamented with pearls and gold.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="P"/>Mares were preferred for drawing chariots because of their
swiftness and sureness.<sup>6</sup> They were also used for drawing
carts, but were not ordinarily so employed.<sup>7</sup> No mention is
made of riding in battle, but for other purposes it was not
unknown.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>Horses were often kept in stalls,<sup>9</sup> and fed there.<sup>10</sup> But they
were also allowed to go out to grass,<sup>11</sup> and were then hobbled.<sup>12</sup>
They were watered to cool them after racing.<sup>13</sup> Their attendants
[Page1-043+ 59]
are frequently referred to ({%aśva-pāla,%}<sup>14</sup> {%aśva-pa,%}<sup>15</sup> {%aśva-pati%}).<sup>16</sup>
Stallions were frequently castrated ({%vadhri%}).<sup>17</sup>
<div n="P"/>Besides reins ({%raśmayaḥ%}), reference is made to halters
({%aśvābhidhānī%}),<sup>18</sup> and whips ({%aśvājani%}).<sup>19</sup> See also {@Ratha.@}
<div n="P"/>Horses from the Indus were of special value,<sup>20</sup> as also horses
from the {@Sarasvatī.@}
<F>1) Av. v. 17, 15.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 83, 1; iv. 32, 17; v. 4, 11;
viii. 78, 2, etc.</F>
<F>3) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 35, 686.</F>
<F>4) Rv. viii. 55, 3. {%Cf.%} v. 33, 8; vi. 47,
22-24; 63, 10; viii. 6, 47; 46, 22, and
Hopkins, {%American Journal of Philology,%}
15, 157.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 68, 11.</F>
<F>6) Pischel, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}

<F>7) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 5, 4, 35.</F>
<F>8) The Aśvins ride, Rv. v. 61, 1-3.

<L>172<pc>1-043<k1>aSvatara<k2>aSvatara
{@Aśva-tara, Aśva-tarī@}¦ are respectively the masculine and
feminine name of ‘mule.’ These animals are mentioned
frequently from the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> onwards. They were known
not to be fruitful,<sup>2</sup> and were probably considered inferior to
horses,<sup>3</sup> but a mule-car was quite common.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) iv. 4, 8; viii. 8, 22; Aitareya
Brāhmaṇa, iii. 47; iv. 9; Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa, xii. 4, 1, 10, etc.; Jaiminīya
Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 4.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 2. 3.
{%Cf.%} Adbhuta Brāhmaṇa in {%Indische%}
{%Studien,%} 1, 40.</F>
<F>3) As were asses, Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
v. 1, 2, 2; Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, vi. 4,
4, 7.</F>
<F>4) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iv. 9; Chān-
dogya Upaniṣad, iv. 2, 1 (in both pas-
sages {%aśvatarī-ratha%}). {%Cf.%} Oertel, {%Trans-%}
{%actions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts%}
{%and Sciences,%} 15, 175.</F>
<LEND>

<L>173<pc>1-043<k1>aSvatTa<k2>aSvatTa<h>1
1. {@Aśva-ttha@}¦ (‘horse-stand’) is one of India's greatest trees,
the {%Ficus religiosa,%} later called {%pippala%}<sup>1</sup> (now Peepal). Vessels
made of the wood of the Aśvattha are mentioned in the Rigveda,<sup>2</sup>
and the tree itself is constantly referred to later.<sup>3</sup> Its hard
wood formed the upper of the two pieces of wood used for
kindling fire, the lower being of {@Śamī.@}<sup>4</sup> It planted its roots in
shoots of other trees, especially the {@Khadira,@} and destroyed
them;<sup>5</sup> hence it is called ‘the destroyer’ ({%vaibādha%}). Its berries
[Page1-044+ 37]
are referred to as sweet, and as eaten by birds.<sup>6</sup> The gods are
said to sit under it in the third heaven.<sup>7</sup> It and {@Nyagrodha@}
are styled the ‘crested ones’ ({%śikhaṇḍin%}).<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) The word {%pippala%} as a neuter occurs
once in the Rv. (i. 164, 20) designating
the berry of the Peepal-tree.</F>
<F>2) i. 135, 8; x. 97, 5.</F>
<F>3) Atharvaveda, iii. 6, 1; iv. 37, 4, etc.</F>
<F>4) Av. vi. 11, 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
xi. 5, 1, 13.</F>
<F>5) Av. iii. 6.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 164, 20. 22.</F>
<F>7) Av. v. 4, 3. {%Cf.%} Chāndogya Upani-
ṣad, viii. 5, 3; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, i. 3.</F>
<F>8) Av. iv. 37, 4. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
{%disches Leben,%} 57, 58.</F>
<LEND>

<L>174<pc>1-044<k1>aSvatTa<k2>aSvatTa<h>2
2. {@Aśva-ttha.@}¦ — This prince is celebrated in a Dānastuti<sup>1</sup> as
having given gifts to Pāyu. He is identified with {@Divodāsa@}
by Griffith,<sup>2</sup> but it is impossible to be certain of this identifica-

<L>189<pc>1-045<k1>azwakarRI<k2>azwakarRI
{@Aṣṭa-karṇī@}¦ is an expression which occurs in one passage of
the Ṛigveda,<sup>1</sup> and which Roth<sup>2</sup> was at first inclined to interpret
[Page1-046+ 46]
as a proper name. There can, however, be no doubt that
it means a cow, not a man, as suggested by Grassmann. The
exact reason why a cow should be so described is uncertain.
Roth<sup>3</sup> was later inclined to see in it the sense ‘having pierced
ears,’ similar epithets being at a later period known to Pāṇini<sup>4</sup>
({%bhinna-karṇa, chinna-karṇa%}). Grassmann's more obvious
rendering, ‘having the sign for (the number) 8 marked on the ear,’
is supported by the similar epithets, ‘having the mark of a lute on
the ear’ ({%karkari-karṇyaḥ%}), ‘having the mark of a sickle on the ear’
({%dātra-karṇyaḥ%}), ‘having the mark of a stake on the ear’ ({%sthūṇā-%}
{%karṇyaḥ%}), ‘having the ears bored’ ({%chidra-karṇyaḥ%}), and {%viṣtya-%}
{%karṇyaḥ,%} given in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<sup>5</sup> The simple mean-
ing, ‘with marked ears,’ is, however, supported by the same
passage of the Maitrāyaṇī, where the verb {%akṣ%} occurs in the
sense ‘to mark.’ In the Atharvaveda the mark used is the
Mithuna, no doubt as a magical device to secure fertility.
<div n="P"/>The marking of ears was apparently a regular practice. It is
twice referred to in the Atharvaveda.<sup>6</sup> The mark is termed
{%lakṣman,%}<sup>7</sup> and was made with a copper-knife<sup>8</sup> ({%lohita%}). The
Maitrayaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>9</sup> forbids the use of an arrow-shaft ({%tejana%}),
or of iron, but permits that of a stem of sugar-cane ({%ikṣu-kāṇḍa%})
or copper.
<F>1) x. 62, 7.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Böhtlingk, Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) vi. 3, 115.</F>
<F>5) iv. 2, 9.</F>
<F>6) vi. 141, 1. 2; xii. 4, 6.</F>
<F>7) Av. vi. 141, 2; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
{%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>8) Av., {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>9) {%Loc. cit.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 234,
348; Delbrück, {%Gurupūjākaumudī,%} 48,
49; Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 13, 466;
Whitney, Translation of the Atharva-
veda, 387.</F>
<LEND>

<L>191<pc>1-046<k1>azwrA<k2>azwrA
{@Aṣṭrā@}¦ is the plougher's ‘goad,’ the badge of agriculture.
It is mentioned several times in the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup>
<F>1) iv. 57, 4; vi. 53, 9; 58, 2; {%aṣṭrā-vin%}
occurs in x. 102, 8. See also Kauśika
Sūtra, 80. {%Cf.%} Roscher, {%Archiv für%}
{%Religionswissenschaft,%} 1, 63; Hille-
brandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 3, 364, n. 8.</F>

<L>192<pc>1-046<k1>asamAtirATaprOzWa<k2>asamAtirATaprOzWa
{@Asamāti Rātha-prauṣṭha.@}¦ — The story of the quarrel between
Asamāti, the Ikṣvāku prince of the Rathaproṣṭha family, and
[Page1-047+ 52]
his priests, the Gaupāyanas, is found only in the later
Brāhmaṇas.<sup>1</sup> It appears to be based on a misreading of the
Rigveda,<sup>2</sup> where {%asamāti%} is merely an adjective. The later
story is that the king was induced to abandon his family priests
by two Asuras, Kirāta and Ākuli, who by their magic com-
passed the death of Subandhu, one of the brother priests, and
that the others revived him by the use of the hymns (Rigveda,
x. 57-60).
<F>1) Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 167
({%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
18, 41 {%et seq.%}); Sāṭyāyanaka, cited in
Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 57, 1; 60, 7; Bṛhad-
devatā, vii. 83 {%et seq.,%} with Macdonell's
notes; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xiii.
12, 5.</F>
<F>2) x. 60, 2. 5; Av. vi. 79, 1. {%Cf.%} Bloom-
field, {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 499;
Max Müller, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
{%Society,%} 1866, 426-465; Böhtlingk's
Dictionary, {%s.v.;%} Hopkins, {%Transactions%}
{%of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}
{%Sciences,%} 15, 48, n. 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>200<pc>1-048<k1>ahan<k2>ahan
{@Ahan,@}¦ ‘day.’ Like other peoples, the Indians used night
as a general expression of time as well as day, but by no means
predominantly.<sup>1</sup> Night is also termed the dark ({%kṛṣṇa%}), as
[Page1-049+ 56]
opposed to the light ({%arjuna%}), day.<sup>2</sup> Aho-rātra<sup>3</sup> is a regular
term for ‘day and night’ combined.
<div n="P"/>The day itself is variously divided. In the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup>
a division into ‘the rising sun’ ({%udyan sūryaḥ%}), ‘the coming
together of the cows’ ({%saṃ-gava%}), ‘midday’ ({%madhyaṃ-dina%}),
‘afternoon’ ({%aparāhṇa%}), and ‘sunset’ ({%astaṃ-yan%}) is found.
In the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> the same series appears with
‘early’ ({%prātar%}) and ‘evening’ ({%sāyāhna%}) substituted for the
first and last members, while a shorter list gives {%prātar,%}
{%saṃgava, sāyam.%} In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>6</sup> there is the
series ‘dawn’ {%(uṣas), saṃgava, madhyaṃdina,%} and {%aparāhṇa.%}
<div n="P"/>The morning is also, according to Zimmer, called {%api-śarvara,%}<sup>7</sup>
as the time when the dark is just past. It is named {%svasara,%}<sup>8</sup>
as the time when the cows are feeding, before the first milking
at the {%saṃgava,%} or when the birds are awakening.<sup>9</sup> It is also
called {%pra-pitva,%}<sup>10</sup> according to Zimmer.<sup>11</sup> But Geldner<sup>12</sup> points
out that that term refers to the late midday, which also is
called {%api-śarvara,%} as bordering on the coming night, being the
time when day is hastening to its close, as in a race. From
another point of view, evening is called {%abhi-pitva,%}<sup>13</sup> the time
when all come to rest. Or again, morning and evening are
denoted as the dawning of the sun ({%uditā sūryasya%}), or its
setting ({%ni-mruc%}). The midday is regularly {%madhyam ahnām,%}<sup>14</sup>
{%madhye,%}<sup>15</sup> or {%madhyaṃdina. Saṃgava%}<sup>16</sup> is the forenoon, between
the early morning ({%prātar%}) and midday ({%madhyaṃdina%}).
<div n="P"/>The divisions of time less than the day are seldom precisely
given. In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>17</sup> however, a day and
[Page1-050+ 48]
night make up 30 {%muhūrtas;%} 1 {%muhūrta%} = 15 {%kṣipra;%} 1 {%kṣipra%} =
15 {%etarhi;%} 1 {%etarhi%} = 15 {%idāni;%} 1 {%idāni%} = 15 breathings; 1 breath-
ing = 1 spiration; 1 spiration = 1 twinkling ({%nimeṣa%}), etc. In
the Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka<sup>18</sup> the series is {%dhvaṃsayo, nimeṣāḥ,%}
{%kāṣṭhāḥ, kalāḥ, kṣanā, muhūrtā, ahorātrāḥ.%} A thirtyfold division
of day as well as of night is seen in one passage of the
Rigveda<sup>19</sup> by Zimmer, who compares the Babylonian sixty-
fold division of the day and night. But the expression used — 
thirty Yojanas — is too vague and obscure — Bergaigne<sup>20</sup> refers
it to the firmament — to build any theory upon with safety.
<div n="P"/>The longer divisions of time are regularly ‘half month’
({%ardha-māsa%}), ‘month’ ({%māsa%}), ‘season’ ({%ṛtu%}), and ‘year’
({%saṃvatsara%}), which often<sup>21</sup> occur in this sequence after
{%ahorātrāṇi%} (‘days and nights’).
<F>1) Rv. iv. 16, 19; viii. 26, 3; i. 70, 4. {%Cf.%} Av. x. 7, 42.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 9. 1.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 190, 2; Av. xiii. 3, 8, etc.;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 41, etc.</F>
<F>4) ix. 6, 45.</F>
<F>5) i. 5, 3, 1; 4, 9, 2.</F>
<F>6) iv. 2, 11.</F>
<F>7) Rv. iii. 9, 7; {%cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-%}
{%Noten,%} 1, 230.</F>
<F>8) Rv. ii. 34, 8; ix. 94, 2.</F>
<F>9) Rv. ii. 19, 2; 34, 5.</F>
<F>10) Rv. vii. 41, 4; viii. 1, 29. Sieg.
{%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 127 {%et seq.,%}
interprets {%paritakmyāyām%} (Rv. i. 116, 15)
similarly.</F>
<F>11) {%Altindisches Leben.%} 362.</F>
<F>12) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 155-179.</F>
<F>13) Rv. i. 126, 3; iv. 34, 5.</F>
<F>14) Rv. vii. 41, 4.</F>
<F>15) Rv. viii. 27, 20.</F>
<F>16) {%Cf.%} Rv. v. 76, 3 ({%saṃgave, prātar%}
{%ahno, madhyaṃdine%}); Taittirīya Brāh-
maṇa, ii. 1, 1, 3; Jaiminīya Upaniṣad
Brāhmaṇa, i. 12, 4; Aitareya Brāh-
maṇa, iii. 18, 14; Geldner, {%Vedische%}
{%Studien,%} 3, 112, 113. Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%}
362, places it too early — before the
cows are driven out.</F>
<F>17) xii. 3, 2, 5. {%Cf.%} Taittirīya Brāh-
maṇa, iii. 10, 1, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>18) vii. 20. {%Cf.%} Śāṅkhāyana Srauta
Sūtra, xiv. 78 {%et seq.;%} Weber, {%Indische%}
{%Streifen,%} 1, 92-95.</F>
<F>19) Rv. i. 123, 8.</F>
<F>20) {%Religion Védique.%} 3, 283 {%et seq.%}
{%Cf.%} Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
{%s.v. kratu.%}</F>
<F>21) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 15;
Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 7; Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28; Śāṅkhāyana
Āraṇyaka, vii. 20; Bṛhadāraṇyaka
Upaniṣad. iii. 8, 9, etc. {%Cf.%} Zimmer,
{%Altindisches Leben,%} 361-363.</F>
<LEND>

<L>202<pc>1-050<k1>ahi<k2>ahi
{@Ahi.@}¦ — This word occurs frequently from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
onwards to denote ‘snake.’ Reference is several times<sup>2</sup> made
to its casting its slough. Mention is also made of the serpent's
peculiar movement,<sup>3</sup> which earns for it the designation<sup>4</sup> of
‘the toothed rope’ ({%datvatī rajjuḥ%}). The poisonous character
[Page1-051+ 39]
of its bite is spoken of,<sup>5</sup> as well as the torpidity of the reptile
in winter, when it creeps into the earth.<sup>6</sup> The cast skin is
used as an amulet against highwaymen.<sup>7</sup> Mention is made of
a mythical horse, Paidva, which the Aśvins gave to Pedu as
a protection against snakes,<sup>8</sup> and which is invoked as a
destroyer of serpents.<sup>9</sup> The ichneumon ({%nakula%}) is regarded
as their deadly enemy, and as immune against their poison
through the use of a healing plant,<sup>10</sup> while men kill them with
sticks<sup>11</sup> or strike off their heads.<sup>12</sup>
<div n="P"/>Many species of snakes are mentioned: see {@Aghāśva,@}
{@Ajagara, Asita, Kaṅkaparvan, Karikrata, Kalmāṣagrīva,@}
{@Kasarṇīla, Kumbhīnasa, Tiraścarāji, Taimāta, Darvi, Daśo-@}
{@nasi, Puṣkarasāda, Pṛdāku, Lohitāhi, Śarkoṭa, Śvitra, Sarpa.@}
<F>1) vii. 104, 7, etc. The word {%sarpa,%}
which is usual in the Atharvaveda,
occurs only once (x. 16, 6) in the Rv.</F>
<F>2) Rv. ix. 86, 44; Av. i. 27; Satapatha
Brāhmaṇa, xi. 2, 6, 13; Bṛhadāraṇyaka
Upaniṣad, iv. 4, 10; Jaiminīya Brāh-
maṇa, i. 9. ii. 139; Kāṭhaka Upaniṣad,
ii. 6; 17.</F>
<F>3) Aitareya Āraṇyaka, v. 1, 4.</F>
<F>4) Av. iv. 3, 2.</F>

6, 56.</F>
<F>6) Av. xii. 1, 46.</F>

<L>208<pc>1-052<k1>AKyAna<k2>AKyAna
{@Ā-khyāna.@}¦ — In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> we hear of the

series of stories<sup>2</sup> used at the Aśvamedha (‘horse sacrifice’)

at its will is called the ‘cyclic’ ({%pari-plavam%}). The Aitareya
Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> mentions also Ākhyāna-vids (‘men versed in
tales’), who tell the Sauparṇa legend, elsewhere<sup>4</sup> known as a
{@Vyākhyāna.@} Yāska, in the Nirukta,<sup>5</sup> frequently uses the term,
sometimes in a pregnant sense as denoting the doctrine of the
Aitihāsikas or traditional interpreters of the Rigveda.<sup>6</sup>

<L>214<pc>1-053<k1>ANgirasa<k2>ANgirasa

{@Aṅgiras,@} borne by many sages and teachers, like {@Kṛṣṇa,@}
{@Ājīgarti, Cyavana, Ayāsya, Saṃvarta, Sudhanvan,@} etc.

<L>218<pc>1-053<k1>Aji<k2>Aji
{@Āji@}¦ is constantly used in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the later
literature to express the sense of ‘a race,’ and only seldom
denotes ‘a battle.’ {@Horse@}-racing was one of the favourite
amusements of the {@Vedic@} Indian,<sup>2</sup> the other being dicing
[Page1-054+ 65]
({@Akṣa@}). The racecourse, called Kāṣṭhā<sup>3</sup> or Āji<sup>4</sup> itself, appears
from the Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> to have been a quasi-circular one to
a mark ({%kārṣman%}<sup>6</sup> ) and back again. In the Rigveda the
course is described as broad ({%urvī%}) and the distance as
measured out ({%apāvṛktā aratnayaḥ%}).<sup>7</sup> Prizes ({%dhana%}) were
offered ({%dhā%}),<sup>8</sup> and eagerly competed for. Other words for
victory and the prize are {%kāra%}<sup>9</sup> and {%bhara;%}<sup>10</sup> and to ‘run a
race’ is described by the expressions {%ājim aj, i, dhāv, sṛ.%}<sup>11</sup>
The person who instituted a race is referred to as {%āji-sṛt,%}<sup>12</sup> and
Indra is called {%āji-kṛt%}<sup>13</sup> (‘race-maker’), and {%āji-pati%}<sup>14</sup> (‘lord
of the race’).
<div n="P"/>The swift steeds ({%vājin, atya%}) used for the races were often
washed and adorned.<sup>15</sup> According to Pischel<sup>16</sup> the name of
one swift mare is preserved — viz., Viśpalā,<sup>17</sup> whose broken leg
was replaced by the Aśvins in a race; but the interpretation
is very doubtful. Geldner<sup>18</sup> has also found a comic picture of
a horse-chariot race in the Mudgala hymn in the Rigveda,
but Bloomfield<sup>19</sup> has shown that that interpretation is un-
sound. Pischel<sup>20</sup> also seeks to show that races were run in
honour of gods, but the evidence for the theory is inadequate.<sup>21</sup>
[Page1-055+ 46]
A formal race, however, is a feature of the ritual of the Rājasūya
or royal consecration.<sup>22</sup>
<F>1) v. 37, 7; vi. 24, 6, etc.</F>
<F>2) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 291;
Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 120; 2.
1 {%seq.%}</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 80, 8; Av. ii. 14, 6.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iv. 24, 8; Av. xiii. 2, 4.</F>
<F>5) ii. 14, 6; xiii. 2, 4.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ix. 36, 1; 74, 8.</F>
