<L>430<pc>1-112<k1>ftvij<k2>ftvij
{@Ṛtv-ij@}¦ is the regular term for ‘sacrificial priest,’ covering all
the different kinds of priests employed at the sacrifice. It
appears certain that all the priests were Brāhmaṇas.<sup>1</sup> The
number of priests officiating at a sacrifice with different functions
was almost certainly seven. The oldest list, occurring in one
passage of the Rigveda,<sup>2</sup> enumerates their names as Hotṛ, Potṛ,
Neṣṭṛ, Agnīdh, Praśāstṛ, Adhvaryu, Brahman, besides the
institutor of the sacrifice. The number of seven probably
explains the phrase ‘seven Hotṛs’ occurring so frequently in
the Rigveda, and is most likely connected with that of the
mythical ‘seven Ṛṣis.’ It may be compared with the eight of
Iran.<sup>3</sup> The chief of the seven priests was the Hotṛ, who was
the singer of the hymns, and in the early times their composer
also. The Adhvaryu performed the practical work of the
sacrifice, and accompanied his performance with muttered
formulas of prayer and deprecation of evil. His chief assist-
ance was derived from the Agnīdh, the two performing the
smaller sacrifices without other help in practical matters. The
Praśāstṛ, Upavaktṛ, or Maitrāvaruṇa, as he was variously
called, appeared only in the greater sacrifices as giving in-
structions to the Hotṛ, and as entrusted with certain litanies.
The Potṛ, Neṣṭṛ, and Brahman belonged to the ritual of the
Soma sacrifice, the latter being later styled Brāhmaṇāc-
chaṃsin to distinguish him from the priest who in the later
[Page1-113+ 60]
ritual acted as supervisor. Other priests referred to in the
Rigveda<sup>4</sup> are the singers of Sāmans or chants, the Udgātṛ
and his assistant the Prastotṛ, while the Pratihartṛ, another
assistant, though not mentioned, may quite well have been
known. Their functions undoubtedly represent a later stage
of the ritual, the development of the elaborate series of
sacrificial calls on the one hand, and on the other the use
of long hymns addressed to the Soma plant. Other priests,
such as the Achāvāka,<sup>5</sup> the Grāvastut, the Unnetṛ, and the
Subrahmaṇya, were known later in the developed ritual of the
Brāhmaṇas, making in all sixteen priests, who were technically
and artificially classed in four groups<sup>6</sup> Hotṛ, Maitrāvaruṇa,
Achāvāka, and Grāvastut; Udgātṛ, Prastotṛ, Pratihartṛ, and
Subrahmaṇya; Adhvaryu, Pratisthātṛ, Neṣṭṛ, and Unnetṛ;
Brahman, Brāhmaṇācchaṃsin, Agnīdhra, and Petṛ.
<div n="P"/>Apart from all these priests was the {@Purohita,@} who was
the spiritual adviser of the king in all his religious duties.
Geldner<sup>7</sup> holds that, as a rule, when the Purohita actually
took part in one of the great sacrifices he played the part of
the Brahman, in the sense of the priest who superintended the
whole conduct of the ritual. He sees evidence for this view in
a considerable number of passages of the Rigveda<sup>8</sup> and the
later literature,<sup>9</sup> where Purohita and Brahman were combined
or identified. Oldenberg,<sup>10</sup> however, more correctly points out
[Page1-114+ 49]
that in the earlier period this was not the case: the Purohita
was then normally the Hotṛ, the singer of the most important
of the songs; it was only later that the Brahman, who in the
capacity of overseer of the rite is not known to the Rigveda,
acquired the function of general supervision hitherto exercised
by the Purohita, who was {%ex officio%} skilled in the use of magic
and in guarding the king by spells which could also be applied
to guarding the sacrifice from evil demons. With this agrees
the fact that Agni, pre-eminently<sup>11</sup> the Purohita of men, is also
a Hotṛ, and that the two divine Hotṛs of the Āprī hymns are
called<sup>12</sup> the divine Purohitas. On the other hand, the rule
is explicitly recognized in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>13</sup> that a
Kṣatriya should have a Brahman as a Purohita; and in
the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>14</sup> the Vasiṣṭha family have a special
claim to the office of Brahman-Purohita, perhaps an indi-
cation that it was they who first as Purohitas exchanged the
function of Hotṛs for that of Brahmans in the sacrificial
ritual.
<div n="P"/>The sacrifices were performed for an individual in the great
majority of cases. The Sattra,<sup>15</sup> or prolonged sacrificial session,
was, however, performed for the common benefit of the priests
taking part in it, though its advantageous results could only be
secured if all the members actually engaged were consecrated
({%dīkṣita%}). Sacrifices for a people as such were unknown. The
sacrifice for the king was, it is true, intended to bring about
the prosperity of his people also; but it is characteristic that
the prayer<sup>16</sup> for welfare includes by name only the priest and
the king, referring to the people indirectly in connexion with
the prosperity of their cattle and agriculture.

<L>431<pc>1-115<k1>fSya<k2>fSya

<L>435<pc>1-115<k1>fzi<k2>fzi
{@Ṛṣi,@}¦ ‘seer,’ is primarily a composer of hymns to the gods.
In the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> reference is often made to previous singers
and to contemporary poets. Old poems were inherited and
refurbished by members of the composer's family,<sup>2</sup> but the
great aim of the singers was to produce new and approved
hymns.<sup>3</sup> It is not till the time of the Brāhmaṇas that the
[Page1-116+ 62]
composition of hymns appears to have fallen into disuse,<sup>4</sup>
though poetry was still produced, for example, in the form of
{@Gāthās,@} which the priests were required to compose them-
selves<sup>5</sup> and sing to the accompaniment of the lute at the
sacrifice. The Ṛṣi was the most exalted of Brāhmaṇas,<sup>6</sup> and
his skill, which is often compared with that of a carpenter,<sup>7</sup>
was regarded as heaven-sent.<sup>8</sup> The Purohita, whether as Hotṛ
or as Brahman (see {@Ṛtvij@}), was a singer.<sup>9</sup> No doubt the Ṛṣis
were normally<sup>10</sup> attached to the houses of the great, the petty
kings of Vedic times, or the nobles of the royal household.
Nor need it be doubted that occasionally<sup>11</sup> the princes them-
selves essayed poetry: a Rājanyarṣi, the prototype of the later
Rājarṣi or ‘royal seer,’ who appears in the Pañcaviṃśa
Brāhmaṇa,<sup>12</sup> though he must be mythical as Oldenberg<sup>13</sup>
points out, indicates that kings cultivated poetry<sup>14</sup> just as later
they engaged in philosophic disputations.<sup>15</sup> Normally, how-
ever, the poetical function is Brahminical, Viśāmitra and others
not being kings, but merely Brāhmaṇas, in the Rigveda.
<div n="P"/>In the later literature the Ṛṣis are the poets of the hymns
preserved in the Saṃhitās. a Ṛṣi being regularly<sup>16</sup> cited when
a Vedic Saṃhitā is quoted. Moreover, the Ṛṣis become the
representatives of a sacred past, and are regarded as holy sages,
[Page1-117+ 56]
whose deeds are narrated as if they were the deeds of gods or
Asuras.<sup>17</sup> They are typified by a particular group of seven,<sup>18</sup>
mentioned four times in the Rigveda,<sup>19</sup> several times in the
later Saṃhitās,<sup>20</sup> and enumerated in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka
Upaniṣad<sup>21</sup> as Gotama, Bharadvāja, Viśvāmitra, Jamadagni,
Vasiṣṭha, Kaśyapa, and Atri. In the Rigveda itself Kutsa,<sup>22</sup>
Atri,<sup>23</sup> Rebha,<sup>24</sup> Agastya,<sup>25</sup> the Kuśikas,<sup>26</sup> Vasiṣṭha,<sup>27</sup> Vyaśva,<sup>28</sup>
and others appear as Ṛṣis; and the Atharvaveda<sup>29</sup> contains a
long list, including Aṅgiras, Agastī, Jamadagni, Atri, Kaśyapa,
Vasiṣṭha, Bharadvāja, Gaviṣṭhira, Viśvāmitra, Kutsa, Kakṣīvant,
Kaṇva, Medhātithi, Triśoka, Uśanā Kāvya, Gotama, and
Mudgala.
<div n="P"/>Competition among the bards appears to have been known.
This is one of the sides of the riddle poetry ({@Brahmodya@}) that
forms a distinctive feature<sup>30</sup> of the Vedic ritual of the Aśva-
medha, or horse sacrifice. In the Upaniṣad period such
competitions were quite frequent. The most famous was that
of Yājñavalkya, which was held at the court of Janaka of
Videha, as detailed in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>31</sup> and
which was a source of annoyance to {@Ajātaśatru@} of {@Kāśī.@}<sup>32</sup>
According to an analogous practice, a Brāhmaṇa, like {@Uddālaka@}
{@Aruṇi,@} would go about disputing with all he came across, and
compete with them for a prize of money.<sup>33</sup>
<F>1) i. 1, 2; 45, 3; viii. 43, 13, etc.</F>
<F>2) i. 89, 3; 96, 2; iii. 39, 2; viii. 6.
11. 43; 76, 6, etc.</F>
<F>3) i. 109, 2; ii. 18, 3; iii. 62, 7;
vi. 50, 6; vii. 14, 4; 93, 1; viii. 23,
14, etc.</F>
<F>4) Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 151.</F>
<F>5) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 4, 2, 8;
3, 5.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ix. 96, 6, etc. {%Cf.%} Satapatha
Brāhmaṇa, xii. 4, 4, 6, where pre-
eminence is assigned to a Brāhmaṇa
descended from a Ṛṣi.</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 130, 6; v. 2, 11; 29, 15; 73,

<L>444<pc>1-119<k1>ekAzwakA<k2>ekAzwakA
{@Ekāṣṭakā.@}¦ — That Aṣṭakā is the eighth day after the full
moon appears clearly from the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> Ekāṣṭakā, or
‘sole Aṣṭakā,’ must denote not merely any Aṣṭakā, but some
particular one. Sāyaṇa, in his commentary on the Atharva-
veda,<sup>2</sup> in which a whole hymn celebrates the Ekāṣṭakā, fixes
the date meant by the term as the eighth day in the dark half
of the month of Māgha (January — February). The Ekāṣṭakā,
is declared in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup> to be the time for the
consecration ({%dīkṣā%}) of those who are going to perform a year
long sacrifice. See also {@Māsa.@}
<F>1) xv. 16, 2. {%Cf.%} Satapatha Brāh-
maṇa, vi. 2, 2, 23; 4, 2, 10.</F>
<F>2) iii. 10.</F>
<F>3) vii. 4, 8 1. {%Cf.%} iii. 3, 8, 4; iv. 3,
11, 1; v. 7, 2, 2; Pañcaviṃśa Brāl
maṇa, v. 9, 4.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 305;
Weber, {%Naxatra,%} 2, 341, 342.</F>

<L>456<pc>1-121<k1>Etareya<k2>Etareya
{@Aitareya,@}¦ perhaps a patronymic from Itara, though the
commentator Sāyaṇa<sup>1</sup> regards the word as a metronymic from
[Page1-122+ 38]

<L>458<pc>1-122<k1>EtihAsika<k2>EtihAsika
{@Aiti-hāsika.@}¦ — This term was applied to the people who
explained the Vedic hymns by treating them as legendary
history ({@Itihāsa@}), as Sieg<sup>1</sup> shows by the passages of the
Nirukta,<sup>2</sup> where their views are opposed to those of the
{@Nairuktas,@} who relied rather on etymology. Sieg<sup>3</sup> also seems
right in finding them in the Naidānas of the Nirukta:<sup>4</sup> it is
possible that their textbook was called the Nidāna.
<F>1) {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 13 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) ii. 16; xii. 1, etc.</F>
<F>3) {%Op. cit.,%} 29.</F>
<F>4) vi. 9; vii. 6.</F>

<L>465<pc>1-123<k1>ogaRa<k2>ogaRa
{@Ogaṇa@}¦ is a word occurring only once, as a plural, in the
Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where it appears to indicate persons hostile to the
seer of the hymn, and apparently opposed to the Āryan religion.
Ludwig<sup>2</sup> regards the terms as the proper name of a people, but
Pischel<sup>3</sup> thinks that it is merely an adjective meaning ‘weak’
({%ogaṇa = ava-gaṇa%}), as in Pāli.

<L>466<pc>1-123<k1>otu<k2>otu
{@Otu@}¦ in Vedic literature<sup>1</sup> denotes the ‘woof’ in weaving and
corresponds to {@Tantu,@} ‘the warp,’ the roots {%vā,%}<sup>2</sup> ‘to weave,’
and {%tan,%}<sup>3</sup> to stretch,’ from which these two terms are derived,
being used in parallel senses. In the process of weaving a
shuttle ({@Tasara@}) was used. The ‘weaver’ is termed {%vāya,%}<sup>4</sup> and
the ‘loom’ {%veman.%}<sup>5</sup> A wooden peg ({@Mayūkha@}) was used to
[Page1-124+ 56]
stretch the web on, while lead was employed as a weight to
extend it.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>The work of weaving was probably the special care of
women.<sup>7</sup> A metaphor in the Atharvaveda<sup>8</sup> personifies Night
and Day as two sisters weaving the web of the year, the
nights serving as warp, the days as woof.
<F>1) Rv. vi. 9, 2. 3; Av. xiv. 2, 51;
Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 9, 2. etc.</F>
<F>3) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 80;
Rv. x. 130, 2; Av. x. 7, 43, etc.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 26, 6, etc.</F>
<F>5) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 83.</F>
<F>6) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 80.</F>
<F>7) Av. x. 7, 42; xiv. 2, 51. {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 92. 3.</F>
<F>8) x. 7, 42; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,
ii. 5, 5, 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 254,
255; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 465.</F>
<LEND>

<L>468<pc>1-124<k1>opaSa<k2>opaSa
{@Opaśa@}¦ is a word of somewhat doubtful sense, occurring in
the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> and occasionally later.<sup>3</sup> It
probably means a ‘plait’ as used in dressing the hair, especially
of women,<sup>4</sup> but apparently, in earlier times,<sup>5</sup> of men also.
The goddess Sinīvālī is called {%svaupaśā,%}<sup>6</sup> an epithet of doubtful
sense, from which Zimmer<sup>7</sup> conjectures that the wearing of
[Page1-125+ 50]
false plaits of hair was not unknown in Vedic times. What
was the difference between the braids referred to in the
epithets {%pṛthu ṣṭuka,%}<sup>8</sup> ‘having broad braids,’ and {%viṣita-ṣṭuka,%}<sup>9</sup>
‘having loosened braids,’ and the Opaśa cannot be made out
from the evidence available. Geldner<sup>10</sup> thinks that the original
sense was ‘horn,’ and that when the word applies to Indra<sup>11</sup>
it means ‘diadem.’
<F>1) x. 85. 8, {%Cf.%} i. 173, 6; viii. 14, 5;
ix. 71. 1.</F>
<F>2) vi. 138, 1. 2; ix. 3, 8, where it is
applied metaphorically in describing
the roof of a house.</F>
<F>3) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, iv. 1, 1.</F>
<F>4) Av. vi. 138. 1, 2.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 173, 6; viii. 14, 5.</F>
<F>6) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 5, 3;
Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 5; Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 56. The reading
is uncertain. Bloomfield (see below)
assumes {%sv-opaśā%} to be the correct form
(‘having a fair {%opaśa%}’).</F>
<F>7) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 264.</F>
<F>8) Rv. x. 86, 8.</F>
<F>9) Rv. i. 167, 5 (of Rodasī).</F>
<F>10) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 131, quoting
Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 4, 3, where
{%dvy-epaśāḥ%} is used of cattle; but the
sense may be figurative.</F>
<F>11) Rv. viii. 14, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
{%vaveda,%} 538, 539; Whitney, Translation
of the Atharvaveda, 348.</F>

<L>469<pc>1-125<k1>ozaDi<k2>ozaDi
{@Oṣadhi.@}¦ — Roughly speaking, the vegetable world is divided
in Vedic literature<sup>1</sup> between Oṣadhi or {@Vīrudh@} ‘plants’ and
{@Vana@} or {@Vṛkṣa@} ‘trees.’ Oṣadhi is employed in opposition to
Vīrudh to denote plants as possessing a healing power or some
other quality useful to men, while Vīrudh is rather a generic
term for minor vegetable growths, but sometimes,<sup>2</sup> when occur-
ring beside Oṣadhi, signifies those plants which do not possess
medicinal properties.
<div n="P"/>A list of the minor parts of which a plant is made up is given
in the later Saṃhitās.<sup>3</sup> It comprises the root ({%mūla%}), the
panicle ({%tūla%}), the stem ({%kāṇḍa%}), the twig ({%valśa%}), the flower
({%puṣpa%}), and the fruit ({%phala%}), while trees<sup>4</sup> have, in addition, a
corona ({%skandha%}), branches ({%śākhā%}), and leaves ({%parṇa%}). The
Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> gives an elaborate, though not very intelligible,
division of plants into those which expand ({%pra-stṛṇatīḥ%}), are
bushy ({%stambinīḥ%}), have only one sheath ({%eka-śuṅgāḥ%}), are
creepers ({%pra-tanvatīḥ%}), have many stalks ({%aṃśumatīḥ%}), are
[Page1-126+ 35]
jointed ({%kāṇḍinīḥ%}), or have spreading branches ({%vi-śākhāḥ%}). In
the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> plants are termed ‘fruitful’ ({%phalinīḥ%}), ‘blossom-
ing’ ({%puṣpavatīḥ%}), and ‘having flowers’ ({%pra-sūvarīḥ%}).
<F>1) Rv. x. 97 and {%passim. Oṣadhi-%}
{%vanaspati%} is a frequent compound, from
the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa (vi. 1, 1, 12)
onwards. The medicinal properties of
plants account for the epithet ‘of
manifold powers’ ({%nānā-vīryā%}) applied
to them in Av. xii. 1, 2.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 3, 2.</F>
<F>3) {%Ibid.,%} vii. 3, 19, 1; Vājasaneyi
Saṃhitā, xxii. 28.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 20, 1.
{%Cf.%} Rv. i. 32, 5; Av. x. 7, 38.</F>
<F>5) viii. 7, 4, with Whitney's notes.
{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Atharva-%}
{%veda,%} 579; Henry, {%Les livres VIII. et%}
{%IX. de l' Atharvavéda,%} 58 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>6) x. 97. 3. 15. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben.%} 57.</F>
<LEND>

<L>486<pc>1-128<k1>OrRavABa<k2>OrRavABa

<L>487<pc>1-129<k1>Orva<k2>Orva
{@Aurva,@}¦ ‘descendant of Uru or Urva,’ appears in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
in close connexion with {@Bhṛgu,@} being probably a Bhṛgu
himself. As in one passage of the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> the
descendants of Aitaśa are called the worst of the Aurvas, while
the parallel version of the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> calls them the
worst of the Bhṛgus, the Aurvas must have been a branch of
the larger family of the Bhṛgus. Aurva himself is said in the
Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup> to have received offspring from Atri. In
the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> two Aurvas are referred to as
authorities. See also {@Kutsa.@}
<F>1) viii. 102, 4.</F>
<F>2) vi. 33.</F>
<F>3) xxx. 5.</F>
<F>4) vii. 1, 8, 1.</F>
<F>5) xxi. 10, 6. Hopkins, {%Transactions%}
{%of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}
{%Sciences,%} 15, 54, reads {%ūrvau.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}
2, 173, n. 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>488<pc>1-129<k1>OlAna<k2>OlAna
{@Aulāna@}¦ is a word occurring in a single passage of the
Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where it may possibly be a patronymic of {@Śaṃtanu@}
as a ‘descendant of Ula.’ Ludwig,<sup>2</sup> however, conjectures that
the reading should be ‘Kaulāna.’ Sieg<sup>3</sup> regards Aulāna as
a later descendant<sup>4</sup> of Śaṃtanu, who utilized the story of
Devāpi's rain-making as an introduction to his rain hymn.
<F>1) x. 98, 11.</F>

of Śaṃtanu, born in the family of the

<L>490<pc>1-130<k1>OSija<k2>OSija
{@Auśija,@}¦ ‘descendant of Uśij,’ is a patronymic clearly applied
to {@Kakṣīvant@} in the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> It is also applied to {@Ṛjiśvan,@}<sup>2</sup>
but Ludwig<sup>3</sup> thinks that the correct reading of the passage in
question is {%auśijasyarjiśvā,%} ‘Ṛjiśvan, son of Auśija.’ In one
verse<sup>4</sup> Auśija and Kakṣīvant are both mentioned, but in such a
way that two different persons must apparently be meant. In
other passages where the patronymic occurs alone, it is doubtful
who is meant, or whether a proper name at all is intended.<sup>5</sup>
Kakṣīvant Auśija appears also in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup>
and elsewhere.

<L>495<pc>1-131<k1>kakuha<k2>kakuha
{@Kakuha,@}¦ a word occurring several times in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is
understood by Roth<sup>2</sup> to designate part of a chariot, perhaps the
seat. Ludwig,<sup>3</sup> again, regards it in one passage<sup>4</sup> as the proper
name of a Yādava prince who took spoil from {@Tirindira,@} the
{@Parśu,@} but this view is hardly probable.<sup>5</sup> It is, on the whole,
most likely that the word always means ‘chief,’ ‘pre-eminent,’
being applied as an epithet to horses, chariots, princes, etc.<sup>6</sup>
This is the only sense given by Grassmann,<sup>7</sup> and later adopted
by Roth.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) i. 46, 3; 181 5; 184, 3; ii. 34, 11;
iii. 54, 14; v. 73, 7; 75, 4; viii. 6, 48.</F>

3, 160, 161; 5, 142.</F>
<F>4) viii. 6, 48.</F>

36, 37.</F>
<F>6) So certainly in Rv. viii. 45, 14;
ix. 67, 8; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 3,
1. 2, and often in the older form
{%kakubha.%}</F>

<L>498<pc>1-131<k1>kakzIvant<k2>kakzIvant
{@Kakṣīvant@}¦ is the name of a Ṛṣi mentioned frequently in the
Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and occasionally elsewhere.<sup>2</sup> He appears to have
been a descendant of a female slave named Uśij.<sup>3</sup> He must
have been a {@Pajra@} by family, as he bears the epithet Pajriya,<sup>4</sup>
[Page1-132+ 55]
and his descendants are called Pajras.<sup>5</sup> In a hymn of the
Rigveda<sup>6</sup> he celebrates the prince {@Svanaya Bhāvya,@} who
dwelt on the {@Sindhu@} (Indus), as having bestowed magnificent
gifts on him; and the list of Nārāśaṃsas (‘Praises of Heroes’)
in the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>7</sup> mentions one by Kakṣīvant
Auśija in honour of Svanaya Bhāvayavya. In his old age he
obtained as a wife the maiden {@Vṛcayā.@}<sup>8</sup> He appears to have
lived to be a hundred,<sup>9</sup> the typical length of life in the Vedas.
He seems always to be thought of as belonging to the past, and
in a hymn of the fourth book of the Rigveda<sup>10</sup> he is mentioned
with the semi-mythical {@Kutsa@} and {@Kavi Uśanas.@} Later, also,
he is a teacher of bygone days.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>In Vedic literature he is not connected with {@Dīrghatamas@}
beyond being once mentioned along with him in a hymn of the
Rigveda.<sup>12</sup> But in the Bṛhaddevatā<sup>13</sup> he appears as a son of
Dīrghatamas by a slave woman, Uśij.
<div n="P"/>Weber<sup>14</sup> considers that Kakṣīvant was originally a Kṣatriya,
not a Brāhmaṇa, quoting in favour of this view the fact that
he is mentioned beside kings like {@Para Āṭṇāra, Vītahavya@}
{@Śrāyasa,@} and {@Trasadasyu Paurukutsya.@}<sup>15</sup> But that these are
all kings is an unnecessary assumption: these persons are
mentioned in the passages in question undoubtedly only as
famous men of old, to whom are ascribed mythical sacrificial
performances, and who thus gained numerous sons.
<F>1) i. 18, 1; 51, 13; 112, 11; 116, 7;
117, 6; 126, 3; iv. 26, 1; viii. 9, 10;
ix. 74, 8; x. 25, 10; 61, 16.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 29, 5, and passage noted
below.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 18, 1; perhaps also i, 112,
11, but Auśija may there be a separate
name (see Auśija). {%Cf.%} Pañcaviṃśa
Brāhmaṇa, xiv. 11, 16.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 116, 7; 117, 6.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 126, 4.</F>
<F>6) i. 126.</F>
<F>7) xvi. 4, 5.</F>
<F>8) Rv. i. 51, 13.</F>
<F>9) Rv. ix. 74, 8.</F>
<F>10) iv. 26, 1.</F>
<F>11) Av. iv. 29, 5; xviii. 3, 15; Aitareya
Brāhmaṇa, i. 21, 6. 7; Jaiminīya
Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 11.</F>
<F>12) viii. 9, 10</F>
<F>13) iv. 11 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>14) {%Episches im vedischen Ritual,%} 22-25.</F>
<F>15) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 6, 5, 3;
Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxii. 3; Pancaviṃśa
Brāhmaṇa, xxv. 16, 3, {%Cf.%} xiv. 11, 16.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 221,
236, n. 1; Ludwig Translation of the
Rigveda, 3, 102; Geldner, {%Rigveda,%}
{%Kommentar,%} 23, 24.</F>
<LEND>

<L>505<pc>1-134<k1>kaRva<k2>kaRva
{@Kaṇva@}¦ is the name of an ancient Ṛṣi repeatedly referred to
in the Rigveda and later.<sup>1</sup> His sons and descendants,<sup>2</sup> the
Kaṇvas, are also often mentioned, especially in the eighth
book of the Rigveda, the authorship of that book, as well as of
part of the first, being attributed to this family. A descendant
of Kaṇva is also denoted by the name in the singular, either
alone<sup>3</sup> or accompanied by a patronymic, as Kaṇva Nārṣada<sup>4</sup>
and Kaṇva Śrāyasa,<sup>5</sup> besides in the plural the Kaṇvas Sauśra-
vasas.<sup>6</sup> The Kaṇva family appears to have been connected with
the Atri family,<sup>7</sup> but not to have been of great importance.<sup>8</sup> In
one passage of the Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> they seem to be definitely
regarded with hostility.
<F>1) Rv. i. 36, 8. 10. 11. 17. 19; 39, 7. 9;
47, 5; 112, 5; 117, 18; 118, 7; 139, 9;
v. 41, 4; viii. 5, 23. 25; 7, 18; 8, 20;
49, 10; 50, 10; x. 71, 11; 115, 5; 150,
5; Av. iv. 37, 1; vii. 15, 1; xviii. 3, 15;

viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, viii. 2, 2; ix. 2, 6;
Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xxviii. 8, Kaṇva-
vat occurs in Rv. viii. 6, 11; 52, 8;
Av. ii. 32, 3; Kaṇva-mant in Rv. viii. 2,
22.</F>
<F>2) As {%Kaṇvāḥ%} (in the plural), Rv. i. 14,
2. 5; 37, 1. 14; 44, 8; 46, 9; 47. 2.
4-10; 49, 4; viii. 2, 16; 3, 16; 4, 2. 3;
5, 4; 6, 3. 18. 21. 31. 34. 47; 7, 32;
8, 3; 9, 14; 32, 1; 33, 3; 34, 4; as
{%Kaṇvasya sūnavaḥ,%} Rv. i, 45, 5; as
{%putrāḥ,%} viii. 8, 4. 8; as {%Kāṇvāyanāḥ,%}

<L>509<pc>1-135<k1>kanA<k2>kanA
{@Kanā, Kanyā.@}¦ — Both these words, of which the former is
very rare,<sup>1</sup> while the latter is the normal term from the Rigveda<sup>2</sup>
onwards, denote ‘maiden’ or ‘young woman.’ It is doubtful
whether Kanīnakā (accented on the final syllable) has this
meaning,<sup>3</sup> or only denotes the pupil of the eye,<sup>4</sup> which is the
sense of {%kanīnakā%} or {%kanīnikā%} (both accented on the ante-
penultimate) in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas. See
also {@Strī.@}

etc.</F>

{%s.v.,%} cites in this sense Rv. iv. 32,
23; x. 40, 9; Nirukta, iv. 15; but
neither of the Rv. passages is at all
clear.</F>

{%vaveda,%} 401; Keith, {%Aitareya Āraṇyāka,%}

{%the East,%} 32, 330.</F>

<L>511<pc>1-135<k1>kaparda<k2>kaparda
{@Kaparda,@}¦ ‘braid,’ {@Kapardin,@} ‘wearing braids.’ These words
refer to the Vedic custom of wearing the hair in braids or
plaits. Thus a maiden is said to have her hair in four plaits
({%catuṣ-kapardā%}),<sup>1</sup> and the goddess Sinīvālī is described as ‘wear-
ing fair braids’ ({%su-kapardā%}).<sup>2</sup> Men also wore their hair in this
style, for both Rudra<sup>3</sup> and Pūṣan<sup>4</sup> are said to have done so,
while the {@Vasiṣṭhas@}<sup>5</sup> were distinguished by wearing their hair
in a plait on the right ({%dakṣiṇatas-kaparda%}). The opposite was
to wear one's hair ‘plain’ ({%pulasti%}).<sup>6</sup> See also {@Opaśa.@}
<F>1) Rv. x. 114, 3.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 56.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 114, 1. 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
hitā, xvi. 10. 29. 43. 48. 59.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 55, 2; ix. 67. 11.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 33, 1. {%Cf.%} 83, 8.</F>
<F>6) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 43.
{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 264,
265; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} v. 462; Max
Müller, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 424.</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-136+ 53]

<L>512<pc>1-136<k1>kapi<k2>kapi<h>1
1. {@Kapi,@}¦ ‘monkey,’ occurs only once in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> with
reference to Vṛṣā-kapi, the ‘Man-ape,’ in the dialogue of Indra
and Indrāṇī in the presence of Vṛṣākapi. There the ape is
termed the ‘tawny’ ({%harita%}). In the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> the monkey
is mentioned several times as hairy, and an enemy of dogs.
That the ape was tamed appears from its position in the
Vṛṣākapi hymn, and from the mention, in the Taittirīya Saṃ-
hitā,<sup>3</sup> of a {@Mayu@} as belonging to the forest. See also {@Mayu,@}
{@Markaṭa,@} and {@Puruṣa Hastin.@}
<F>1) x. 86. 5. {%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Religion%}
{%des Veda,%} 174; Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%}
2, 22 {%et seq.;%} von Schroeder, {%Mysterium%}
{%und Mimus,%} 304 {%et seq.;%} Schirmeisen,
{%Die Arischen Göttergestalten,%} 218 {%et seq.;%}
Tilak, {%Orion,%} 170-197.</F>
<F>2) iii. 9, 4; iv. 32, 11; vi. 49, 1.
{%Cf.%} also Chāndogya Upaniṣad, i. 6, 7
({%kapy-āsa,%} ‘seat of an ape’).</F>
<F>3) iv. 2, 10, 1. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
{%disches Leben,%} 85, 86.</F>
<LEND>

(xxx. 2), but the name appears rather to be {@Luśākapi.@}

<L>517<pc>1-137<k1>kapota<k2>kapota
{@Kapota@}¦ is the name of a bird, probably the ‘pigeon’ (its
sense in the later language), occurring from the Rigveda
onwards.<sup>1</sup> It is associated in some passages<sup>2</sup> with the owl
({@Ulūka@}) as a messenger of Nirṛti (‘dissolution,’ ‘misfortune’).
This aspect of the pigeon as a bird of evil omen is probably
based on an ancient belief which is also found beyond the
confines of India.<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 30, 4; Av. xx. 135, 12;
Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 4; Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 23. 38.</F>

<F>3) {%Cf.%} Schrader, {%Prchistoric Antiquities,%}
253.

St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>

<L>521<pc>1-138<k1>kamboja<k2>kamboja
{@Kamboja. — Yāska,@}¦ in the Nirukta,<sup>1</sup> refers to the speech of
the Kambojas as differing from that of the other Āryas. The
Kambojas were later settled to the north-west of the Indus, and
are known as Kambujiya in the old Persian inscriptions. A
teacher, {@Kāmboja Aupamanyava,@} pupil of {@Madragāra,@} is
mentioned in the Vaṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> This points to a possible
connexion of the Madras, or more probably the {@Uttara Madras,@}
with the Kambojas, who probably had Iranian as well as Indian
affinities.
<F>1) ii. 2.</F>
<F>2) {%Indische Studien,%} 4, 372.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 102;
Weber, {%Indische Streifen,%} 2, 493; 3, 384;
{%Indische Studien,%} 10, 7; {%Episches im%}
{%vedischen Ritual,%} 45; Max Müller, {%Zeit-%}
{%schrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
{%Gesellschaft,%} 7, 373. On the relation of
Indian and Iranian, see also Jacobi,
{%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1909,
721 {%et seq.;%} 1910, 457 {%et seq.;%} Oldenberg,
{%ibid.,%} 1095 {%et seq.;%} Keith, {%ibid.,%} 1100 {%et%}
{%seq.;%} Kennedy, {%ibid.,%} 1107 {%et seq.;%} and
see {@Parśu.@}</F>

({@Tirya@}).<sup>4</sup>

<L>533<pc>1-140<k1>karmAra<k2>karmAra
{@Karmāra,@}¦ the ‘smith,’ is several times mentioned with
approval in the Vedic Saṃhitās.<sup>1</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> smiths
appear with fishermen ({%dhīvānaḥ%}) and chariot-builders ({%ratha-%}
{%kārāḥ%}), all being classified as clever workers ({%manīṣiṇaḥ%}):
possibly a quasi-caste of smiths was already developing from
the guild organization that probably existed.<sup>3</sup>
<div n="P"/>Little is known of the smith's methods of work and of his
tools. No doubt he smelted ({%dhmā%}) the ore in the fire; hence
he is called {%dhmātṛ,%} the ‘smelter.’<sup>4</sup> Mention is also made of
[Page1-141+ 50]
his bellows of birds' feathers.<sup>5</sup> He made metal vessels ({%gharma%}
{%ayasmaya%})<sup>6</sup> to be put on the fire: even the Soma cup could
occasionally be made of hammered metal ({%ayo-hata%}).<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) Rv. x. 72, 2; Av. iii. 5, 6; Kāṭhaka
Saṃhitā, xvii. 13; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
ii. 9, 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;
xxx. 7. {%Cf. karmāra,%} Rv. ix. 112, 2;
Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 3, 1.</F>
<F>2) iii. 5, 6. The exact sense of the
passage is doubtful. Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
{%disches Leben,%} 252; Bloomfield, {%Hymns%}
{%of the Atharvaveda,%} 144; and Whitney,
Translation of the Atharvaveda, 92,
take the reference to be to ‘skilled
chariot-makers’ ({%dhīvāno ratha-kārāḥ%})
and ‘clever smiths,’ but this is perhaps
less likely. The commentator interprets
{%dhīvānaḥ%} as ‘fishermen’ (in the later
language {%dhīvara%} means both a ‘clever
man’ and a ‘fisherman’).</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Fick, {%Die sociale Gliederung,%} 182.</F>
<F>4) Rv. v. 9. 5.</F>
<F>5) Rv. ix. 112, 2.</F>
<F>6) Rv. v. 30, 15.</F>
<F>7) Rv. ix. 1, 2.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 252, 253; Weber,
{%Indische Studien,%} 17, 196 {%et seq.; Über%}
{%den Rājasūya,%} 19 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>540<pc>1-142<k1>kali<k2>kali<h>2
2. {@Kali@}¦ occurs in the Rigveda, twice in the singular<sup>1</sup> as the
name of a protégé of the Aśvins, and once in the plural.<sup>2</sup>
The persons meant in the latter passage seem to be different
from the former one. The Kalis are once mentioned in the
Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> beside the Gandharvas.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) i. 112, 15; x. 39, 8.</F>
<F>2) viii. 66, 15.</F>
<F>3) x. 10, 13.</F>
<F>4) These Kalis may be connected with
dicing, as in the Atharvaveda the
Apsarases, the wives of the Gandharvas,
are fond of dice, and bestow luck at
play. See Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
p. 135.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
{%Oriental Society,%} 17, 89; Ludwig, Trans-
lation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</F>
<LEND>

<L>544<pc>1-143<k1>kavaca<k2>kavaca
{@Kavaca@}¦ denotes a ‘corselet’ or ‘breastplate’ in the Atharva-

<L>545<pc>1-143<k1>kavaza<k2>kavaza
{@Kavaṣa@}¦ is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as one of
those whom, together with the {@Druhyu@} king, Indra overthrew
for the {@Tṛtsus.@} The Anukramaṇī (Index) also attributes to
him the authorship of several hymns of the Rigveda, including
two (x. 32. 33) that deal with a prince {@Kuruśravaṇa@} and his
descendant {@Upamaśravas.@} There seems no reason to doubt
this attribution, which is accepted by both Zimmer<sup>2</sup> and
Geldner.<sup>3</sup> The former holds that Kavaṣa was the Purohita of
the joint tribes named {@Vaikarṇa,@} in whom he sees the Kuru-
Krivi (Pañcāla) peoples, and that Kavaṣa in that capacity is
mentioned in the Rigveda as representative of those peoples.
He also suggests that the language of Rigveda x. 33, 4 is best
explained by the reduced position in which the Kuru-Krivis
found themselves on their defeat by the Tṛtsus. Ludwig,<sup>4</sup> on
the other hand, thinks that Kavaṣa was the priest of the five
peoples. Geldner<sup>5</sup> holds that Kavaṣa was the Purohita of
Kuruśravaṇa, by whose son, Upamaśravas, he was ill-treated,
and that he composed Rigveda x. 33 to deprecate the anger of
his royal master. Hopkins<sup>6</sup> thinks that he was a king.
<div n="P"/>In the Brāhmaṇas of the Rigveda<sup>7</sup> mention is made of
[Page1-144+ 45]
Kavaṣa Ailūṣa, who was a Brāhmaṇa born of a female slave,
and was reproached on this ground by the other Ṛṣis. He is
possibly identical with the Kavaṣa of the Rigveda.
<F>1) vii. 18, 12.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 127.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 150.</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139.</F>
<F>5) {%Loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>6) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
{%Society,%} 15, 261, 263.</F>
<F>7) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 19; Kauṣī-
taki Brāhmaṇa, xii. 1, 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 3, 459;
Lanman, {%Sanskrit Reader,%} 386, 387;
Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
{%Society,%} 1910, 50.</F>
<LEND>

<L>552<pc>1-145<k1>kaSyapa<k2>kaSyapa

in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> but is a common figure in the later Saṃhitās.<sup>2</sup>

past. According to the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> he anointed King
{@Viśvakarman Bhauvana,@} and in the Upaniṣads<sup>4</sup> he is mentioned
as a Ṛṣi. The Kaśyapas appear in connexion with {@Janam-@}
{@ejaya@} in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>5</sup>
<F>1) ix. 114, 2.</F>
<F>2) Sāmaveda, i. 1, 2, 4, 10; 4, 2, 3, 2
(but in these passages the St. Peters-

xiii. 7, 1, 15.</F>

<L>583<pc>1-149<k1>kAmpIla<k2>kAmpIla
{@Kāmpīla.@}¦ — In one passage of the Yajurveda Saṃhitās<sup>1</sup> the
epithet Kāmpīla-vāsinī is applied to a woman, perhaps the
king's Mahiṣī or chief wife, whose duty it was to sleep beside
the slaughtered animal at the horse sacrifice (Aśvamedha).
The exact interpretation of the passage is very uncertain, but
both Weber<sup>2</sup> and Zimmer<sup>3</sup> agree in regarding Kāmpīla as the
name of the town known as Kāmpīlya in the later literature,
and the capital of Pañcāla in Madhyadeśa.

Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 20;
Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, Aśvamedha, iv. 8;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 18; Tait-
tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 9, 6; Satapatha
Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 2, 8, 3.</F>

{%Literature,%} 114, 115.</F>

<L>589<pc>1-150<k1>kAru<k2>kAru
{@Kāru,@}¦ ‘poet,’ is a word almost confined to the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup>
There is evidence that the poet was regarded as a professional
man, just as much as the physician ({@Bhiṣaj@}).<sup>2</sup> The poets, no
doubt, mainly lived at the courts of princes amid their re-
tainers,<sup>3</sup> though they would probably also sing the praises of rich
merchants. There was probably no essential connexion between
the priest and the poet. Though the priest was often a poet,
yet poetry can hardly have been restricted to the priestly caste.
Indeed, at the horse sacrifice (Aśvamedha) the Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> expressly requires that one of the singers of pane-
gyrics should be a Rājanya, while the other was a Brāhmaṇa,
both singing verses of their own composition. The Anukra-
maṇī (Index) in several cases<sup>5</sup> attributes hymns of the Rigveda
to princes; and even though this may often be merely the
same sort of procedure<sup>6</sup> as has made Śūdraka the author of
the Mṛcchakaṭikā, or Harṣa of the Ratnāvalī, and has given
us royal teachers of the Brahman doctrine,<sup>7</sup> still the Indian
tradition evidently saw nothing odd in the idea of non-
Brāhmaṇas as poets. Most of the non-sacred poetry has,
[Page1-151+ 37]
however, disappeared, for the epic is a product, as it stands,
of a later period. See also {@Ṛṣi.@}
<F>1) i. 148, 2; 165, 12; 177, 5; 178, 3;
ii. 43, 1; iii. 33, 8; 39, 7; v. 33, 7;
vii. 27; 68, 9; 72, 4, etc.: Maitrāyaṇī
Saṃhitā, i. 8, 7; Gopatha Brāhmaṇa,
i. 2, 21.</F>
<F>2) ix. 112. 3.</F>
<F>3) vii. 73. 1.</F>
<F>4) xiii. 1, 5, 1; 4, 3, 5.</F>
<F>5) {%E.g.,%} x. 92 is attributed to Śāryāta
Mānava.</F>
<F>6) See Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 202.</F>
<F>7) Weber, {%Episches im vedischen Ritual,%}
20, n. 4, sees in Av. xx. a recension
of Kṣatriya character. He also finds
Kṣatriyas in {@Viśvāmitra@} and {@Kakṣīvant,@}
but hardly with reason. {%Cf.%} {@Varṇa.@}</F>
<LEND>

<L>596<pc>1-152<k1>kAla<k2>kAla
{@Kāla,@}¦ the generic expression for ‘time,’ first occurs in the
Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where, however, it is used only once, in the late
tenth book. It is known to the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> where Kāla has
already developed the sense of time as fate. The word is
frequent in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>3</sup> superseding the earlier use of {@Ṛtu.@}
The more general division of time is into ‘past’ ({%bhūta%}),
‘present’ ({%bhavat%}), and ‘future’ ({%bhaviṣyat%}).<sup>4</sup> For other divisions
see {@Ahan, Māsa, Saṃvatsara.@}
<F>1) x. 42, 9.</F>
<F>2) xix. 53. 54.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 3, 3;
ii. 4, 2, 4; iii. 8, 3, 36; vii. 2, 2, 21,
etc.</F>
<F>4) {%E.g.,%} Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, vii. 20.</F>
<LEND>

<L>598<pc>1-152<k1>kAlakAYja<k2>kAlakAYja

the Atharvaveda. Whitney<sup>5</sup> suggests that the three stars of

<L>602<pc>1-153<k1>kASi<k2>kASi
{@Kāśi, Kāśya.@}¦ — The name Kāśi denotes (in the plural<sup>1</sup>) the
people of Kāśi (Benares), and Kāśya, the king of Kāśi. The
Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> tells of {@Dhṛtarāṣṭra,@} king of Kāśi, who
was defeated by {@Śatānīka Sātrājita,@} with the result that the
Kāśis, down to the time of the Brāhmaṇa, gave up the kindling
of the sacred fire. Sātrājita was a {@Bharata.@} We hear also of
{@Ajātaśatru@} as a king of Kāśi;<sup>3</sup> and no doubt {@Bhadrasena@}
{@Ajātaśatrava,@} a contemporary of {@Uddālaka,@} was also a king of
Kāśi.
<div n="P"/>The Kāśis and {@Videhas@} were closely connected, as was
natural in view of their geographical position. The compound
name Kāśi-Videha occurs in the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad;<sup>4</sup> in the
Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>5</sup> {@Gārgī@} describes Ajātaśatru as either
a Kāśi or a Videha king. The Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>6</sup>
[Page1-154+ 49]
mentions one Purohita as acting for the kings of Kāśi, Kosala,
and Videha; and the Baudhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>7</sup> mentions Kāśi
and Videha in close proximity. Weber,<sup>8</sup> indeed, throws out
the suggestion that the Kāśis and the Videhas together con-
stitute the {@Uśīnaras,@} whose name is very rare in Vedic
literature.
<div n="P"/>As Kosala and Videha were in close connexion, Kāśi and
Kosala are found combined in the compound name Kāśi-
Kauśalyas of the Gopatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>Though Kāśi is a late word, it is quite possible that the town
is older, as the river {@Varaṇāvatī@} referred to in the Athar-
vaveda<sup>10</sup> may be connected with the later Vārāṇasī (Benares).
<div n="P"/>It is significant that while the Kāśis, Kosalas, and Videhas
were united, any relations which the Kuru-Pañcala peoples
may have had with them were hostile. It is a fair conclusion
that between these two great groups of peoples there did exist
some political conflict as well as probably a difference of culture
in some degree. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>11</sup> in the story of the
advance of Āryan civilization over Kosala and Videha, preserves
a clear tradition of this time, and a piece of evidence that in
the Kuru-Pañcāla country lay the real centre of the Brāhmaṇa
culture (see also {@Kuru-Pañcāla@}). That the Kosala-Videhas
were originally settlers of older date than the Kuru-Pañcālas
is reasonably obvious from their geographical position, but the
true Brāhmaṇa culture appears to have been brought to them
from the Kuru-Pañcala country. It is very probable that the
East was less Āryan than the West, and that it was less
completely reduced under Brahmin spiritual supremacy, as the
movement of Buddhism was Eastern, and the Buddhist texts<sup>12</sup>
reveal a position in which the Kṣatriyas rank above Brāhmaṇas.
With this agrees the fact that the later Vedic texts<sup>13</sup> display
[Page1-155+ 43]
towards the people of Magadha a marked antipathy, which
may be reasonably explained by that people's lack of orthodoxy,
and which may perhaps be traced as far back as the Vājasaneyi
Saṃhitā.<sup>14</sup> It is, of course, possible that the Kosala-Videhas
and Kāśis actually were merely offshoots of the tribes later
known as the Kuru-Pañcālas, and that they by reason of
distance and less complete subjugation of the aborigines lost
their Brahminical culture. This hypothesis, however, appears
less likely, though it might be supported by a literal inter-
pretation of the legend of the Aryan migration in the Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa.<sup>15</sup>
<F>1) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 5, 4,
19. 21. The plural occurs also in
the Paippalāda recension of the Athar-
vaveda, v. 22, 14.</F>
<F>2) xiii. 5, 4, 19.</F>
<F>3) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 1, 1;
iii. 8, 2; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, iv. 1.</F>
<F>4) Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>5) iii. 8, 2.</F>
<F>6) xvi. 29, 5.</F>
<F>7) xxi. 13.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 212,
213.</F>
<F>9) i. 2, 9.</F>
<F>10) iv. 7. 1. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches%}
{%Leben,%} 20; Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the%}
{%Atharvaveda,%} 376.</F>
<F>11) i. 4, 1, 10 {%et seq. Cf.%} Weber,
{%Indische Studien,%} 1, 170 {%et seq.;%} Eggeling,
{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 12, xlii {%et seq.,%}
104, n. 1.</F>
<F>12) See Fick, {%Die seciale Gliederung,%}
chap. iv.</F>
<F>13) Kātyāyana Srauta Sūtra, xxii. 4,
22; Lāṭyāyana Śrauta Sūtra, viii. 6,
28. See Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10,
99; Fick, {%op. cit.,%} 140, n. 1; and {%of.%}
{@Magadha.@}</F>
<F>14) xxx. 5. 22. See {@Magadha.@}</F>
<F>15) {%Cf.%} Eggeling, {%loc. cit.,%} 104, n. 1.
{%Cf.%} Grierson, {%Journal of the Royal%}
{%Asiatic Society,%} 1908, 837, 1143; Keith,
{%ibid.,%} 831, 1138; Oldenberg, {%Buddha,%}
402 {%et seq.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>607<pc>1-156<k1>kAs<k2>kAs
{@Kās, Kāsa, Kāsā, Kāsikā.@}¦ — All these four forms<sup>1</sup> of the same
word denote ‘cough,’ which is mentioned in the Atharvaveda
as accompanying a headache,<sup>2</sup> as a symptom in fever ({@Takman@}),<sup>3</sup>
and as an independent disease.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) Kās: Av. i. 12, 3; v. 22, 10;
{@Kāsa:@} Av. v. 22, 11 (probably); Kāsā:
Av. vi. 105, 1 {%et seq.;%} Kāsikā: Av, v. 22,
12; xi. 2, 22.</F>
<F>2) Av. i. 12, 3.</F>
<F>3) v. 22, 10.</F>
<F>4) vi. 105.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 385;
Grohmann, {%Indische Studien,%} 9, 394;
Jolly, {%Medicin,%} 89.</F>

<L>611<pc>1-156<k1>kitava<k2>kitava
{@Kitava,@}¦ ‘the gambler,’ is frequently referred to in the Rig-
veda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> A father is represented as chastising his son
for gambling.<sup>3</sup> The gambler seems at times to have fallen,
along with his family, into servitude, presumably by selling
himself to pay his debts.<sup>4</sup> Technical names<sup>5</sup> for different sorts
of gamblers given in the Yajurveda Saṃhitās are Ādinava-darśa,
[Page1-157+ 49]
Kalpin, Adhi-kalpin, and Sabhā-sthāṇu. None of these can be
safely<sup>6</sup> explained, though the last has usually<sup>7</sup> been taken as a
satirical name derived from the gambler's devotion to the dicing
place ({@Sabhā@}), ‘pillar of the dicing hall.’ The first literally
means ‘seeing ill-luck,’<sup>8</sup> and may refer to the quickness of the
dicer to note an error on the part of his antagonist, or to his
eagerness to see the defeat of his rival.
<F>1) ii. 29, 5; v. 85, 8; x. 34, 3. 7. 10.
11. 13.</F>
<F>2) Av. vii. 50, 1; 109, 3; Vājasaneyi
Saṃhitā, xxx. 8. 18. 22; Aitareya Brāh-
maṇa, ii. 19, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. ii. 29, 5. {%Cf.%} {@Pitṛ.@}</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 34. {%Cf.%} perhaps the {%bhakta-%}
{%dāsa,%} ‘slave for hire,’ of the Mānava
Dharma Sāstra, viii. 415; Fick, {%Die%}
{%sociale Gliederung,%} 197.</F>
<F>5) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 3, 1 {%et seq.;%}
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 18.</F>
<F>6) {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 18, 282;
Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 284.</F>
<F>7) So Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
hitā, xxx. 18; Sāyaṇa on Taittirīya
Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 16, 1.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} Roth, St. Petersburg Dic-
tionary, {%s.v.;%} Weber, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>612<pc>1-157<k1>kiMpuruza<k2>kiMpuruza
{@Kiṃ-puruṣa,@}¦ lit. ‘what sort of man,’ appears in the Brāh-
maṇas<sup>1</sup> to designate the ‘ape,’ which is a mimic man. Possibly
the same sense should be seen in the passage of the Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>2</sup> where it occurs, and where Roth<sup>3</sup> assumes it
to refer to a contemptible man. Max Müller<sup>4</sup> renders it
‘savage.’

patha Brāhmaṇa, i. 2, 3, 9; vii. 5,
2, 32.</F>
<F>2) xxx. 16; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii.
4, 12, 1.</F>

{%Omina und Portenta,%} 356; Eggeling,

<L>613<pc>1-157<k1>kiyAmbu<k2>kiyAmbu
{@Kiyāmbu@}¦ is the name of one of the water-plants which are to
grow, according to a funeral hymn in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> on the place
where the body of the dead was burned. The word seems to
mean ‘having some water,’ possibly by popular etymology.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) x. 16, 13 = Av. xviii. 3, 6.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Sāyaṇa on Rv., {%loc. cit.,%} and on

Kyāmbu is the form.

{%Oriental Society,%} October, 1890, xl.</F>

<L>614<pc>1-157<k1>kirAta<k2>kirAta<h>1
1. {@Kirāta@}¦ is a name applied to a people living in the caves
of the mountains, as appears clearly from the dedication of the
Kirāta to the caves ({%guhā%}) in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>1</sup> and
from the reference in the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> to a Kirāta girl ({%kairā-%}
{%tikā%}), who digs a remedy on the ridges of the mountains.
[Page1-158+ 54]
Later<sup>3</sup> the people called Kirātas were located in Eastern Nepal,
but the name seems to have been applied to any hill folk, no
doubt aborigines, though the Mānava Dharma Śāstra<sup>4</sup> regards
them as degraded Kṣatriyas.
<F>1) xxx. 16; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 12, 1.</F>
<F>2) x. 4, 14.</F>
<F>3) Lassen, {%Indische Alterthumskunde,%} 1^2,
530, 534.</F>
<F>4) x. 44.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 32;
Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3,
207; V. Smith, {%Journal of the Royal%}
{%Asiatic Socicty,%} 1909, 258, n. 1; Lévi,
{%Le Népal,%} 2, 77.</F>
<LEND>

<L>615<pc>1-158<k1>kirAta<k2>kirAta<h>2
2. {@Kirāta.@}¦ — In the story of {@Asamāti@} there appear, as the two
priests who are opposed to the {@Gaupāyanas,@} Kirāta and {@Akuli@}
according to the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> or Kilāta and Ākuli
according to the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> No doubt the name is
chosen, not as that of a historic person, but as a suitable
designation of a hostile priest; for it is probably identical with
the name of the mountaineers described in the preceding article.
<F>1) xiii. 12, 5 (where the text reads
{%kirāta-kulyau%}). Böhtlingk, Dictionary,
{%s.v.,%} takes the word, with Sāyaṇa, as
an adjective, {%kirāta-kula,%} ‘of the family
of Kirāta.’ The reading in the Bṛhad-
devatā (vii. 86) is {%kirātākulī.%}</F>
<F>2) i. 1, 4, 14 (where the text reads
{%kilātākulī%}). {%Cf.%} also Sāṭyāyanaka Brāh-
maṇa {%apud%} Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 57, 1;
60, 1; Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 167;
{%Journal of the American Oriental Socicty,%}
18, 41 {%et seq.;%} Hopkins, {%Transactions of%}
{%the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}
{%Sciences,%} 15, 48, n. 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>617<pc>1-158<k1>kilAsa<k2>kilAsa
{@Kilāsa@}¦ is the name of a disease, ‘white leprosy,’ in the Athar-
vaveda<sup>1</sup> and the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, etc.<sup>2</sup> It resulted in the
appearance of grey ({%palita%}) and white ({%śukla, śveta%}) spots all
over the skin. Haug gave the same sense to {%alasa%} in the
Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> but this is doubtful. The fem. Kilāsī is
taken by Max Müller to mean a ‘spotted deer’ in one passage
of the Rigveda.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) i. 23, 24.</F>
<F>2) xxx. 21; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,
xiv. 3, 17; xxiii. 11, 11; Taittirīya
Āraṇyaka, v. 4, 12. {%Cf.%} Zimmer,
{%Altindisches Leben,%} 391; Bloomfield,
{%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 266; Jolly,
{%Medicin,%} 98; Hopkins, {%Transactions of%}
{%the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}
{%Sciences,%} 15, 68.</F>
<F>3) vi. 33, 5.</F>
<F>4) v. 53, 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>618<pc>1-159<k1>kIkawa<k2>kIkawa
{@Kīkaṭa.@}¦ — The name of this people occurs only in one passage
of the Rigveda, where they appear as hostile to the singer and
as under the leadership of {@Pramaganda.@} Yāska<sup>2</sup> declares that
Kīkaṭa was the name of a non-Āryan country, and later<sup>3</sup>
Kīkaṭa is given as a synonym of Magadha. Hence Zimmer<sup>4</sup>
concludes that the Kīkaṭas were a non-Āryan people living in
the country later known as Magadha. Weber<sup>5</sup> holds that this
people were located in Magadha, but were Āryan, though at
variance with other Āryan tribes, perhaps because of heretical
tendencies, for Magadha was later a seat of Buddhism. But
the identification is uncertain, and is doubted by Oldenberg<sup>6</sup>
and Hillebrandt.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="P"/>^1 iii. 53, 14.
<F>2) Nirukta, vi. 32.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 31, 118. {%Cf.%}
Geldner, {%Rigveda, Kommentar,%} 58.</F>
<F>5) {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 186; {%Indian%}
{%Literature,%} 79, n. *.</F>
<F>6) {%Buddha,%} 402, 403; {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1,
253.</F>
<F>7) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 14-18.</F>
<LEND>

<L>623<pc>1-160<k1>kIlAla<k2>kIlAla
{@Kīlāla,@}¦ a word denoting a ‘sweet drink,’ is found in all the
later Saṃhitās,<sup>1</sup> but not in the Rigveda. As the Surā-kāra,
‘maker of Surā,’ is dedicated in the list of victims in the human
sacrifice<sup>2</sup> (Puruṣamedha) to Kīlāla, it must have been a drink
of somewhat the same nature as the {@Surā@} itself, possibly, as
Zimmer<sup>3</sup> suggests, a kind of rum.
<F>1) Av. iv. 11, 10; 26, 6; 27, 5;
vi. 69, 1; x. 6, 25; xii. 1, 59; Tait-
tirīya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 12, 13; Maitrā-
yaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 12; iii. 11, 3. 4;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 34; iii. 43;
xx. 65; xxx. 11, etc.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;
Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 9, 1.</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 281.</F>

<L>631<pc>1-161<k1>kutsa<k2>kutsa
{@Kutsa@}¦ is the name of a hero frequently mentioned in the
Rigveda, which, however, gives practically no information
about him, for he was no doubt already a figure of the mythic
past. He is several times<sup>1</sup> called Ārjuneya, ‘descendant of
Arjuna,’ and is usually<sup>2</sup> associated with Indra in the exploit of
defeating the demon Śuṣṇa and winning the sun. He is said<sup>3</sup>
to have defeated {@Smadibha, Tugra,@} and the {@Vetasus,@} but, on the
other hand, he is several times<sup>4</sup> mentioned with {@Atithigva@} and
{@Āyu@} as being vanquished by Indra, his defeat in one passage<sup>5</sup>
being attributed to {@Tūrvayāṇa.@} Elsewhere<sup>6</sup> he appears with
Atithigva as a friend of Indra's. In the later literature he is
seldom<sup>7</sup> mentioned except in connexion with the myth of his
binding Indra, which is found in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>8</sup> and which is
based on an obscure verse in the Rigveda.<sup>9</sup>
[Page1-162+ 41]
<div n="P"/>The Kutsas, or descendants of Kutsa, are mentioned in one
hymn of the Rigveda.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) Rv. iv. 26, 1; vii. 19, 2; viii. 1,
11.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 63, 3; 121, 19; 174, 5;
175, 4; iv. 30, 4; v. 29, 4; vi. 20, 5;
vii. 19, 2; x. 99, 9.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 49, 4.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 53, 10; ii. 14, 7; viii. 53, 2.
{%Cf.%} iv. 26, 1.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 53, 10.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 51, 6; vi. 26, 3.</F>
<F>7) {%E.g.,%} Av. iv. 29, 5; Pañcaviṃśa
Brāhmaṇa, xiv. 11, 26.</F>
<F>8) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, ix. 2, 22;
Śāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 38,
5; Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 228; Oertel.
{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
18, 31.</F>
<F>9) x. 38, 5.</F>
<F>10) vii. 25, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
veda, 3, 113, 148; Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift%}
{%der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell-%}
{%schaft,%} 42, 210, 211; Hillebrandt,
{%Vedische Mythologie,%} 3, 284 {%et seq.,%} who
suggests that perhaps two Kutsas — one
a friend of Indra, and the other a foe
 — may be distinguished; Geldner,
{%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 171; Hopkins,
{%Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of%}
{%Arts and Sciences,%} 15, 57, n. 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>635<pc>1-162<k1>kuBA<k2>kuBA
{@Kubhā@}¦ is the name of a river mentioned twice in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup>
and no doubt identical with the modern Kabul river, the
Greek <lang n="greek">Κωφήν</lang>.
<F>1) v. 53, 9; x. 75. 6. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 14; Ludwig, Translation
of the Rigveda, 3, 200.</F>
<LEND>

<L>636<pc>1-162<k1>kuBra<k2>kuBra
{@Kubhra@}¦ is the name of some animal in the Maitrāyaṇī
Saṃhitā (ii. 5, 3).

<L>637<pc>1-163<k1>kumuda<k2>kumuda
{@Ku-muda@}¦ is the name of a plant mentioned with other water
plants in one passage of the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> It is no doubt the
white water-lily ({%Nymphœa esculenta%}), being the name of that
plant in post-Vedic Sanskrit also.
<F>1) iv. 34. 5. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 70.</F>
<LEND>

<L>638<pc>1-163<k1>kumba<k2>kumba
{@Kumba@}¦ is mentioned with {@Opaśa@} and {@Kurīra@} as an ornament
of women's hair in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> Geldner<sup>2</sup> thinks that,
like those two words, it originally meant ‘horn,’ but this is
very doubtful. Indian tradition<sup>3</sup> simply regards the term as
denoting a female adornment connected with the dressing of
the hair.
<F>1) vi. 138, 3.</F>
<F>2) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 131.</F>
<F>3) Sāyaṇa on Av. vi. 138, 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 265;
Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%}
538, 539; Whitney, Translation of the
Atharvaveda, 348; Caland, {%Über das%}
{%vituclle Sūtra des Baudhāyana,%} 59.</F>
<LEND>

<L>639<pc>1-163<k1>kumbyA<k2>kumbyA
{@Kumbyā@}¦ or {@Kumvyā@} is a word mentioned after Ṛc, Yajus,
Sāman, and Gāthā in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> to denote
a form of speech. In the Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>2</sup> it appears as
one of the forms of measured speech together with Ṛc and
Gāthā. The precise meaning of the term is unknown. Weber<sup>3</sup>
suggests the sense ‘refrain.’
<F>1) xi. 5, 7, 10.</F>
<F>2) ii. 3, 6.</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Studien,%} 10, 111, n.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Keith, {%Aitareya Āraṇyaka,%} 221;
Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 44.
101.</F>
<LEND>

<L>640<pc>1-163<k1>kumBa<k2>kumBa
{@Kumbha@}¦ is a word of frequent occurrence in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup>
as well as later,<sup>2</sup> and denotes a ‘pot.’ Usually no doubt made
of clay, it was easily broken.<sup>3</sup> See also {@Ukhā.@}
<F>1) i. 116, 7; 117, 6; vii. 33, 13, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. i. 6, 4; iii. 12, 7, etc.; Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 87, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 89, 7.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Schrader, {%Prehistoric Antiquities,%}
367.</F>
<LEND>

<L>641<pc>1-163<k1>kumBInasa<k2>kumBInasa
{@Kumbhī-nasa@}¦ (‘pot-nosed’) is the name of an animal
mentioned in the list of victims at the horse sacrifice (Aśva-
medha) in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā.<sup>1</sup> Possibly some sort of
snake is meant, as in the later literature.
<F>1) v. 5, 14, 1. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 95; St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s. v.%}</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-164+ 48]

<L>642<pc>1-164<k1>kuyavAc<k2>kuyavAc
{@Kuya-vāc@}¦ (‘evil-speaking’) appears in one passage of the
Rigveda<sup>1</sup> to denote a demon slain by Indra, probably as a
personification of the barbarian opponents of the Āryans. The
expression {%mṛdhra-vāc%} (‘speaking insultingly’) is similarly used
of barbarians in the Rigveda.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) i. 174, 7.</F>
<F>2) v. 29, 10; 32, 8. See Dasyu.</F>
<LEND>

<L>643<pc>1-164<k1>kurIra<k2>kurIra
{@Kurīra,@}¦ like {@Opaśa@} and {@Kumba,@} denotes some sort of female
head ornament in the description of the bride's adornment in
the wedding hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and in the Atharvaveda.<sup>2</sup>
According to the Yajurveda Saṃhitās,<sup>3</sup> the goddess Sinīvālī is
described by the epithets {%su-kapardā, su-kurīra, sv-opaśā,%} as
wearing a beautiful head-dress.
<div n="P"/>According to Geldner,<sup>4</sup> the word originally meant ‘horn’;
but this is uncertain, as this sense is not required in any
passage in which the term occurs.<sup>5</sup>
<F>1) x. 85. 8.</F>
<F>2) vi. 138, 3.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 5, 3:
Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7. 5; Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 56.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 131, 132.</F>
<F>5) Gopatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 21
(= vaitāna Sūtra, xi. 22), cited by
Geldner, is quite vague.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 265;

<L>644<pc>1-164<k1>kurIrin<k2>kurIrin
{@Kurīrin@}¦ (‘having a {@Kurīra@}’) is a word occurring in an
ambiguous passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> in which it may be
taken either as a noun meaning a ‘crested animal,’ perhaps as
Zimmer<sup>2</sup> suggests the ‘peacock,’ or as an epithet of the word
{@Aja,@} ‘goat,’ in which case it might mean ‘horned.’ But even
in the latter alternative a metaphorical application of the word
seems sufficient, just as in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> {@Opaśa@}
is used of the horns of cattle, and thus renders unnecessary
the adoption of Geldner's<sup>4</sup> view that the original meaning of
{@Kurīra@} is ‘horn.’
<F>1) v. 31, 2.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 91.</F>
<F>3) xiii. 4, 3.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 130.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
{%vaveda,%} 457, 539; Weber, {%Indische%}
{%Studien,%} 18, 285; Whitney, Translation
of the Atharvaveda, 279.</F>

[Page1-165+ 63]

<L>645<pc>1-165<k1>kuru<k2>kuru
{@Kuru.@}¦ — The Kurus appear as by far the most important
people in the Brāhmaṇa literature. There is clear evidence
that it was in the country of the Kurus, or the allied Kuru-
Pañcālas, that the great Brāhmaṇas were composed.<sup>1</sup> The
Kurus are comparatively seldom mentioned alone, their name
being usually coupled with that of the Pañcālas on account of
the intimate connexion of the two peoples. The Kuru-Pañcālas
are often expressly referred to as a united nation.<sup>2</sup> In the land
of the Kuru-Pañcālas speech is said to have its particular
home;<sup>3</sup> the mode of sacrifice among the Kuru-Pañcālas is
proclaimed to be the best;<sup>4</sup> the Kuru-Pañcāla kings perform
the Rājasūya or royal sacrifice;<sup>5</sup> their princes march forth on
raids in the dewy season, and return in the hot season.<sup>6</sup> Later
on the Kuru-Pañcāla Brahmins are famous in the Upaniṣads.<sup>7</sup>
Weber<sup>8</sup> and Grierson<sup>9</sup> have sought to find traces in Vedic
literature of a breach between the two tribes, the latter scholar
seeing therein a confirmation of the theory that the Kurus
belonged to the later stream of immigrants into India, who
were specially Brahminical, as opposed to the Pañcālas, who
were anti-Brahminical. In support of this view, Weber refers
to the story in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>10</sup> of a dispute between
{@Vaka Dālbhya@} and {@Dhṛtarāṣṭra Vaicitravīrya,@} the former
being held to be by origin a Pañcāla, while the latter is held
[Page1-166+ 51]
to be a Kuru. But there is no trace of a quarrel between
Kurus and Pañcālas in the passage in question, which merely
preserves the record of a dispute on a ritual matter between a
priest and a prince: the same passage refers to the Naimiṣīya
sacrifice among the Kuru-Pañcālas, and emphasizes the close
connexion of the two peoples.<sup>11</sup> Secondly, Weber conjectures
in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>12</sup> that {@Subhadrikā@} of {@Kāmpila@} was
the chief queen of the king of a tribe living in the neighbour-
hood of the clan, for whose king the horse sacrifice described
in the Saṃhitā was performed. But the interpretation of this
passage by Weber is open to grave doubt;<sup>13</sup> and in the Kāṇva
recension of the Saṃhitā<sup>14</sup> a passage used at the Rājasūya
shows that the Kuru-Pañcālas had actually one king. More-
over, there is the evidence of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>15</sup> that
the old name of the Pañcālas was {@Krivi.@} This word looks very
like a variant of Kuru, and Zimmer<sup>16</sup> plausibly conjectures that
the Kurus and Krivis formed the {@Vaikarṇa@}<sup>17</sup> of the Rigveda,
especially as both peoples are found about the Sindhu and the
Asiknī.<sup>18</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Kurus alone are chiefly mentioned in connexion with
the locality which they occupied, {@Kurukṣetra,@} We are told,
however, of a domestic priest ({@Purohita@}) in the service of both
the Kurus and the {@Sṛñjayas,@}<sup>19</sup> who must therefore at one time
have been closely connected.<sup>20</sup> In the Chāndogya Upaniṣad
reference is made to the Kurus being saved by a mare ({%aśvā%}),<sup>21</sup>
and to some disaster which befel them owing to a hailstorm.<sup>22</sup>
In the Sūtras, again, a ceremony (Vājapeya) of the Kurus is
mentioned.<sup>23</sup> There also a curse, which was pronounced on them
and led to their being driven from Kurukṣetra, is alluded to.<sup>24</sup>
[Page1-167+ 46]
This possibly adumbrates the misfortunes of the Kauravas in
the epic tradition.
<div n="P"/>In the Rigveda the Kurus do not appear under that name as
a people. But mention is made of a prince, {@Kuruśravaṇa@}
(‘Glory of the Kurus’),<sup>25</sup> and of a {@Pākasthāman Kaurayāṇa.@}<sup>26</sup>
In the Atharvaveda<sup>27</sup> there occurs as a king of the Kurus
{@Parikṣit,@} whose son, {@Janamejaya,@} is mentioned in the Śata-
patha Brāhmaṇa<sup>28</sup> as one of the great performers of the horse
sacrifice.
<div n="P"/>It is a probable conjecture of Oldenberg's<sup>29</sup> that the Kuru
people, as known later, included some of the tribes referred to
by other names in the Rigveda. Kuruśravaṇa, shown by his
name to be connected with the Kurus, is in the Rigveda called
Trāsadasyava, ‘descendant of {@Trasadasyu,@}’ who is well known
as a king of the {@Pūrus.@} Moreover, it is likely that the Tṛtsu-
{@Bharatas,@} who appear in the Rigveda as enemies of the Pūtus,
later coalesced with them to form the Kuru people.<sup>30</sup> Since the
Bharatas appear so prominently in the Brāhmaṇa texts as a
great people of the past, while the later literature ignores them
in its list of nations, it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that
they became merged in some other tribe. Moreover, there is
evidence that the Bharatas occupied the territory in which the
Kurus were later found. Two of them are spoken of in a hymn
of the Rigveda<sup>31</sup> as having kindled fire on the {@Dṛṣadvatī,@} the
{@Āpayā,@} and the {@Sarasvatī@} — that is to say, in the sacred places
of the later Kurukṣetra. Similarly, the goddess Bhāratī
(‘belonging to the Bharatas’) is constantly mentioned in the
Āprī (‘propitiatory’) hymns together with Sarasvatī.<sup>32</sup> Again,
according to the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, one Bharata king was
victorious over the Kāśis,<sup>33</sup> and another made offerings to
Gaṅgā and Yamunā,<sup>34</sup> while raids of the Bharatas against the
{@Satvants@} are mentioned in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>35</sup> Nor is it
[Page1-168+ 60]
without importance that the Bharatas appear as a variant for
the Kuru Pañcālas in a passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>36</sup>
and that in the list of the great performers of the horse sacrifice
the names of one Kuru and two Bharata princes are given
without any mention of the people over which they ruled,
while in other cases that information is specifically given.<sup>37</sup>
<div n="P"/>The territory of the Kuru-Pañcālas is declared in the Aitareya
Brāhmaṇa to be the middle country ({@Madhyadeśa@}).<sup>38</sup> A group
of the Kuru people still remained further north — the {@Uttara@}
{@Kurus@} beyond the Himālaya. It appears from a passage of
the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa that the speech of the Northerners — 
that is, presumably, the Northern Kurus — and of the Kuru-
Pañcālas was similar, and regarded as specially pure.<sup>39</sup> There
seems little doubt that the Brahminical culture was developed
in the country of the Kuru-Pañcālas, and that it spread thence
east, south, and west. Traces of this are seen in the Vrātya
Stomas (sacrifices for the admission of non-Brahminical
Āryans) of the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>40</sup> and in the fact that in
the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka it is unusual for a Brahmin to dwell
in the territory of {@Magadha.@}<sup>41</sup> The repeated mention of Kuru-
Pañcāla Brahmins is another indication of their missionary
activity.<sup>42</sup>
<div n="P"/>The geographical position of the Kuru-Pañcālas renders it
probable that they were later immigrants into India than the
{@Kosala-Videha@} or the {@Kāśis,@}<sup>43</sup> who must have been pushed
[Page1-169+ 71]
into their more eastward territories by a new wave of Āryan
settlers from the west. But there is no evidence in Vedic
literature to show in what relation of time the immigration of
the latter peoples stood to that of their neighbours on the west.
It has, however, been conjectured,<sup>44</sup> mainly on the ground of
later linguistic phenomena, which have no cogency for the
Vedic period, that the Kurus were later immigrants, who,
coming by a new route, thrust themselves between the original
Āryan tribes which were already in occupation of the country
from east to west. {%Cf.%} also {@Kṛtvan.@} For other Kuru princes
see {@Kauravya.@}
<F>1) For the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,

{%Sanskrit Keader,%} 297, etc. The narra-

{%et seq.; Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%}
1908, 837 {%et seq.%} On the other hand, it is
probably an error to assume that the
Bharatas were originally situated far
west of Kurukṣetra, and that the main
action of the Rigveda was confined to
the Panjab. When Vasiṣṭha celebrates
the crossing of the Vipāś and Śutudrī
(Rv. iii. 33), he probably came from
the east, as Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%}
2, 218, points out, and not from the
west. Adopting the ordinary view,
Hopkins, {%India, Old and New,%} 52, finds
it necessary to suggest that Yamunā is
only another name in the Rv. for
the Paruṣṇī. But the necessity for
this suggestion, which is not in itself
plausible, disappears when it is realized
that the Bharatas held a territory
roughly corresponding to Kurukṣetra,
and bounded on the east by the
Yamunā. On the other hand, Hille-
brandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 142, 143.
places the Kurus near the Ārjīkīyā in
Kaśmīr, which puts them too far north.
So also Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 103,
and Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
12, xlii. It seems probable that the
Kurus were at a very early period
widely scattered to the north of the
Himālaya, in Kurukṣetra, and about
the Sindhu and Asiknī.

<L>646<pc>1-169<k1>kurukzetra<k2>kurukzetra
{@Kuru-kṣetra@}¦ (‘land of the Kurus’) is always regarded in the
Brāhmaṇa texts<sup>1</sup> as a particularly sacred country. Within its
boundaries flowed the rivers {@Dṛṣadvatī@} and {@Sarasvatī,@} as well
as the {@Āpayā.@}<sup>2</sup> Here, too, was situated {@Śaryaṇāvant,@}<sup>3</sup> which
[Page1-170+ 46]
appears to have been a lake, like that known to the Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa by the name of {@Anyataḥ-plakṣā.@}<sup>4</sup> According to
Pischel, there was also in Kurukṣetra a stream called {@Pastyā,@}<sup>5</sup>
which he sees in certain passages of the Rigveda. The boun-
daries of Kurukṣetra are given in a passage of the Taittirīya
Āraṇyaka<sup>6</sup> as being Khāṇḍava on the south, the Tūrghna on
the north, and the Parīṇah on the west. Roughly speaking, it
corresponded to the modern Sirhind.

Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iv. 1, 5, 13;
xi. 5, 1, 4; xiv. 1, 1, 2; Aitareya
Brāhmaṇa, vii. 30; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃ-
hitā, ii. 1, 4; iv. 5, 9; Jaiminīya
Brāhmaṇa, iii. 126 ({%Journal of the%}
{%American Oriental Society,%} 11, cxlvi);
Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xv. 16, 11,
etc.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Rv. iii. 23; Pischel, {%Vedische%}
{%Studien,%} 2, 218.</F>
<F>3) See Pischel, {%loc. cit.,%} and {%cf.%} {@Ārjī-@}
{@kīyā.@}</F>
<F>4) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5, 1, 4.</F>
<F>5) Pischel, {%loc. cit.,%} 219.</F>
<F>6) v. 1, 1. These places cannot be
further identified. See also {@Mara.@}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} von Schroeder, {%Indiens Literatur%}

<L>647<pc>1-170<k1>kuruNga<k2>kuruNga
{@Kuruṅga@}¦ is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as a prince and a

Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> the Turvaśas are connected with the {@Pañcālas@}
{@(Krivis).@}

<L>651<pc>1-171<k1>kula<k2>kula
{@Kula, Kula-pā.@}¦ — As an uncompounded word, Kula does not
occur before the period of the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>1</sup> It denotes the
‘home’ or ‘house of the family,’ and by metonymy the family
itself, as connected with the home. The Kula-pā (lit. ‘house
protector’), or chief of the family, is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>2</sup>
as inferior to and attendant on the {@Vrājapati@} in war, the latter
being perhaps the leader of the village contingent of the clan.
In the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> a girl is ironically called Kulapā, because
she is left without a husband in the world, and has only Yama
(the god of death) for a spouse.
<div n="P"/>The use of the term Kula points clearly to a system of
individual families, each no doubt consisting of several members
under the headship of the father or eldest brother, whose Kula
the dwelling is. As distinct from {@Gotra,@} Kula seems to mean
the family in the narrower sense of the members who still
live in one house, the undivided family. {%Cf.%} {@Gṛha, Grāma,@}
{@Jana, Viś.@}
<F>1) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 2, 22;
ii. 1, 4, 4; 4, 1, 14; xi. 5, 3, 11; 8, 1, 3;
xiii. 4, 2, 17; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,
i. 5, 32; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iii., 13,
6, etc.</F>
<F>2) x. 179, 2.</F>
<F>3) i. 14, 3. {%Cf.%} Whitney, Translation
of the Atharvaveda, 15; Bloomfield,
{%Hymns of the Athcrvaveda,%} 252, correcting
Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 314.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 162.</F>
<LEND>

<L>666<pc>1-173<k1>kuSika<k2>kuSika
{@Kuśika@}¦ is the probably mythical forefather<sup>1</sup> of the Kuśikas,
and especially the father of the most important member of
that family, {@Viśvāmitra.@}<sup>2</sup> The Kuśikas are repeatedly referred
[Page1-174+ 52]
to in the third Maṇḍala of the Rigveda,<sup>3</sup> and figure in the
legend of Śunaḥśepa in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>4</sup> They were
clearly a family of priests who attached themselves to the
service of the princes of the {@Bharatas.@} They were especially
devoted to the worship of Indra; hence he is styled Kauśika
even in the Rigveda.<sup>5</sup>

<L>672<pc>1-175<k1>kuzWa<k2>kuzWa<h>1
1. {@Kuṣṭha@}¦ is the name of a plant ({%Costus speciosus%} or {%arabicus%})<sup>1</sup>
which is prominent in the Atharvaveda.<sup>2</sup> It grew especially on
the mountains, along with the Soma, on the high peaks of the
Himālaya ({%Himavant%}) where the eagles nest, and was thence
brought east to men.<sup>3</sup> Like Soma, it is said to have grown in
the third heaven under the famous {@Aśvattha@} tree, where the
gods were wont to assemble, and thence it was brought in a
golden ship.<sup>4</sup> As a remedy, it held the highest place among
herbs, being called by the auspicious names Nagha-māra and
Naghā-riṣa, and styled the offspring of Jīvala and Jīvalā, the
‘lively’ ones.<sup>5</sup> It cured headache ({%śīrṣāmaya%}), diseases of the
eyes, bodily affliction,<sup>6</sup> but especially fever — hence called ‘fever-
destroyer’ ({%takma-nāśana%}) — and consumption ({@Yakṣma@}). From
its general properties it was also named ‘all-healing’ ({%viśva-%}
{%bheṣaja%}).<sup>7</sup> Its aromatic qualities were apparently known, as it
is classed with ‘salve’ ({@Āñjana@}) and ‘nard’ ({@Nalada@}).<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) Or {%Saussurea auriculata,%} Hillebreandt.
{%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 65.</F>
<F>2) v. 4; vi. 102; xix. 139.</F>
<F>3) v. 4, 1. 2. 8; xix. 39, 1.</F>
<F>4) v. 4, 3-6; vi. 75, 1. 2; xix. 39, 6-8.</F>
<F>5) v. 4, 1; xix. 39, 4.</F>
<F>6) v. 4, 10.</F>
<F>7) xix. 39, 9.</F>
<F>8) vi. 102, 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Grohmann, {%Indische, Studien,%} 9,
420 {%et seq.;%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
63, 64; Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
{%vaveda,%} 415, 680; Whitney, Translation
of the Atharvaveda, 227, 228.</F>
<LEND>

<L>674<pc>1-176<k1>kusIdin<k2>kusIdin
{@Kusīdin@}¦ is a designation of the ‘usurer’ found in the Śata-
patha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> and the Nirukta,<sup>2</sup> and often in the Sūtras.
Jolly,<sup>3</sup> referring doubtless to the expression {%kusīda apratītta,%}<sup>4</sup> ‘a
loan not yet repaid,’ occurring in connexion with {%an-ṛṇa,%} ‘free
from debt,’ appears to be right in taking Kusīda to have the
sense of ‘loan’ in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā. The rate of interest
on loans is not specified before the Sūtra period.<sup>5</sup> {%Cf.%} {@Ṛṇa.@}
<F>1) xiii. 4, 3, 11.</F>
<F>2) vi. 32.</F>

<L>677<pc>1-176<k1>kUcakra<k2>kUcakra
{@Kūcakra@}¦ is a word occurring only once in an obscure verse
of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where Zimmer<sup>2</sup> suggests that it has the sense
of the wheel by which water is raised from a well. Much
more probable is the interpretation of Roth,<sup>3</sup> who understands
it to mean the female breast.

<L>690<pc>1-179<k1>kftvan<k2>kftvan
{@Kṛtvan.@}¦ — In one passage of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> the word Kṛtvan in
the plural is mentioned with the {@Ārjīkas@} and the five peoples.
Pischel<sup>2</sup> thinks that it means a people, and Sāyaṇa expressly
says that the Kṛtvans designate a country.<sup>3</sup> The name in that
case would point to some connexion with the {@Kurus@} or {@Krivis.@}
Hillebrandt,<sup>4</sup> however, thinks that the word is an adjective
which qualifies Ārjīkas and designates this people as magicians,
being applied to them by an opponent. In favour of this view,
he quotes Hiouen Thsang's statement<sup>5</sup> that the neighbouring
kings held the base Kaśmīrians in such scorn as to refuse all
alliance with them, and to give them the name of Ki-li-to, or
Kṛtyas. He suggests that the Ārjīkas settled in Kasmīr in
ancient times already had the same evil reputation as their
successors in later days.
<F>1) ix. 65, 23.</F>
<F>2) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 209.</F>
<F>3) {%Kṛtvāna iti deśābhidhānam.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 136, 137</F>
<F>5) Cunningham, {%Aneient Gevgraphy of%}
{%India,%} 93.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Roth, St. Petersburg Dic-
tionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>692<pc>1-179<k1>kfmi<k2>kfmi
{@Kṛmi,@}¦ ‘worm.’ In the later Saṃhitās,<sup>1</sup> and especially in the
Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> worms play a considerable part. They are
[Page1-180+ 47]
regarded as poisonous, and are spoken of as found in the
mountains, in forests, in waters, in plants, and in the human
body. In accordance with widespread primitive ideas, they
are considered to be the causes of disease in men and animals.
The Atharvaveda contains three hymns<sup>2</sup> as charms directed
against them. The first of these hymns is of a general character,
the second is meant to destroy worms in cattle, and the third is
intended to cure children of worms. When found in men,
worms are said to have their place in the head and ribs,<sup>3</sup> and
to creep into the eyes, nose, and teeth.<sup>4</sup> They are described as
dark brown, but white in the fore part of the body, with black
ears, and as having three heads.<sup>5</sup> They are given many specific
names: {@Alāṇḍu, Ejatka, Kaṣkaṣa, Kīṭa, Kurūru, Nīlaṅgu,@}
{@Yevāṣa, Vaghā, Vṛkṣasarpī, Śaluna, Śavarta, Śipavitnuka,@}
{@Stega.@}
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;
Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 11; Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30; Mantra Brāh-
maṇa, ii. 7; Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, iv. 36;
Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 4, 1, 2; and
{%of.%} Rv. i. 191.</F>
<F>2) ii. 31. 32; v. 23.</F>
<F>2) ii. 31, 32; v. 23.</F>
<F>3) Av. ii. 31, 4.</F>
<F>4) Av. v. 23, 3.</F>
<F>5) Av. v. 23, 4 {%et seq.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 98,
393; Kuhn, {%Zeitschrift für vergleichende%}
