<L>929<pc>1-244<k1>grAma<k2>grAma
{@Grāma.@}¦ — The primitive sense of this word, which occurs
frequently from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards, appears to have been
‘village.’ The Vedic Indians must have dwelt in villages which
were scattered over the country, some close together,<sup>2</sup> some far
apart, and were connected by roads.<sup>3</sup> The village is regularly
contrasted with the forest ({%araṇya%}), and its animals and plants
with those that lived or grew wild in the woods.<sup>4</sup> The villages
contained cattle, horses, and other domestic animals, as well as
men.<sup>5</sup> Grain was also stored in them.<sup>6</sup> In the evening the
cattle regularly returned thither from the forest.<sup>7</sup> The villages
were probably open, though perhaps a fort ({@Pur@}) might on
[Page1-245+ 58]
occasion be built inside.<sup>8</sup> Presumably they consisted of
detached houses with enclosures, but no details are to be found
in Vedic literature. Large villages ({%mahāgrāmāḥ%}) were known.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>The relation of the villagers is difficult to ascertain with
precision. In several passages<sup>10</sup> the word occurs with what
appears to be the derivative sense of ‘body of men.’ This
sense presumably started from the use of the word to denote
the ‘village folk,’ as when {@Śaryāta Mānava@} is said in the
Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup> to have wandered about with his
‘village’ ({%grāmeṇa%}); but, as Zimmer<sup>12</sup> observes, this restricted
sense nowhere appears clearly in the Rigveda,<sup>13</sup> where indeed
the ‘folk’ ({%jana%})<sup>14</sup> of the Bharatas is in one passage<sup>15</sup> called
the ‘horde seeking cows’ ({%gavyan grāmaḥ%}). Zimmer<sup>16</sup> tends to
regard the Grāma as a clan, and as standing midway between
the family and the tribe ({@Viś@}). The Grāma may, however,
perhaps be regarded more correctly<sup>17</sup> as an aggregate of several
families, not necessarily forming a clan, but only part of a clan
({@Viś@}), as is often the case at the present day.<sup>18</sup>
<div n="P"/>Vedic literature tells us very little about the social economy
of the village. There is nothing to show that the community
as such held land. What little evidence there is indicates that
individual tenure of land was known (see {@Urvarā, Kṣetra@}), but
this, in effect though not in law, presumably meant tenure by a
family rather than by an individual person. The expression
[Page1-246+ 58]
‘desirous of a village’ ({%grāma-kāma%}), which occurs frequently in
the later Saṃhitās,<sup>19</sup> points, however, to the practice of the king's
granting to his favourites his royal prerogatives over villages so
far as fiscal matters were concerned. Later<sup>20</sup> the idea developed
that the king was owner of all the land, and parallel with that
idea the view that the holders of such grants were landlords.
But of either idea there is no vestige in Vedic literature beyond
the word {%grāma-kāma,%} which much more probably refers to the
grant of regalia than to the grant of land, as Teutonic parallels
show.<sup>21</sup> Such grants probably tended to depress the position
of the actual cultivators, and to turn them into tenants, but
they can hardly have had this effect to any appreciable extent
in early times.
<div n="P"/>The village does not appear to have been a unit for legal
purposes in early days,<sup>22</sup> and it can hardly be said to have been
a political unit. The village no doubt, as later, included in its
members various menials, besides the cultivating owners, and
also the Brāhmaṇas and Kṣatriyas who might hold interest
in it by royal grant or usage without actually cultivating land,
such as chariot-makers ({@Ratha-kāra@}), carpenters ({@Takṣan@}),
smiths ({@Karmāra@}), and others, but they did not presumably, in
any sense, form part of the brotherhood.<sup>23</sup> All alike were
politically subject to the king, and bound to render him food or
service or other tribute, unless he had transferred his rights to
[Page1-247+ 60]
others of the royal family or household, as was no doubt often
the case, either in whole or part. The king's share in a village
is referred to as early as the Atharvaveda.<sup>24</sup>
<div n="P"/>At the head of the village was the Grāma-ṇī, or ‘leader of
the village,’ who is referred to in the Rigveda,<sup>25</sup> and often in
the later Saṃhitās and in the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>26</sup> The exact
meaning of the title is not certain. By Zimmer<sup>27</sup> the Grāmaṇī
is regarded as having had military functions only, and he is
certainly often connected with the {@Senānī,@} or ‘leader of an
army.’ But there is no reason so to restrict the sense: pre-
sumably the Grāmaṇī was the head of the village both for civil
purposes and for military operations. He is ranked in the
Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>28</sup> as inferior to the {@Sūta,@} or ‘charioteer,’
with whom, however, he is associated<sup>29</sup> as one of the {@Ratnins,@}
the ‘jewels’ of the royal establishment. The post was especially
valuable to a Vaiśya, who, if he attained it, was at the summit
of prosperity ({%gataśrī%}).<sup>30</sup> The Grāmaṇī's connexion with the
royal person seems to point to his having been a nominee of
the king rather than a popularly elected officer. But the post
may have been sometimes hereditary, and sometimes nomi-
nated or elective: there is no decisive evidence available.
The use of the singular presents difficulties: possibly the
Grāmaṇī of the village or city where the royal residence was
situated was specially honoured and influential.<sup>31</sup>

<L>941<pc>1-250<k1>Gfta<k2>Gfta
{@Ghṛta,@}¦ the modern Ghee or ‘clarified butter,’ is repeatedly
mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> both as in ordinary use
and as a customary form of sacrifice. According to a citation
in Sāyaṇa's commentary on the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> the dis-
tinction between Ghṛta and {@Sarpis@} consisted in the latter being
butter fully melted, while the former was butter melted and
hardened ({%ghanī-bhūta%}), but this distinction cannot be pressed.
Because the butter was thrown into the fire, Agni is styled
‘butter-faced’ ({%ghṛta-pratīka%}),<sup>4</sup> ‘butter-backed’ ({%ghṛta-pṛṣṭha%}),<sup>5</sup>
and ‘propitiated with butter’ ({%ghṛta-prasatta%}),<sup>6</sup> and ‘found of
butter’ ({%ghṛta-prī%}).<sup>7</sup> Water was used to purify the butter: the
waters were therefore called ‘butter-cleansing’ ({%ghṛta-pū%}).<sup>8</sup> In
the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa^9 it is said that Ājya, Ghṛta, Āyuta, and
Navanīta pertain to gods, men, Pitṛs, and embryos respectively.
<F>1) i. 134, 6; ii. 10, 4; iv. 10, 6; 58,
5. 7. 9; v. 12, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 22, etc.;
Av. iii. 13, 5, etc.; Śatapatha Brāh-
maṇa, i. 8, 1, 7 (with Dadhi, Mastu,
Amikṣā); ix. 2, 1, 1 (Dadhi, Madhu,
Ghṛta), etc.</F>
<F>3) i. 3 (p. 240, edition Aufrecht).</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 143, 7; iii. 1, 18; v. 11, 1;
x. 21, 7, etc.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 164, 1; v. 4, 3; 37, 1; vii. 2,
4, etc.</F>
<F>6) Rv. v. 15. 1.</F>
<F>7) Av. xii. 1, 20; xviii. 4, 41.</F>
<F>8) i. 3.

<L>943<pc>1-250<k1>GoraANgirasa<k2>GoraANgirasa

while in the Rigveda Sūtras<sup>4</sup> the {%Atharvāṇo vedaḥ%} is connected
[Page1-251+ 44]
with {%bheṣajam%} and the {%Āṅgiraso vedaḥ%} with {%ghoram.%} He is
accordingly a personification of the dark side of the practice
of the Atharvaveda.<sup>5</sup> He is also mentioned in the Aśvamedha
section of the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā.<sup>6</sup>

<L>946<pc>1-251<k1>GozA<k2>GozA
{@Ghoṣā@}¦ is mentioned as a protégée of the Aśvins in two
passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> probably as the recipient of a husband,
who is perhaps referred to in another passage<sup>2</sup> as Arjuna,
though this is not likely. Sāyaṇa finds a reference there to
a skin disease, which is considered in the later tradition of the
Bṛhaddevatā<sup>3</sup> to have been the cause of her remaining unwed,
but this view is not tenable. According to Sāyaṇa, her son,
Suhastya, is alluded to in an obscure verse of the Rigveda;<sup>4</sup>
Oldenberg,<sup>5</sup> however, here sees a reference to Ghoṣā herself,
while Pischel<sup>6</sup> thinks that the form ({%ghoṣe%}) is not a noun at all,
but verbal.

<F>4) i. 120, 5.</F>

invented from x. 41, 3, probably assisted
by the fact that Vadhrimatī was given
a son, {@Hiraṇyahasta,@} by the Aśvins
(Rv. i. 117, 24).</F>

<L>948<pc>1-252<k1>cakra<k2>cakra
{@Cakra,@}¦ the ‘wheel’ of a chariot or wagon, is repeatedly
mentioned from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards, often in a metaphorical
sense. The wheel was fixed on the axle ({@Akṣa@}) when the
chariot was required for use; this required considerable
strength, as is shown by a reference in the Rigveda.<sup>2</sup> The
wheel consisted normally of spokes ({@Ara@}), and a nave ({@Nābhi@}),<sup>3</sup>
in the opening ({@Kha@}) of which the end of the axle ({@Āṇi@}) was
inserted. An indication of the importance attached to the
strength of the wheel is the celebration of the car of the god
Pūṣan as having a wheel that suffers no damage.<sup>4</sup> The usual
number of wheels was two,<sup>5</sup> but in seven passages of the Rigveda<sup>6</sup>
a chariot is called ‘three-wheeled,’ in a few others ‘seven-
wheeled,’<sup>7</sup> while in one of the Atharvaveda<sup>8</sup> it is styled ‘eight-
wheeled.’ Zimmer<sup>9</sup> argues that these epithets do not refer to
real chariots, pointing out that in all the passages where
{%tri-cakra,%} ‘three-wheeled,’ occurs there is a mythical reference.
On the other hand, Weber<sup>10</sup> thinks that there might have been
chariots with three wheels, one being in the centre between the
two occupants. This is not very conclusive; at any rate, the
seven-wheeled and the eight-wheeled chariots can hardly be
regarded as indicating the existence of real vehicles with that
number of wheels.
<div n="P"/>In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup> the potter's wheel ({%kaulāla-%}
{%cakra%}) is referred to.
<F>1) i. 130, 9; 155, 6; 164, 2. 11. 14;
174, 5; iv. 1, 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. xi. 7, 4; xix. 53, 1. 2, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 41, 6.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 54, 3.</F>
<F>5) Rv. viii. 5, 29; Chāndogya Upani-
ṣad, iv. 16, 5; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, i. 4.</F>
<F>6) i. 118, 2; 157, 3; 183, 1; viii. 58, 3;
x. 41, 1; 85, 14 (all of the Aśvins'
chariot); iv. 36, 1 (of a chariot made
by the Ṛbhus, who are three in
number).</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 164, 3, 12; ii. 40, 3.</F>
<F>8) xi. 4, 22.</F>
<F>9) {%Altindisches Leben,%} viii., ix.</F>
<F>10) {%Proceedings of the Berlin Acadcmy,%}
1898, 564, quoting Virchow, {%Zeistchrift%}
{%für Ethnologie,%} 5, 200.</F>
<F>11) xi. 8, 1, 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 247.</F>
<LEND>

<L>949<pc>1-252<k1>cakravAka<k2>cakravAka
{@Cakra-vāka@}¦ is the name, apparently derived from the nature
of its cry, of a species of gander ({%Anas casarca%}), the modern
Chakwā, as it is called in Hindī, or Brahmany duck in English.<sup>1</sup>
It is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>2</sup> and in the list of victims at the
[Page1-253+ 58]
Aśvamedha, or horse sacrifice, in the Yajurveda,<sup>3</sup> while in the
Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup> it already appears as the type of conjugal fidelity,
its characteristic in the classical literature.
<F>1) Criffith, {%Hymns of the Rigveda,%} 1, 309, n. 4.</F>
<F>2) ii. 39, 3.</F>
<F>3) Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 3. 13;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 22. 32;
xxv. 8.</F>
<F>4) xiv. 2, 64.

<L>950<pc>1-253<k1>cakzus<k2>cakzus
{@Cakṣus,@}¦ ‘eye.’ The ‘evil eye’ ({%ghoraṃ cakṣus%}) was well
known in the Atharvaveda, which contains spells to counteract
its influence.<sup>1</sup> As remedies against it are mentioned salve from
Mount {@Trikakubh@}<sup>2</sup> and the {@Jaṅgiḍa@} plant.<sup>3</sup> In the wedding
ceremony the wife is entreated not to have the evil eye ({%aghora-%}
{%cakṣus%}).<sup>4</sup> The structure of the eye, and its division into white
({%śukla%}), dark ({%kṛṣṇa%}), and the pupil ({%kanīn ikā%}) are repeatedly
referred to in the later Brāhmaṇas.<sup>5</sup> The desease {@Alaji@} appears
to have been an affection of the eyes.
<F>1) ii. 7; xix. 45, are so employed in
the ritual.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 9, 6.</F>
<F>3) Av. xix. 35, 3.</F>
<F>4) Pāraskara Gṛhya Sūtra, i. 4; Śāṅkh-
āyana Gṛhya Sūtra, i. 16.</F>
<F>5) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xii. 8, 2,
26; Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 254. 324;
Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 26, 1;
34, 1; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 2, 2;
Aitareya Āraṇyaka, ii. 1, 5, etc. So
the man ({@puru 1@}) in the eye is repeatedly
mentioned: Chāndogya Upaniṣad, i. 7,
5; iv. 15, 1; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,
ii. 3, 5; iv. 2, 2; v. 5, 2. 4, etc.;
Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 27, 2.
The Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 2, 3,
adds the water ({%āpaḥ%}) in the eye, the
upper and the lower lids ({%vartanī%}), and
seven red lines ({%lohinyo rājayaḥ%}).

<L>953<pc>1-254<k1>candra<k2>candra<h>1
1. {@Candra,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Candra-mas,@}<sup>2</sup> are the names of the ‘moon,’ the
latter occurring from the Rigveda onwards, but the former
being first used in this sense by the Atharvaveda. Very little is
said about the moon in Vedic literature, except as identified
with {@Soma,@}<sup>3</sup> both alike being described as waxing and waning.
Reference is, however, made to the regular changes of the
moon, and to its alternation with the sun,<sup>5</sup> to which it, as Soma,
is declared in the Rigveda to be married.<sup>6</sup> Mention is also
made of its disappearance at the time of new moon,<sup>7</sup> and of its
birth from the light of the sun.<sup>8</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> reference
is made to demons eclipsing the moon ({%grahāś cāndramāsāḥ%}).
<div n="P"/>For the phases of the moon, and the month as a measure of
time, see {@Māsa.@} For the moon and its mansions, see {@Nakṣatra.@}
<div n="P"/>^4) Rv. x. 55, 5. {%Cf.%} Av. x. 8, 32.
<F>1) Av. ii. 15, 2; 22, 1; iii. 31, 6, etc.;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28; xxxix. 2;
Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vi. 2, 2, 16, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 105, 1; viii. 82, 8; x. 64, 3;
85, 19; Av. xi. 6, 7; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
hitā, i. 28; xxiii. 10. 59, etc.</F>
<F>3) See Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
pp. 112, 113. The identification is
clearly found in the later parts of the
Rigveda.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 68, 10. {%Cf.%} i. 62, 8; 72, 10.</F>
<F>6) x. 85, 18. 19.</F>
<F>7) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 4, 18;
iv. 6, 7, 12; xi. 1, 6, 19; xiv. 4, 2, 13;
Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 28, 8; perhaps
Rv. x. 138, 4.</F>
<F>8) Rv. ix. 71, 9; 76, 4; 86, 32;

as referring to an eclipse of the moon.

<L>956<pc>1-255<k1>camasa<k2>camasa
{@Camasa@}¦ denotes a ‘drinking vessel,’ usually as employed for
holding {@Soma@} at the sacrifice. It is frequently mentioned from
the Rigveda onwards.<sup>1</sup> It was made of wood ({%vṛkṣa%}),<sup>2</sup> and is
hence called {%dru.%}<sup>3</sup> According to the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>4</sup> it
was made of {@Udumbara@} wood.

<L>957<pc>1-255<k1>camU<k2>camU
{@Camū@}¦ is a term of somewhat doubtful sense occurring
repeatedly in the Rigveda, and connected with the preparation
of Soma. Zimmer<sup>1</sup> considers that in the dual it denotes the
two boards between which, in his opinion, the Soma was
crushed ({%cf.%} {@Adhiṣavaṇa@}). Roth,<sup>2</sup> however, appears to be right
in taking the normal sense to designate a vessel into which the
Soma was poured from the press, and Hillebrandt<sup>3</sup> shows
clearly that when it occurs in the plural<sup>4</sup> it always has this
sense, corresponding to the Graha-pātras of the later ritual,
and that sometimes it is so used in the singular<sup>5</sup> or dual<sup>6</sup> also.
In some cases,<sup>7</sup> however, he recognizes its use as denoting the
mortar in which the Soma was pressed: he may be right here,
as this mode of preparation was probably Indo-Iranian.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>In a derivative sense Camū appears in the Śatapatha Brāh-
maṇa<sup>9</sup> to denote a trough, either of solid stone or consisting of
[Page1-256+ 48]
bricks, used by the Eastern people to protect the body of the
dead from contact with the earth, like modern stone-lined
graves or vaults.
<F>1) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 277, 278.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v. Cf.%}
Grassmann, {%Rigveda,%} 1, 15.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 164-175.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iii. 48, 5; viii. 2, 8; 82, 7. 8;
ix. 20, 6; 62, 16; 63, 2; 92, 2; 93, 3;
97, 21. 37. 46; 99, 6. 8.</F>
<F>5) Rv. ix. 107, 18; x. 91, 15.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ix. 69, 5; 71, 1; 72, 5; 86, 47;
96, 20. 21; 97 2. 48; 103, 4; 107, 10;
108. 10.</F>
<F>7) Singular: Rv. v. 51, 4; viii. 4, 4;
76, 10; ix. 46, 3; x. 24, 1. Dual:
i. 28, 9; iv. 18, 3; vi. 57, 2; ix. 36, 1.</F>
<F>8) Hillebrandt, {%op. cit.,%} 1, 158-164.</F>
<F>9) xiii. 8, 2, 1; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books%}
{%of the East,%} 44, 430, n. 1. In Śāṅkh-

<L>958<pc>1-256<k1>caraka<k2>caraka
{@Caraka@}¦ primarily denotes a ‘wandering student,’ a sense
actually found in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad.<sup>1</sup> More
especially it denotes the members of a school of the Black
Yajurveda, the practices of which are several times referred to
with disapproval in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> In the Vāja-
saneyi Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup> the Caraka teacher ({%Carakācārya%}) is enumerated
among the sacrificial victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human
sacrifice. His dedication there to ill-doing is a clear hint of a
ritual feud.
<F>1) iii. 3, 1.</F>
<F>2) iii. 8, 2, 24 (where the reference is
to Taittirīya Saṃhitā vi. 3, 9, 6; 10, 2,
or some parallel passage); iv. 1, 2, 19;

viii. 1, 3, 7; 7, 1, 14. 24.</F>
<F>3) xxx. 18; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4,
16, 1. Its occurrence in the latter text
renders improbable von Schroeder's
view, {%Indiens Literatur und Cultur,%} 188,
that Caraka included all the Black
Yajurveda schools.

<L>962<pc>1-257<k1>carman<k2>carman
{@Carman,@}¦ denoting ‘hide’ in general, is a common expression
from the Rigveda onwards.<sup>1</sup> The oxhide was turned to many
uses, such as the manufacture of bowstrings, slings, and reins
(see {@Go@}). It was especially often employed to place above the
boards<sup>2</sup> on which the Soma was pressed with the stones.<sup>3</sup> It
was possibly also used for making skin bags.<sup>4</sup> Carmaṇya
denotes leather-work generally in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="P"/>The art of tanning hides ({%mlā%}) was known as early as the
Rigveda,<sup>6</sup> where also the word for ‘tanner’ ({%carmamna%}) occurs.<sup>7</sup>
Details of the process are lacking, but the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup>
refers to stretching out a hide with pegs ({%śañkubhiḥ%}), and the
Rigveda<sup>9</sup> mentions the wetting of the hide.
<F>1) Rv. i. 85, 5; 110, 8; 161, 7;
iii. 60, 2; iv. 13, 4, etc.; Av. v. 8, 13;
x. 9, 2; xi. 1, 9, etc.; Taittirīya Saṃ-
hitā, iii. 1, 7, 1; vi. 1, 9, 2, etc. The
stem {%carma,%} neuter (loc., {%carme%}), is found
in the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 7, 2, 2.</F>
<F>2) Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1,
148-150; 181-183.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 94, 9; 116, 4.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 106, 10, is so taken by
Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben.%} 228, who
compares {%Odyssey,%} x. 19.</F>
<F>5) v. 32. {%Cf. paricarmaṇya,%} Sāṅkhā-
yana Āraṇyaka, ii. 1.</F>
<F>6) viii. 55, 3 (a late hymn).</F>

<L>969<pc>1-259<k1>cAturmAsya<k2>cAturmAsya
{@Cātur-māsya,@}¦ ‘four-monthly,’ denotes the festival of the
Vedic ritual held at the beginning of the three seasons of four
months each, into which the Vedic year was artificially divided.<sup>1</sup>
It is clear that the sacrifices commenced with the beginning
of each season,<sup>2</sup> and it is certain that the first of them, the
Vaiśvadeva, coincided with the Phālgunī full moon,<sup>3</sup> the second,
the Varuṇa-praghāsas, with the Āṣāḍhī full moon,<sup>4</sup> and the
third, the Sāka-medha, with the Kārttikī full moon.<sup>5</sup> There
were, however, two alternative datings: the festivals could also
be held in the Caitrī, the Śrāvaṇī, and Āgrahāyaṇī (Mārgaśīrṣī)
full moons,<sup>6</sup> or in the Vaiśākhī, Bhādrapadī, and Pauṣī full
moons.<sup>7</sup> Neither of the later datings is found in a Brāhmaṇa
text, but each may well have been known early, since the
Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>8</sup> and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> both
recognize the full moon in the month Caitra as an alternative
to the full moon in the month Phālguna, for the beginning of
the year.
<div n="P"/>Jacobi considers that the commencement of the year with the
full moon in the asterism Phalgunī, which is supported by other
evidence,<sup>10</sup> indicates that the year at one time began with the winter
solstice with the moon in Phalgunī, corresponding to the summer
solstice when the sun was in Phalgunī. These astronomical
conditions, he believes, existed in the time of the Rigveda,<sup>11</sup>
and prevailed in the fourth millennium B.C. The alternative
[Page1-260+ 51]
dates would then indicate periods when the winter solstice
coincided with the Caitrī or the Vaiśākhī full moon. But
Oldenberg<sup>12</sup> and Thibaut<sup>13</sup> seem clearly right in holding that
the coincidence of Phālgunī with the beginning of spring,<sup>14</sup>
which is certain, is fatal to this view, and that there is no
difficulty in regarding this date as consistent with the date of
the winter solstice in the new moon of Māgha, which is given
by the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa,<sup>15</sup> and which forms the basis of
the calculations of the Jyotiṣa.<sup>16</sup> The full moon in Phālguna
would be placed about one month and a half after the winter
solstice, or, say, in the first week of February, which date,
according to Thibaut, may reasonably be deemed to mark the
beginning of a new season in India about 800 B.C. At the
same time it must be remembered that the date was necessarily
artificial, inasmuch as the year was divided into three seasons,
each of four months, and the Indian year does not in fact
consist of three equal seasons. The variations of the other
datings would then not be unnatural if any school wished to
defer its spring festival, the Vaiśvadeva, to the time when
spring had really manifested itself. See also {@Saṃvatsara.@}
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 6, 5, 3;
Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 9, 5; ii. 2,
2, 2; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 3, 36;
ii. 5, 2, 48; 6, 4, 1; v. 2, 3, 10; xiii. 2,
5, 2; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, v. 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 3, 36
({%cf.%} xiv. 1, 1, 28); Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa,
v. 1.</F>
<F>3) In the month Phālguna, or Feb-
ruary-March.</F>
<F>4) In the month Āṣāḍhā, or June-
July.</F>
<F>5) That is, in the month Kārttika,
when the moon is in the asterism
Kṛttikā: Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 3,
13; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, v. 1, etc.</F>
<F>6) Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, iii. 13, 1;
14, 1. 2; 15, 1. These are the full-
moon days in the months Caitra
(March-April), Śrāvaṇa (July-August),
and Mārgaśīṛṣa (November-December)
respectively.</F>
<F>7) Deva's Paddhati on Kātyāyana
Srauta Sūtra, pp. 430, 450, 497. These
are the full-moon days in the months
Vaiśākha (April-May), Bhādrapada
(August-September), and Pauṣa (De-
cember-January) respectively.</F>
<F>8) vii. 4, 8, 1. 2.</F>
<F>9) v. 9, 8. 11.</F>
<F>10) {%Indian Antiquary,%} 23, 156 {%et seq.;%}
{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
{%Gesellschaft,%} 49, 223 {%et seq.;%} 50, 72-81.</F>
<F>11) vii. 103, 9; x. 85, 13. {%Cf. Festgruss%}
{%an Rudolf von Roth,%} 68 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>12) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 48, 630 {%et seq.;%}
49, 475, 476; 50, 453-457.</F>
<F>13) {%Indian Antiquary,%} 24, 86 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>14) See Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 2,
6, 8; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 4, 1,
2-4. So the Phālgunī full moon is
called ‘the mouth of the seasons
({%ṛtūnāṃ mukham%}) — {%e.g.,%} Pañcaviṃśa
Brāhmaṇa, xxi. 15, 2; Kāṭhaka Saṃ-
hitā, viii. 1; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6,
9; and the first season is always spring:
Śatapaṭha Brāhmaṇa, i. 5, 3, 8-14;
ii. 1, 3, 1; vii. 2, 4, 26; xi. 2, 7, 32;
xii. 8, 2, 34; xiii. 5, 4, 28; Taittirīya

<L>974<pc>1-261<k1>citra<k2>citra
{@Citra@}¦ is the name of several persons. ({%a%}) The Rigveda<sup>1</sup> con-
tains a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) of a prince Citra. The
later legend<sup>2</sup> attributes this panegyric to Sobhari, and describes
Citra as king of the rats.
<div n="P"/>({%b%}) Citra Gāṅgyāyani or Gārgyāyaṃ is mentioned in the
Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad<sup>1</sup> as a contemporary of {@Āruṇi@} and {@Śvetaketu.@}
<div n="P"/>({%c%}) Citra Gauśrāyaṇi is mentioned as a teacher in the Kauṣī-
taki Brāhmaṇa.<sup>1</sup>
<F>1) viii. 21, 18.</F>
<F>2) Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 58 {%et. seq.,%} with Macdonell's notes.</F>

<L>975<pc>1-261<k1>citraraTa<k2>citraraTa
{@Citra-ratha@}¦ (‘having a brilliant car’) is the name of two
persons.
<div n="P"/>({%a%}) It designates an Āryan prince, who, with Arṇa, was
defeated by Indra for the Turvaśa-Yadus on the {@Sarayu@} (per-
haps the modern Sarju in Oudh), according to the Rigveda (iv.
30, 18). The locality would accord with the close connexion
of Turvaśa and {@Krivi@} or {@Pañcāla.@}
[Page1-262+ 46]
<div n="P"/>({%b%}) Citraratha is also the name of a king for whom the
{@Kāpeyas@} performed a special kind of sacrifice ({%dvirātra%}), with
the result, according to the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> that in the
Caitrarathi family only one member was a Kṣatra-pati, the rest
dependents. Apparently this must mean that the Caitrarathis
were distinguished from other families of princes by the fact
that the chief of the clan received a markedly higher position
than in most cases, in which probably the heads of the family
were rather an oligarchy than a monarch and his dependents.
See {@Rājan.@}
<F>1) xx. 12, 5. {%Cf.%} Hopkins. {%Transactions%}
{%of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}
{%Sciences,%} 15, 52, 53; Weber, {%Indische%}
{%Studien,%} 1, 32; {%Indian Literature,%} 68, n.</F>
<LEND>

{@Citrā.@}¦ See {@Nakṣatra.@}

<L>978<pc>1-262<k1>cIpudru<k2>cIpudru
{@Cīpudru@}¦ designates some substance mentioned in a hymn of
the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> as of use in healing. The commentator

the ritual application of this hymn.<sup>3</sup> Whitney<sup>4</sup> suggests that
the form of the word should be Cīpuḍu.

<L>979<pc>1-262<k1>cumuri<k2>cumuri
{@Cumuri@}¦ is the name of an enemy of {@Dabhīti,@} for whom he,
along with his friend {@Dhuni,@} is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as
having been defeated by Indra. Elsewhere<sup>2</sup> the two are spoken
of, along with {@Śambara, Pipru,@} and Śuṣṇa, as having been
crushed by Indra, who destroyed their castles. It is impossible
to say whether real men or demons are meant, but in favour of
[Page1-263+ 40]
a man being denoted by Cumuri is the form of the name, which
seems not to be Āryan.<sup>3</sup>

<L>993<pc>1-264<k1>cyavana<k2>cyavana
{@Cyavana,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Cyavāna,@}<sup>2</sup> are variant forms of the name of an
ancient Ṛṣi, or seer. The Rigveda<sup>3</sup> represents him as an old
decrepit man, to whom the Aśvins restored youth and strength,
making him acceptable to his wife, and a husband of maidens.
[Page1-265+ 49]
The legend is given in another form in the Śatapatha Brāh-
maṇa,<sup>4</sup> where Cyavana is described as wedding Sukanyā,
the daughter of {@Śaryāta.@} He is there called a Bhṛgu or
Āṅgirasa, and is represented as having been rejuvenated by
immersion in a pond — the first occurrence of a motive, later
very common in Oriental literature. Another legend about
Cyavāna is apparently alluded to in an obscure hymn of the
Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> where he seems to be opposed to the {@Paktha@} prince
{@Tūrvayāṇa,@} an Indra worshipper, while Cyavāna seems to
have been specially connected with the Aśvins. This explana-
tion of the hymn, suggested by Pischel,<sup>6</sup> is corroborated by the
Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>7</sup> which relates that {@Vidanvant,@} another
son of Bhṛgu, supported Cyavana against Indra, who was
angry with him for sacrificing to the Aśvins; it is also note-
worthy that the Aśvins appear in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> as
obtaining a share in the sacrifice on the suggestion of Sukanyā.
But a reconciliation of Indra and Cyavana must have taken
place, because the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> relates the inauguration
of {@Śāryāta@} by Cyavana with the great Indra consecration
({%aindreṇa mahābhiṣekeṇa%}). In the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇā<sup>10</sup>
Cyavana is mentioned as a seer of Sāmans or Chants.
<F>1) This form is found even in the
Nirukta (iv. 19), regularly in all
the Vedic texts other than the Rigveda,
and in the Epic.</F>
<F>2) The Rv. has this form through-
out.</F>
<F>3) i. 116, 10; 117, 13; 118, 6; v. 74, 5;
vii. 68, 6; 71, 5; x. 39, 4.</F>
<F>4) iv. 1, 5, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) x. 61, 1-3.</F>
<F>6) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 71-77; accepted
by Griffith, {%Hymns of the Rigveda,%} 2,
465.</F>
<F>7) iii. 121-128; {%Journal of the American%}
{%Oriental Society,%} 11, cxlvi; 26, 43 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>8) iv. 1, 5, 13 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>9) viii. 21, 4; Pischel, {%op. cit.,%} 1, 75.</F>
<F>10) xiii. 5, 12; xix. 3, 6; xiv. 6, 10;
xi. 8, 11.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 243,
250-254; Ludwig, Translation of the

<L>995<pc>1-265<k1>Cadis<k2>Cadis

[Page1-266+ 49]

Aquarii may be meant, since the next verse mentions {@Vicṛtau,@}
which is the constellation <lang n="greek">λ</lang> and <lang n="greek">ν</lang> Scorpionis, and is not far
from Aquarius. See also {@Chardis.@}

<L>996<pc>1-266<k1>Candas<k2>Candas<h>1
1. {@Chandas@}¦ in the Rigveda usually denotes a ‘song of
praise’ or ‘hymn.’<sup>1</sup> The original sense of the word, as derived
from the verb {%chand,%} ‘to please,’ was probably ‘attractive
spell,’ ‘magic hymn,’<sup>2</sup> which prevailed on the gods. In a very
late hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>3</sup> as well as in one of the Atharvaveda,<sup>4</sup>
the word is mentioned in the plural ({%chandāṃsi%}), beside Ṛc
({%ṛcaḥ%}), Sāman ({%sāmāni%}), and Yajus, and seems to retain its
original meaning, not improbably with reference to the magical
subject-matter of the Atharvaveda. From denoting a (metrical)
hymn it comes to mean ‘metre’ in a very late verse of the
Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> in which the ‘Gāyatrī, the Triṣṭubh, and all ({%sarvā%})
the metres ({%chandāṃsi%}) are mentioned. In the later Saṃhitās
three<sup>6</sup> or seven<sup>7</sup> metres are enumerated, and in the Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> eight. By the time of the Rigveda Prātiśākhya<sup>9</sup>
the metres were subjected to a detailed examination, though
much earlier references are found to the number of syllables in
the several metres.<sup>10</sup> Later the word definitely denotes a Vedic
text generally, as in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>11</sup>
<F>1) Rv. x. 85, 8 (an obscure verse);
114, 5; Av. iv. 34, 1; v. 26, 5;
vi. 124, 1; xi. 7, 8, etc.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Roth in St. Petersburg Dic-
tionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 90, 9.</F>
<F>4) Av. xi. 7, 24.</F>
<F>5) x. 14, 16.</F>
<F>6) Av. xviii. 1, 17; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
hitā, i. 27, etc.</F>
<F>7) Av. viii. 9, 17. 19, etc.</F>
<F>8) viii. 3, 3, 6, etc.</F>
<F>9) xvi. 1 {%et seq. Cf.%} Max Müller,
{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, xcv. {%et%}
{%seq.%}</F>
<F>10) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xiv. 4; Jaitti-
rīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 2, 7.</F>
<F>11) xi. 5, 7, 3. So Gobhila Gṛhya
Sūtra, iii. 3, 4. 15, etc.</F>
<LEND>

<L>997<pc>1-267<k1>Candas<k2>Candas<h>2

and must mean ‘having a large roof.’ Bloomfield<sup>2</sup> accepts the

<L>998<pc>1-267<k1>Candoga<k2>Candoga
{@Chando-ga,@}¦ ‘metre-singing,’ is the term applied to reciters of

to their order in the Chandaārcika of the Sāmaveda. It is
only found in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> and often in the
Sūtras.<sup>2</sup>

<L>999<pc>1-267<k1>Cardis<k2>Cardis
{@Chardis@}¦ occurs often in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and occasionally later,<sup>2</sup>
denoting a secure dwelling-place. The word appears to be
incorrectly written, because the metre shows that the first
syllable is always short. Roth<sup>3</sup> accordingly suggested that
{@Chadis@} should be read instead. But Chadis means ‘roof,’ while
Chardis never has that sense. Bartholomae<sup>4</sup> is therefore prob-
ably right in suggesting some other form, such as Chaḍis.
<F>1) i. 48, 15; 114, 5; vi. 15, 3; 46, 9.
12, etc.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 9, 2;
3, 6, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 19;
xiv. 12.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.;%}
Oldenberg, {%Prolegomena,%} 477.</F>
<F>4) {%Studien,%} 1, 47; 2, 58. {%Cf.%} Wacker-
nagel, {%Altindische Grammatik,%} 1, xii.,
n. 2; Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deu-%}
{%tschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 55,
312.</F>

<L>1002<pc>1-268<k1>jaNgiqa<k2>jaNgiqa
{@Jaṅgiḍa@}¦ is the name of a healing plant mentioned in the
hymns of the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> It was used as an amulet against
the diseases, or symptoms of disease, {@Takman, Balāsa,@}
{@Āśarīka, Viśarīka, Pṛṣṭyāmaya,@}<sup>2</sup> fevers and rheumatic pains,
{@Viṣkandha@} and {@Saṃskandha,@}<sup>3</sup> {@Jambha,@} and so on. But it is
also regarded as a specific against all diseases, and as the best
of healing powers.<sup>4</sup> It is said to be produced from the juices
({%rasa%}) of ploughing ({%kṛṣi%}),<sup>5</sup> but this need only mean that it grew
in cultivated land, not that it was itself cultivated. What plant
the name designates is quite uncertain, for it disappears in the
later literature. Caland<sup>6</sup> takes it in the Kauśika Sūtra to be
the {%Terminalia arjuneya.%}
<F>1) ii. 4; xix. 34. 35.</F>
<F>2) Av. xix. 34, 10.</F>
<F>3) Av. ii. 4, 1; xix. 34, 1. 5.</F>
<F>4) Av. xix. 34, 9. 7.</F>
<F>5) Av. ii. 4, 5.</F>
<F>6) {%Altindisches Zauberritual,%} 15, render-
ing Kauśika Sūtra, viii. 15.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
{%vaveda,%} 433; Whitney, Translation of
the Atharvaveda, 42; Weber, {%Indische%}
{%Studien,%} 13, 141; Grohmann, {%ibid.,%} 9,
417; Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 65,
66, 390.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1004<pc>1-269<k1>jana<k2>jana
{@Jana,@}¦ besides meaning ‘man’ as an individual, with a
tendency to the collective sense, commonly denotes a ‘people’
or ‘tribe’ in the Rigveda and later. Thus, the ‘five tribes’
({@Panca Janāḥ@} or {@Janāsaḥ@}) are frequently referred to, and in
one hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> the ‘people of Yadu’ ({%yādva jana%})
and the {@Yadus@} ({%yādvāḥ%}) are synonymous. Again, the king
({%rājan%}) is described as ‘protector ({%gopā%}) of the people ({%janasya%}),’<sup>2</sup>
and there are other references to king and Jana.<sup>3</sup> The people
of the {@Bharatas@} ({%bhārata jana%}) is also mentioned;<sup>4</sup> there is no
ground to assume with Hopkins<sup>5</sup> that Jana in this case means
a clan or horde ({@Grāma@}), as distinguished from a people.
<div n="P"/>It is difficult to say exactly how a people was divided.
Zimmer<sup>6</sup> argues from a passage in the Rigveda<sup>7</sup> that a people
was divided into cantons ({@Viś@}), cantons into joint families or
clans, or village communities ({@Grāma, Vṛjana@}), and these again
into single families. He thinks that the four divisions are
reflected in the passage in question. by Jana, Viś, Janman, and
Putrāḥ, or sons, and argues that each village community was
originally founded on relationship. But it is very doubtful
whether this precise division of the people can be pressed. The
division of the Jana into several Viś may be regarded as
probable, for it is supported by the evidence of another passage
of the Rigveda,<sup>8</sup> which mentions the Viś as a unit of the fighting
men, and thus shows that, as in Homeric times and in ancient
Germany, relationship was deemed a good principle of military
arrangement. But the subdivision of the Viś into several
Grāmas is very doubtful. Zimmer<sup>9</sup> admits that neither Grāma<sup>10</sup>
[Page1-270+ 47]
nor {@Vṛjana@}<sup>11</sup> has the special sense of a subdivision of the Viś
when used for war, for both words only denote generally an
armed host. He finds other designations of the village host in
{@Vrā@}<sup>12</sup> and in {@Vrāja,@}<sup>13</sup> but it is sufficient to say that the former
passage is of extremely doubtful import,<sup>14</sup> and that the latter
has no reference to war at all. It is therefore impossible to state
in what exact relation the Grāma in Vedic times stood to the
Viś or to the family (Kula or Gotra). The confusion is increased
by the vagueness of the sense of both Grāma and Viś. If the
latter be regarded as a local division, then no doubt the Grāma
must have been a part of a district; but if a Viś was a unit of
relationship, then a Grāma may have contained families of
different Viśes, or may have sometimes coincided with a
Viś, or have contained only a part of a Viś. But in any
case the original state of affairs must have been greatly
modified by the rise of the system of caste, and the substitu-
tion of a hierarchical for a political point of view. The
elements of the people were represented by the family — either
as an individual family inhabiting one home ({@Kula@}), and con-
sisting often, no doubt, of a joint family of brothers, or as a
patriarchal family of sons who still lived with their father — and
by the clan, the later {@Gotra,@} which included all those who
claimed a common ancestor. The Gotra may be regarded as
roughly corresponding to the Latin {%gens%} and the Greek <lang n="greek">γένος</lang>,
and possibly the Viś may be the equivalent of the {%curia%} and
<lang n="greek">φρήτρη</lang>, and the Jana of the {%tribus%} and <lang n="greek">φῦλον</lang> or <lang n="greek">φῦλη</lang>.<sup>15</sup> These
three divisions may also be seen in the Viś, Zantu, and Daqyu
of the Iranian world, where the use of Viś suggests that in the
Indian Viś a relationship based on blood rather than locality is
meant — and perhaps even in the {%vicus, pagus,%} and {%civitas%} of the
old German polity described in the Germania<sup>16</sup> of Tacitus.
The family in some form appears as the third element of the
Jana in a passage of the Rigveda,<sup>17</sup> where the house ({%gṛha%}) is
[Page1-271+ 44]
contrasted with the Jana and the Viś. Possibly, too, another
passage<sup>18</sup> contrasts the {%adhvara,%} or family sacrifice, with that of
the Jana or Viś, rather than, as Zimmer<sup>19</sup> thinks, the village
with the two larger units. But it is significant of the particu-
larism of the Vedic Indians that while the king maintained a
fire which might be regarded as the sacred fire of the tribe,
there is no sure trace<sup>20</sup> of any intermediate cult between that of
the king and that of the individual householder. The real
elements in the state are the Gotra and the Jana, just as
ultimately the {%gens%} and {%tribus,%} the <lang n="greek">γένος</lang> and <lang n="greek">φῦλον</lang> are alone
important. It may be that Viś sometimes represents in the
older texts what later was known as the Gotra. See {@Viś.@}
<div n="P"/>This appears clearly when the constitution of society in the
Brāhmaṇa period is considered. The tribe or people still exists,
and is presupposed, but the division into Viś disappears. The
real division is now the separate castes ({@Varṇa@}), but the
numerous sections into which each of them is divided appear to
be based in part on the ancient Gotra.

<L>1005<pc>1-271<k1>janaSArkarakzya<k2>janaSArkarakzya<h>2
2. {@Jana Śārkarakṣya@}¦ (‘descendant of {@Śarkarakṣa@}’) is
mentioned as a teacher in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa (x. 6, 1, 1
{%et seq.%}) and the Chāndogya Upaniṣad (v. 11, 1; 15, 1). He was
a contemporary of {@Aśvapati Kaikeya,@} and of {@Aruṇa Aupaveśi@}
and his son {@Uddālaka Āruṇi.@}
<LEND>

<L>1006<pc>1-271<k1>janaka<k2>janaka
{@Janaka,@}¦ king of Videha, plays a considerable part in the
Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>2</sup>
as well as in the Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> and the Kauṣītaki
Upaniṣad.<sup>4</sup> He was a contemporary of {@Yājñavalkya Vāja-@}
[Page1-272+ 50]
{@saneya,@}<sup>5</sup> of {@Śvetaketu Āruṇeya,@} and of other sages.<sup>6</sup> He had
become famous for his generosity and his interest in the dis-
cussion of the nature of Brahman, as ultimate basis of reality,
in the life-time of {@Ajātaśatru@} of Kāśi.<sup>7</sup> It is significant that
he maintained a close intercourse with the Brahmins of the
Kuru-Pañcālas, such as Yājñavalkya and Śvetaketu; for this
indicates that the home of the philosophy of the Upaniṣads
was in the Kuru-Pañcāla country rather than in the east.
There is a statement in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> that he
became a Brahmin ({%brahmā%}). This does not, however, signify
a change of caste, but merely that in knowledge he became
a Brahmin (see {@Kṣatriya@}). Janaka is occasionally mentioned
in later texts: in the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> he has already
become quite mythical; in the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>10</sup>
a {%sapta-rātra%} or seven nights' rite is ascribed to him.
<div n="P"/>It is natural to attempt to date Janaka by his being a con-
temporary of Ajātaśatru, and by identifying the latter with the
Ajātasattu of the Pāli texts:<sup>11</sup> this would make the end of the
sixth century B.C. the approximate date of Janaka.<sup>12</sup> But it is
very doubtful whether this identification can be supported:
Ajātaśatru was king of Kāśi, whereas Ajātasattu was king of
Magadha, and his only connexion with Kāśi was through his
marriage with the daughter of Pasenadi of Kosala.<sup>13</sup> More-
over, the acceptance of this chronology would be difficult to
reconcile with the history of the development of thought; for
it would make the rise of Buddhism contemporaneous with the
Upaniṣads, whereas it is reasonably certain that the older
Upaniṣads preceded Buddhism.<sup>14</sup> Nor do the Vedic texts know
anything of Bimbisāra or Pasenadi, or any of the other princes
famed in Buddhist records.
[Page1-273+ 54]
<div n="P"/>The identification<sup>15</sup> of Janaka of Videha and the father of
Sītā is less open to objection, but it cannot be proved, and is
somewhat doubtful. In the Sūtras Janaka appears as an
ancient king who knew of a time when wifely honour was less
respected than later.<sup>16</sup>

<L>1009<pc>1-273<k1>janamejaya<k2>janamejaya<h>1
1. {@Janam-ejaya@}¦ (‘man-impelling’) is the name of a king,
a {@Pārikṣita,@}<sup>1</sup> famous towards the end of the Brāhmaṇa period.
He is mentioned in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> as owning
horses which when wearied were refreshed with sweet drinks,
and as a performer of the Aśvamedha, or horse sacrifice.<sup>3</sup> His
capital, according to a Gāthā quoted in the Śatapatha<sup>4</sup> and
the Aitareya Brāhmaṇas,<sup>5</sup> was {@Āsandīvant.@} His brothers
{@Ugrasena, Bhīmasena,@} and {@Śrutasena@} are mentioned as having
[Page1-274+ 49]
by the horse sacrifice purified themselves from sin. The priest
who performed the sacrifice for him was {@Indrota Daivāpi@}
{@Śaunaka.@}<sup>6</sup> On the other hand the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>7</sup> which
also mentions his Aśvamedha, names {@Tura Kāvaṣeya@} as his
priest. It also contains an obscure tale stating that at one
sacrifice of his he did not employ the {@Kaśyapas,@} but the
{@Bhūtavīras,@} being, however, induced by the {@Asitamṛgas@} to
have recourse to the Kaśyapas again.<sup>8</sup> He was a {@Kuru@} prince;
see {@Parikṣit.@} The Gopatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> tells an absurd tale
about him, evidently as of an ancient hero.

<L>1012<pc>1-274<k1>jani<k2>jani
{@Jani, Janī.@}¦ — These words appear to denote ‘wife,’ usually
applying to her in relation to her husband ({@Pati@}). The more
general sense of ‘woman’ is doubtful; for when Uṣas is called
a fair {@Janī,@}<sup>1</sup> ‘wife’ may be meant, and the other passage<sup>2</sup> cited
for this sense by Delbrück,<sup>3</sup> which refers to the begetting of
children, seems to demand the sense of ‘wives.’ Since the
words usually appear in the plural,<sup>4</sup> it is possible they may
[Page1-275+ 45]
refer not to ‘wives’ proper, but to Hetairai. This is, how-
ever, rendered unlikely because the Rigveda<sup>5</sup> uses the phrase
{%patyur janitvam,%} denoting ‘wifehood to a husband,’ as well
as the expression {%janayo na patnīḥ,%}<sup>6</sup> ‘like wives (who are)
mistresses,’<sup>7</sup> besides containing passages in which the word has
reference to marriage.<sup>8</sup> The singular occurs in the dialogue of
Yama and Yamī.<sup>9</sup>

xii. 35; xx. 40. 43, etc. {%Cf.%} Rv. x. 43, 1.
In x. 110, 5, the phrase is {%patibhyo na%}
{%janayaḥ,%} where both plurals may be

<L>1019<pc>1-276<k1>jamadagni<k2>jamadagni
{@Jamad-agni@}¦ is one of the somewhat mythical sages of the
Rigveda, where he is frequently mentioned. In some passages<sup>1</sup>
his name occurs in such a way as to indicate that he is the
author of the hymn; once<sup>2</sup> he is thus associated with {@Viśvā-@}
{@mitra.@} In other passages<sup>3</sup> he is merely referred to, and the
Jamadagnis are mentioned once.<sup>4</sup> In the Atharvaveda,<sup>5</sup> as well
as the Yajurveda Saṃhitās<sup>6</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>7</sup> he is quite a
frequent figure. Here he appears as a friend of Viśvāmitra<sup>8</sup>
and a rival of {@Vasiṣṭha.@}<sup>9</sup> He owed his prosperity to his {%catū-%}
{%rātra,%} or ‘four-night’ ritual, with which his family were also
very successful.<sup>10</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>11</sup> Jamadagni is connected
with {@Atri@} and {@Kaṇva,@} as well as {@Asita@} and {@Vitahavya.@} He was
Adhvaryu priest at the proposed sacrifice of {@Śunaḥśepa.@}<sup>12</sup>

<L>1020<pc>1-276<k1>jamBa<k2>jamBa
{@Jambha@}¦ occurs twice in the Atharvaveda as the name of a
disease or a demon of disease. In one passage<sup>1</sup> it is said to be
cured by the {@Jaṅgiḍa@} plant; in the other<sup>2</sup> it is described as
{%samhanuḥ,%} ‘bringing the jaws together.’ Weber<sup>3</sup> argued from
[Page1-277+ 44]
the Kauśika Sūtra<sup>4</sup> that it was a child's ailment, especially
‘teething.’ Bloomfield<sup>5</sup> considers it to mean ‘convulsions,’
while Caland<sup>6</sup> thinks it denotes ‘tetanus.’ Whitney<sup>7</sup> decides
for ‘lockjaw’ or ‘convulsions.’
<F>1) ii. 4, 2.</F>
<F>2) viii. 1, 16.</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Studien,%} 13, 142.</F>
<F>4) xxxii. 1.</F>
<F>5) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 283.</F>
<F>6) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen%}
{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 53, 224; {%Altin-%}
{%disches Zauberritual,%} 103.</F>
<F>7) Translation of the Atharvaveda,
42.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 392.</F>

<L>1024<pc>1-277<k1>jarAboDa<k2>jarAboDa
{@Jarā-bodha,@}¦ a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is

a seer. Roth<sup>3</sup> regards it as a mere adjective meaning ‘attending
to the invocation,’ which is perhaps the most probable inter-

proper name, the literal sense being ‘alert in old age.’

<L>1025<pc>1-278<k1>jarAyu<k2>jarAyu
{@Jarāyu@}¦ is found once in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> in the sense of
a ‘serpent's skin.’ Usually<sup>2</sup> it denotes the outer covering
(chorion) of the embryo, as opposed to the {%ulva,%} the inner
covering (amnion).
<div n="P"/>Living things are occasionally classified according to their
mode of origin. In the Chāndogya Upaniṣad<sup>3</sup> they are divided
into {%(a) āṇḍa-ja,%} ‘egg-born’; {%(b) jīva-ja,%} ‘born alive,’ or born
from the womb; {%(c) udbhij-ja,%} ‘propagated by sprouts.’ In the
Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>4</sup> the division is fourfold: {%(a) āṇḍa-ja;%}
{%(b) jāru-ja,%} that is, {%jarāyu-ja%} (found in the Atharvaveda,<sup>5</sup> and
needlessly read here by Böhtlingk);<sup>6</sup> {%(c) udbhij-ja;%} and {%(d)%}
{%svcda-ja,%} ‘sweat-born,’ explained as ‘insects.’
<F>1) i. 27, 1.</F>
<F>2) Rv. v. 78, 8; Av. i. 11, 4; vi. 49, 1;
ix. 4, 4; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 6, 3;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 8; xix. 76;
Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 3; Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa, iii. 2, 1, 11, etc; Chān-
dogya Upanisad, iii. 10. 2, etc.</F>
<F>3) vi. 3, 1.</F>
<F>4) ii. 6.</F>
<F>5) i. 12, 1.</F>
<F>6) See {%jāru%} in Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa,
ii. 430, 6.

ally later,<sup>2</sup> for a singer of hymns of praise or worshipper.

<L>1027<pc>1-278<k1>jaritf<k2>jaritf<h>2
2. {@Jaritṛ.@}¦ According to Sieg,<sup>1</sup> mention is made in one
hymn of the Rigveda<sup>2</sup> of Jaritṛ, one of the Śārṅgas. That
hymn he seeks to bring into connexion with the epic<sup>3</sup> tradition
[Page1-279+ 35]
of the Ṛṣi Mandapāla, who wedded Jaritā, a female Śārṅga
bird — apparently a hen sparrow ({%caṭakā%}) — and had four sons.
These being abandoned by him and exposed to the danger of
being consumed by a forest fire, prayed to Agni with the hymn
Rigveda x. 142. This interpretation is very doubtful, though
Sāyaṇa<sup>4</sup> appears to have adopted it.
<F>1) {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 44 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) x. 142.</F>
<F>3) Mahābhārata, i. 222, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) On Rv. x. 142, 7. 8.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1029<pc>1-279<k1>jartila<k2>jartila
{@Jartila,@}¦ ‘wild sesamum,’ is mentioned in the Taittirīya
Saṃhitā (v. 4, 3, 2) as an unsuitable sacrificial offering. In
the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa (ix. 1, 1, 3) sesamum seeds are
regarded as combining the qualities of cultivation (viz.,
edibility) with those of wild growth (because they are produced
on unploughed land).

<L>1035<pc>1-280<k1>jahnu<k2>jahnu
{@Jahnu@}¦ occurs only in the plural in the legend of {@Śunaḥśepa,@}
who is said to have obtained, as Devarāta, both the lordship
of the Jahnus and the divine lore of the Gāthins.<sup>1</sup> A {@Jāhnava,@}
or descendant of Jahnu, was, according to the Pañcaviṃśa
[Page1-281+ 45]
Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> {@Viśvāmitra,@} who is said, by means of a certain
{%catū-rātra%} or ‘four-night’ ritual, to have secured the kingdom
for the Jahnus in their conflict with the {@Vṛcīvants.@} He is
here described as a king. Again, in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup>
Viśvāmitra is addressed as a {%rāja-putra,%} ‘prince,’ and {%Bharata-%}
{%rṣabha,%} ‘bull of the Bharatas.’ It is therefore clear that the
Brāhmaṇas, though not the Saṃhitās, saw in him at once a
priest and a prince by origin, though there is no trace whatever
of their seeing in him a prince who won Brahmanhood as in
the version of the later texts.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>A Jahnāvī is mentioned twice in the Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> being either
the wife of Jahnu, or, as Sāyaṇa thinks, the race of Jahnu.
The family must clearly once have been a great one, later
merged in the Bharatas.
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 18 ({%Jah-%}
{%nūnām cādhipatye daive vede ca Gāthinām%});
Asvalāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xii. 14;
Sāṅkhāyana Srauta Sūtra, xv. 27 (p. 195,
1. 21, ed. Hillebrandt, where the read-
ing is different and the sense altered:
{%Jahnūnāṃ cādhitasthire daive vede ca%}
{%Gāthinaḥ.%} The two {%ca%}'s cannot be
justified, and the text must be in-
correct).</F>
<F>2) xxi. 12. {%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%Transactions%}
{%of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}
{%Sciences,%} 15, 54, who correctly explains
the passage which Sāyaṇa misunder-
stands.</F>
<F>3) vii. 17, 6, 7.</F>
<F>4) Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1, 337 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) i. 116, 19; iii. 58, 6. {%Cf.%} Ludwig,
Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 153.</F>

<L>1038<pc>1-281<k1>jAti<k2>jAti
{@Jāti,@}¦ which in the Pāli<sup>1</sup> texts is the word denoting ‘caste,’
does not occur at all in the early Vedic literature; when it is
found, as in the Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra,<sup>2</sup> it has only the
sense of ‘family’ (for which {%cf.%} {@Kula, Gotra,@} and {@Viś@}). For
the influence of the family system on the growth of caste, see
{@Varṇa.@} To assume that it was the basis of caste, as does
[Page1-282+ 48]
Senart,<sup>3</sup> is difficult in face of the late appearance of words for
family and of stress on family.<sup>4</sup>

Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>2</sup> the name appears instead as {@Kratujit@}
{@Jānaki.@} Jānaka is also, according to some manuscripts of the
Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>3</sup> the patronymic of {@Āyasthūṇa,@} but
is here no doubt a misreading of {@Jānaki.@}
<F>1) vii. 34.</F>
<F>2) ii. 3, 8, 1; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xi. 1.</F>
<F>3) vi. 3, 10 (Kāṇva).</F>

<L>1051<pc>1-284<k1>jAmAtf<k2>jAmAtf

<L>1052<pc>1-284<k1>jAmi<k2>jAmi
{@Jāmi,@}¦ a word which appears originally to have meant
‘related in blood,’ is not rarely used as an epithet of ‘sister’
({@Svasṛ@}), and sometimes even denotes ‘sister’ itself, the
emphasis being on the blood-relationship.<sup>1</sup> So it appears in
a passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> where ‘brotherless sisters’
[Page1-285+ 39]
({%abhrātara iva jāmayaḥ%}) are referred to. The word is similarly
used in the dispute occurring in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> as to
the precedence of Rākā, or of the wives of the gods, in a certain
rite. One party is there described as holding that the sister
should be preferred ({%jāmyai vai pūrva-peyam%}) — apparently at a
ceremonial family meal — to the wife, presumably as being of
one blood with the husband, while the wife is not (being {%anyo-%}
{%daryā,%} ‘of another womb’).<sup>4</sup> In the neuter<sup>5</sup> the word means
‘relationship,’ like {%jāmi-tva,%} which also occurs in the Rigveda.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) {%Cf.%} Delbrück, {%Dic indogermanischen%}
{%Verwandtschaftsnamen,%} 463, 464. As ‘rela-
tion,’ it occurs, {%e.g.,%} Rv. i. 31, 10;
75, 3. 4; 100, 11; 124, 6, etc.; as
‘sister,’ Rv. i. 65, 7; x. 10, 10, etc.;
with {%svasā,%} i. 123, 5; 185, 5; iii. 1, 11;
ix. 65, 1; 89, 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) i. 17, 1.</F>
<F>3) iii. 37.</F>
<F>4) Delbrück, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>5) Rv. iii. 54, 9; x. 10, 4; {%jāmi-kṛt,%}
‘making relationship,’ Av. iv. 19, 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Altareya Brāhmaṇa, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>6) i. 105, 9; 166, 13; x. 55, 4; 64, 13.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1053<pc>1-285<k1>jAmiSaMsa<k2>jAmiSaMsa

mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> showing that family disputes
were not rare. This is also indicated by the word {@Bhrātṛvya,@}
which, while properly meaning ‘father's brother's son,’ regularly
denotes simply ‘enemy.’
<F>1) ii. 10, 1 (= Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 5, 6, 3), and personified in ix. 4, 15.

<L>1056<pc>1-285<k1>jAyA<k2>jAyA
{@Jāyā@}¦ regularly denotes ‘wife,’ and, as opposed to {@Patnī,@} wife
as an object of marital affection, the source of the continuance
[Page1-286+ 57]
of the race.<sup>1</sup> So it is used of the wife of the gambler, and of
the wife of the Brāhmaṇa in the Rigveda;<sup>2</sup> it is also frequently
combined with {@Pati,@} ‘husband,’<sup>3</sup> both there and in the later
literature.<sup>4</sup> Patnī, on the other hand, is used to denote the
wife as partner in the sacrifice;<sup>5</sup> when no share in it is assigned
to her, she is called Jāyā.<sup>6</sup> The distinction is, of course,
merely relative; hence one text<sup>7</sup> calls Manu's wife Jāyā,
another<sup>8</sup> Patnī. Later on Jāyā is superseded by Dāra.
<F>1) Delbrück, {%Die indogermanischen Ver-%}
{%wandtschaftsnamen,%} 411, 412. {%Cf.%} Rv.
i. 105, 2; 124, 7; iii. 53, 4; iv. 3, 2;
18, 3; ix. 82, 4; x. 10, 7; 17, 1; 71, 4,
etc.; Av. iii. 30, 2; vi. 60, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) x. 34, 2. 3. 13, and x. 109.</F>
<F>3) Rv. iv. 3, 2; x. 149, 4.</F>
<F>4) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 23, 1. {%Cf.%}
vii. 13, 10; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
iv. 6, 7, 9. {%Cf.%} Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
i. 6, 12.</F>
<F>5) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 9, 2, 14.</F>
<F>6) i. 1, 4, 13.</F>
<F>7) {%Ibid.,%} i. 1, 4, 16.</F>
<F>8) Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 8, 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1057<pc>1-286<k1>jAyAnya<k2>jAyAnya
{@Jāyānya,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Jāyenya,@}<sup>2</sup> are variant forms of the name of a
disease mentioned in the Atharvaveda and the Taittirīya Saṃ-
hitā. In one passage of the former text<sup>3</sup> it is mentioned with
jaundice ({%harimā%}) and pains in the limbs ({%aṅga-bhedo visalpakaḥ%}).
Zimmer<sup>4</sup> thinks these are its symptoms, and identifies it with a
kind of Yakṣma, or disease of the lungs. Bloomfield<sup>5</sup> prefers
to identify it with syphilis, in accordance with certain indica-
tions in the ritual of the Kauśika Sūtra.<sup>6</sup> Roth conjectures
‘gout,’ but Whitney<sup>7</sup> leaves the nature of the disease doubtful.

Wise, {%Hindu System of Medicint,%} 321,
describing Akṣata.</F>
<F>5) {%American Journal of Philology,%} 11,
320 {%et seq.; Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%}
559-561.</F>
<F>6) xxxii. 11. {%Cf.%} also the commentary
on Av. vii. 76, and Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
{%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>7) Translation of the Atharvaveda, 442.

often used mythologically, as, {%e.g., jāra%}

1. {%Cf%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
308.</F>

<L>1077<pc>1-289<k1>jEtrAyaRasahojit<k2>jEtrAyaRasahojit
{@Jaitrāyaṇa Saho-jit@}¦ is apparently in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>1</sup>
the name of a prince who celebrated the Rājasūya, or ‘royal
consecration.’ Von Schroeder<sup>2</sup> quotes in support of Jaitrā-

of Jaitra,’ formed according to the Gaṇa {%karṇādi,%} which is

parallel passage of the Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup> the reading is
different, and no proper personal name appears, the subject
being Indra, the god. This reading seems much more probable,
for the verse should be general, and suit every king performing
the rite.

<L>1081<pc>1-290<k1>jYAtf<k2>jYAtf

<L>1083<pc>1-291<k1>jyA<k2>jyA
{@Jyā@}¦ is the regular word for ‘bowstring’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
and later.<sup>2</sup> The making of bowstrings was a special craft, as
is shown by the occurrence of the Jyā-kāra, or ‘maker of bow-
strings,’ among the victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human
sacrifice, in the Yajurveda.<sup>3</sup> The bowstring consisted of a
thong of ox-hide.<sup>4</sup> It was not usually kept taut,<sup>5</sup> but was
specially tightened when the bow was to be used.<sup>6</sup> The sound
of the bowstring ({%jyā-ghoṣa%}) is referred to in the Atharvaveda.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} {@Ārtnī.@}

<F>2) Av. i. 1, 3; v. 13, 6; vi. 42, 1;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 9; xxix. 51,
etc.</F>
<F>3) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 7; Tait-
tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 3, 1.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 75, 3; Av. i. 1, 3. In the
Epic the bowstring is made of hemp
({%maurvī%}); Hopkins, {%Journal of the%}

<L>1091<pc>1-293<k1>jyotiza<k2>jyotiza
{@Jyotiṣa,@}¦ ‘astronomy.’ It is important to note that no refer-
ence to any work on astronomy occurs in the Saṃhitās or
Brāhmaṇas. The text which claims to represent the astro-
nomical science of the Veda has been edited by Weber,<sup>1</sup> and
has frequently been discussed since.<sup>2</sup> Its date is unknown, but
is undoubtedly late, as is shown alike by the contents and form
of the work.
<F>1) {%Ueber den Vedakalender namens%}
{%Jyotiṣam%} (1862).</F>
<F>2) See references in Thibaut, {%Astren-%}
{%omie, Astrologie und Mathematik,%} 20, 29.</F>

<L>1095<pc>1-294<k1>takman<k2>takman
{@Takman@}¦ is a disease repeatedly mentioned in the Athar-
vaveda, but later not known under this name. It is the subject
of five hymns<sup>1</sup> of the Atharvaveda, and is often mentioned else-
where.<sup>2</sup> Weber<sup>3</sup> first identified it with ‘fever,’ and Grohmann<sup>4</sup>
showed that all the symptoms pointed to that ailment.<sup>5</sup> Refer-
ence is made to the alternate hot and shivering fits of the
patient,<sup>6</sup> to the yellow colour of the jaundice which accompanies
the fever,<sup>7</sup> and to its peculiar periodicity. The words used to
describe its varieties are {%anye-dyuḥ,%}<sup>8</sup> {%ubhaya-dyuḥ,%}<sup>9</sup> {%tṛtīyaka,%}<sup>10</sup>
{%vi-tṛtīya,%}<sup>11</sup> and {%sadaṃ-di,%}<sup>12</sup> the exact sense of most of which
terms is somewhat uncertain. It is agreed<sup>13</sup> that the first
epithet designates the fever known as {%quotidianus,%} which recurs
each day at the same hour, though the word is curious (lit.
[Page1-295+ 54]
‘on the other — {%i.e.,%} next, day’). The {%ubhaya-dyuḥ%} (‘on both
days’) variety appears to mean a disease recurring for two suc-
cessive days, the third being free; this corresponds to the {%rhythmus%}
{%quartanus complicatus.%}<sup>14</sup> But Sāyaṇa considers that it means a
fever recurring on the third day, the ‘tertian.’ The {%tṛtīyaka,%}
however, must be the ‘tertian’ fever,<sup>15</sup> though Zimmer<sup>16</sup> suggests
that it may mean a fever which is fatal at the third paroxysm.
Grohmann<sup>17</sup> regards the {%vi-tṛtīyaka%} as equivalent to the {%tertiana%}
{%duplicata,%} a common form in southern countries, in which the
fever occurs daily, but with a correspondence in point of time
or severity of attack on alternate days. Bloomfield<sup>18</sup> suggests
that it is identical with the {%ubhaya-dyuḥ%} variety. The {%sadaṃ-di%}<sup>19</sup>
type appears to be the kind later known as {%saṃtata-jvara%}
(‘continuous fever’), in which there are attacks of several days’
duration, with an interval followed by a fresh period of attack.
Fever occurred at different seasons, in the autumn ({%śārada%}), in
the hot weather ({%graiṣma%}), in the rains ({%vārṣika%}),<sup>20</sup> but was
especially prevalent in the first, as is indicated by the epithet
{%viśva-śārada,%} ‘occurring every autumn.’<sup>21</sup>
<div n="P"/>The disease is said to arise when Agni enters the waters.<sup>22</sup>
From this Weber<sup>23</sup> deduced that it was considered to be the
result of a chill supervening on heat, or the influence of heat on
marshy land. Grohmann<sup>24</sup> preferred to see in this connexion
of the origin of the disease with Agni's entering the waters<sup>25</sup>
an allusion to the fact that fever arises in the rainy season, the
time when Agni, as lightning, descends to earth with the rain.
Zimmer.<sup>26</sup> who accepts this view, further refers to the prevalence
[Page1-296+ 41]
of fever in the Terai, and interprets {%vanya,%} an epithet of fever
found in the Atharvaveda,<sup>27</sup> as meaning ‘sprung from the
forest,’ pointing out that fever is mentioned as prevalent among
the {@Mūjavants@} and {@Mahāvṛṣas,@} two mountain tribes of the
western Himālaya.<sup>28</sup> There is no trace of fever having been
observed to be caused by the bite of the {%anopheles%} mosquito,
which breeds in stagnant water: this theory has without reason
been held to be known to classical Indian medicine.<sup>29</sup>
<div n="P"/>Among the symptoms of Takman, or among complications
accompanying it, are mentioned ‘itch’ ({@Pāman@}), ‘headache’
({%śīrṣa-śoka%}),<sup>30</sup> ‘cough’ ({@Kāsikā@}), and ‘consumption,’ or perhaps
some form of itch ({@Balāsa@}).
<div n="P"/>It is perhaps significant that the Takman does not appear
until the Atharvaveda. It is quite possible that the Vedic
Āryans, when first settled in India, did not know the disease,
which would take some generations to become endemic and
recognized as dangerous. What remedies they used against it
is quite uncertain, for the Atharvaveda mentions only spells
and the {@Kuṣṭha,@} which can hardly have been an effective
remedy, though still used in later times. Fever must, even in
the Atharvan period, have claimed many victims, or it would
not be mentioned so prominently.
<F>1) i. 25; v. 22; vi. 20; vii. 116;
xix. 39 ({%cf.%} v. 4).</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 9, 8; v. 4. 1. 9; 30, 16;
ix. 8, 6; xi. 2, 22. 26, etc.</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Studien,%} 4, 119; Roth, {%Zur%}
{%Litteratur und Geschishte des Weda,%} 39,
had, from the use of Kuṣṭha as a
remedy, regarded it as denoting
‘leprosy,’ and was followed by Pictet,
Kuhn's {%Zeitschrift%} 5, 337. Muir, {%Sanskrit%}
{%Texts,%} 4, 280, thought ‘consumption’
was meant.</F>
<F>4) {%Indische Studien,%} 9, 381 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) See also Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the%}
{%Atharvaveda,%} 451 {%et seq.;%} Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
{%disches Leben,%} 379-385, and compare the
{%jvara%} (a non-Vedic word) of the classical
medicine, Wise, {%Hindu System of%}
{%Medicine,%} 219 {%et seq.;%} Jolly, {%Medicin,%}
70-72. Dārila and Keśava, the com-
mentators on the Kauśika Sūtra, every-
where equate {%takman%} and {%jvara.%}</F>
<F>6) Av. i. 25, 2-4; v. 22, 2. 7. 10;
vi. 20, 3; vii. 116, 1.</F>
<F>7) Av. i. 25, 2; v. 22, 2; vi. 20, 3.</F>
<F>8) Av. i. 25, 4; vii. 116, 2.</F>
<F>9) {%Ibid.%}</F>
<F>10) Av. i. 25, 4; v. 22, 13; xix. 39,
10.</F>
<F>11) Av. v. 22, 13.</F>
<F>12) Av. v. 22, 13; xix. 39, 10.</F>
<F>13) Grohmann, {%op. cit.,%} 387; Zimmer,
{%op. cit.,%} 382; Bloomfield, {%op. cit.,%}
274.</F>
<F>14) Grohmann, 388; Zimmer, 382;
Bloomfield, 274. It may conceivably
be the form styled Cāturthaka Vipar-
yaya (Wise, {%op. cit.,%} 232), in which the
paroxysm occurs every fourth day,
and lasts for two days.</F>

<L>1098<pc>1-297<k1>takzan<k2>takzan<h>1
1. {@Takṣan,@}¦ ‘carpenter,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and
often later.<sup>2</sup> He was employed to do all sorts of work in
wood, such as the making of chariots ({@Ratha@}) and wagons
({@Anas@}). Carved work of a finer type seems also to have fallen
to his lot.<sup>3</sup> The axe ({%kuliśa,%}<sup>4</sup> {%paraśu%})<sup>5</sup> is mentioned as one of
his tools, and perhaps the {@Bhurij,@} a word which is, however,
uncertain in sense. In one passage of the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> reference
seems to be made to the pains of the carpenter in bending
over his work. That the carpenters were a low caste, or
formed a separate class of the people, is certainly not true of
Vedic times.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) ix. 112, 1.</F>
<F>2) Av. x. 6, 3; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
xii. 10; xviii. 13; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
ii. 9, 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;
xxx. 6; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4,
2, 1; Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 3, 12;
iii. 6, 4, 4, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 86, 5; Av. xix. 49, 8. {%Cf.%}
Rv. i. 161, 9; iii. 60. 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iii. 2, 1.</F>
<F>5) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xii. 10.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 105, 18. {%Cf.%} Roth, {%Nirukta,%}
{%Erläuterungen,%} 67; Oldenberg. {%Ṛgveda-%}
{%Noten,%} 1, 100.</F>
<F>7) Fick, {%Die sociale Gliederung,%} 210,
n. 1.

<L>1106<pc>1-298<k1>tantu<k2>tantu

the ‘warp’ of a piece of weaving, as opposed to {@Otu,@} the ‘woof.’
Both senses are found in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> In the Śatapatha
Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> the ‘warp’ is called {%anuchāda,%} the ‘woof’ {%paryāsa,%}
the {%tantavaḥ%} being the ‘threads.’ In the Taittirīya Saṃhitā,<sup>3</sup>
[Page1-299+ 38]
on the other hand, the ‘warp’ is {%prācīna-tāna,%} the ‘woof’ {%otu.%}
The threads or cords of the throne ({@Pary ṅka@}) are referred to
in the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Rigveda the word is used only metaphorically, and
this is its most frequent use even in the Brāhmanas.<sup>5</sup> See
also {@Vāṇa.@}
<F>1) xiv. 2, 51 (opposed to {%otu%}); xv. 3, 6
(the {%prāñcaḥ%} and {%tiryañcaḥ%} threads or
cords of the throne of the Vrātya
[{@Āsandī@}]).</F>

<L>1124<pc>1-302<k1>taskara<k2>taskara
{@Taskara@}¦ occurs in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and frequently later,<sup>2</sup> denoting
‘thief’ or ‘robber.’ It appears to be practically synonymous
with {@Stena,@} in connexion with which it is often mentioned.<sup>3</sup>
The Stena and the Taskara are contrasted in the Vājasaneyi
Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup> with the {@Malimlu,@} who is a burglar or house-breaker,
while they are highwaymen, or, as the Rigveda<sup>5</sup> puts it, ‘men
who haunt the woods and risk their lives’ ({%tanū-tyajā vanar-gū%}).
In another passage of the Rigveda,<sup>6</sup> however, the dog is told to
bark at the Taskara or the Stena, which clearly points to an
attempt at house-breaking. The thief goes about at night,<sup>7</sup> and
knows the paths<sup>8</sup> on which he attacks his victim. In one
passage of the Rigveda<sup>9</sup> the use of cords is mentioned, but
whether to bind the thieves when captured, or to bind the
[Page1-303+ 53]
victim, is not clear.<sup>10</sup> The Atharvaveda<sup>11</sup> refers to the Stena
and the Taskara as cattle and horse thieves.<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) i. 191, 5; vi. 27, 3; vii. 55, 3;
viii. 29, 6.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 3, 2; xix. 47, 7; 50, 5;
Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 77-78; xii. 62;
xvi. 21, etc; Nirukta, iii. 14.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 55. 3; Av. xix. 47, 7;
50, 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 79;
xvi. 21, etc.</F>
<F>4) xi. 79 (the Malimlu is {%janeṣu,%} ‘among
men’; the others {%vane,%} ‘in the forest’).
{%Cf.%} for the Malimlu, Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
vi. 3, 2, 6; Atharvaveda, xix. 49, 10.</F>
<F>5) x. 4, 6.</F>
<F>6) vii. 55, 3.</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 191, 5.</F>
<F>8) Rv. viii. 29, 6.</F>
<F>9) x. 4, 6.</F>
<F>10) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 178, n.</F>
<F>11) xix. 50, 5. {%Cf.%} Rv. x. 97, 10 ({%stena%}).</F>
<F>12) Whitney, Translation of the Athar-
vaveda, 984.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1125<pc>1-303<k1>tAyu<k2>tAyu
{@Tāyu@}¦ was another name for thief, perhaps of a less
distinguished and more domestic character than the highway-
man, for though he is referred to as a cattle-thief,<sup>13</sup> he is also
alluded to as a stealer of clothes ({%vastra-mathi%})<sup>14</sup> and as a
debtor.<sup>15</sup> In one passage the Tāyus are said to disappear at
the coming of dawn (which is elsewhere called {%yāvayad-dveṣas,%}
‘driving away hostile beings,’ and {%ṛta-pā,%} ‘guardian of order’),
like the stars of heaven ({%nakṣatra%}).<sup>16</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Śatarudriya litany of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>17</sup> Rudra
is called lord of assailers ({%ā-vyādhin%}), thieves ({%stena%}), robbers
({%taskara%}), pickpockets ({%stāyu%}), stealers ({%muṣṇant%}), and cutters
({%vi-kṛnta%}); and designations of sharpers ({%gṛtsa%}) and bands
({%gaṇa, vrāta%}), apparently of robbers, are mentioned.<sup>18</sup> It is
therefore not surprising that the Rigveda<sup>19</sup> should contain
many prayers for safety at home or on the way, or that
the Atharvaveda should devote several hymns to night<sup>20</sup>
chiefly for protection against the evil doings of thieves and
robbers.
<div n="P"/>Pischel<sup>21</sup> suggests that in one passage of the Rigveda<sup>22</sup>
{@Vasiṣṭha@} is represented as a burglar, but the admits that, since
Vasiṣṭha was attacking the house of his father Varuṇa, he was
only seeking to obtain what he may have regarded as his own.
But the interpretation of the hymn is not certain.<sup>23</sup>
<div n="P"/>Sāyaṇa's explanation of one passage of the Rigveda,<sup>24</sup> as
[Page1-304+ 60]
referring to professional cattle-trackers, like the Khojis of the
Panjab, seems quite probable.<sup>25</sup>
<div n="P"/>The punishment of thieves appears primarily to have been
left to the action of the robbed. The practice of binding them
in stocks<sup>26</sup> seems clearly referred to. But later, at any rate — 
and in all probability earlier also, as in other countries — a more
severe penalty could be exacted, and death inflicted by the
king.<sup>27</sup> There is no hint in Vedic literature of the mode of
conviction; a fire ordeal is not known to the Atharvaveda,<sup>28</sup>
and the ordeal known to the Chāndogya Upaniṣad<sup>29</sup> is not said
to be used in the case of theft. No doubt the stolen property
was recovered by the person robbed if he could obtain it.
Nothing is known as to what happened if the property had
passed from the actual thief into the possession of another
person.
<F>13) Rv. i. 65, 1; vii. 86, 5.</F>
<F>14) Rv. iv. 38, 5.</F>
<F>15) Rv. vi. 12, 5. No doubt this theft

<L>1127<pc>1-305<k1>tAjadBaNga<k2>tAjadBaNga
{@Tājad-bhaṅga@}¦ (‘easily broken’) is apparently the name of
a tree or plant in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> The Kauśika Sūtra<sup>2</sup>

<L>1132<pc>1-306<k1>tAta<k2>tAta
{@Tāta,@}¦ apparently ‘dada's boy,’ an affectionate term of address
by a father ({%cf.%} {@Tata@}) to a son, is found in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>1</sup>
occurring in the vocative only. But in the sense of ‘father,’
through confusion with Tata, it occurs also as early as the
Aitareya Āraṇyaka.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 14, 4;
Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 1, 6;
Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iv. 4, 2.</F>
<F>2) i. 3, 3, where Tata and Tāta are
given as variant forms of the address
of the child to the father. Little,
{%Grammatical Index,%} 75, takes Tāta to
mean ‘father’ primarily, but this seems
unlikely.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Delbrück, {%Die indogermanischen%}
{%Verwandtschaftsnamen,%} 449, 454.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1134<pc>1-306<k1>tAnva<k2>tAnva<h>1
1. {@Tānva@}¦ in an obscure passage of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> seems to
mean a ‘legitimate son,’ who is said not to leave the heritage
({%riktha%}) of his father to his sister ({%jāmi%}). The exact meaning
is probably unascertainable,<sup>2</sup> but the passage may convey a
statement of what was no doubt the fact, that the daughter
had no share in the paternal inheritance; her brother had to
provide for her during her life if she remained unmarried, but
she had no independent portion.<sup>3</sup> (See {@Dāya.@})
<F>1) iii. 31, 2.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Griffith, {%Hymns of the Rigveda,%} 1,
348; Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda Noten,%} 1, 240;
Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 34.</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte,%} 87, for
the modern law of the Panjab.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1143<pc>1-308<k1>tArkzya<k2>tArkzya

<L>1144<pc>1-308<k1>tArpya<k2>tArpya
{@Tārpya@}¦ denotes, in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and later,<sup>2</sup> a garment
made of some material, the nature of which is uncertain. The
commentators on the Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra and the Śata-
patha Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> suggest that a linen garment, or one thrice
soaked in ghee, or one made of the {%tṛpā%} or of the {%triparṇa%} plant,

the author of the Brāhmaṇa himself. Goldstücker's<sup>4</sup> rendering
of the word is ‘silken garment,’ which Eggeling<sup>5</sup> is inclined
to accept.^6

Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 7, 1; 7, 6, 4;
Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxi. 1; Śata-
patha Brāhmaṇa, v. 3, 5, 20; Kātyāyana
Śranta Sūtra, xv. 5, 7 {%et seq.;%} Śāṅkh-
āyana Śrauta Sūtra, xvi. 12, 19.</F>
<F>3) v. 3, 5, 20. {%Cf.%} Kātyāyana, {%loc. cit.;%}

<L>1154<pc>1-310<k1>tirindira<k2>tirindira
{@Tirindira@}¦ is mentioned in a Dānastuti, or ‘Praise of Gifts,’
in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as having, along with {@Parśu,@} bestowed gifts
on the singer. In the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>2</sup> this state-
ment is represented by a tale that the Kaṇva Vatsa obtained
a gift from Tirindira Pāraśavya, Tirindira and Parśu being
in this version thus treated as one and the same man.
Ludwig<sup>3</sup> sees in the Rigvedic passage a proof that the Yadus
had gained a victory over Tirindira, and gave a part of the
booty to the singers; but there is no proof whatever of the
correctness of this interpretation, which Zimmer<sup>4</sup> shows to be
most unlikely. Yadu princes must be meant by Tirindira and
[Page1-311+ 57]
Parśu, though Weber<sup>5</sup> thinks that the singers were Yadus, not
the princes. The latter he holds to have been Iranian ({%cf.%}
<lang n="greek">Τιρίβαζος</lang>, and see {@Parśu@}), and he thinks that in this there is
evidence of continual close relations between India and Iran.
This is perfectly possible, but the evidence for it is rather
slight.

Iranian names found at Boghaz-kiöi,
{%cf.%} Jacobi, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
{%Society,%} 1909, 721 {%et seq.;%} Oldenberg,
{%ibid.,%} 1095-1100; Keith, {%ibid.,%} 1100-1106;
Sayce, {%ibid.,%} 1106, 1107; Kennedy,
{%ibid.,%} 1107-1119. Hillebrandt, {%Vedische%}
{%Mythologie,%} 1, 94 {%et seq.,%} argues in favour
of an early connexion of Iranians and
Indians in Arachosia, where he places
part of the action of the Rigveda.
Hopkins, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
{%Society,%} 17, 16, 277, holds that traces of
Iranian connexion are signs of late
date; Arnold, {%ibid.,%} 18, 205 {%et seq.,%}
opposes this view.

<F>2) xvi. 11. 20.</F>

<L>1158<pc>1-312<k1>tila<k2>tila
{@Tila@}¦ denotes in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> the sesamum
plant, and particularly its grains, from which a rich oil ({@Taila@})
was extracted. It is often<sup>3</sup> mentioned in connexion with {@Māṣa,@}
‘kidney bean.’ The Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup> attributes the bean
and the sesamum to the winter ({%hemanta%}) and the cool ({%śiśira%})
seasons. The stalk of the sesamum plant ({%tila-piñjī,%}<sup>5</sup> {%til-piñja%}<sup>6</sup>)
was used for fuel, and the seed was boiled in the form of
porridge ({%tilaudana%}<sup>7</sup>) for food.

<L>1170<pc>1-314<k1>turva<k2>turva
{@Turva@}¦ occurs only once in the Rigveda (x. 62, 10), doubtless
